PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 August, on motion by Senator Minchin:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —To conclude, the Labor Party believes that the Senate should carry a second reading amendment. Accordingly, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the motion, add:
"but the Senate:
(1) is of the opinion that a properly resourced university sector is vital to Australia's economic and social well‐being;

(2) expresses deep concern at the damage caused by the Government's funding reductions to higher education, which are forcing universities to seek alternative sources of funds, such as undergraduate fees, which in turn are reducing access to universities at the very time when Australia needs to be broadening such access;
(3) expressed particular concern at the ending of the successful Commonwealth Industry Places Scheme; and
(4) condemns the Government for failing to recognise the importance of education to Australia's future and for continuing to withdraw public investment in it".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting the measures contained in the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1997 . There are a number of measures in this bill to which I will refer. First of all, I note that this particular higher education funding bill departs from tradition; that is, it represents a break from the traditional structure of higher education bill funding in that it allows for the provision of funds for 1998 and earlier. I note there is no allocation for 1999 and 2000. I think you will find that a number of advocacy groups are very concerned about that change to the triennium funding structure for higher education in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats will be supporting the simplification of the remission of debt for the open learning scheme. I note that this government is the first government to preside over a universal up‐front fee payment for undergraduate education with the introduction of a gap fee. A gap fee is one that open learning students have no opportunity to defer. So although it can be argued that open learning is one way of making higher education more accessible to, say, traditionally disadvantaged groups, particularly those in remote or regional areas, the lack of opportunity to defer those payments is sad.

This government is also continuing the tradition of user pays begun under the former Labor government. I note the amount that the Commonwealth is granting towards the open learning system is only $218,000 in this bill, compared with around $9.5 million as recently as 1995. I am dismayed to see a diminution in the resources being allocated to open learning in this bill. In fact, it puts Australia at odds with the rest of the world which is increasingly recognising the joys and the possibilities of open learning and distance education. This bill also allows for the 25 per cent discount on some course contributions.

Probably one of the biggest features of this bill is the rationalisation and restructuring program—$26 million over the next four years. While the Democrats support that additional money, particularly for regional and remote institutions, we treat this as an acknowledgment, as basically a concession by this government that, in fact, its regressive budget cuts have hit hardest at regional and remote institutions.

The Democrats will be supporting the Labor Party's second reading amendment and we will seek to amend that with a second reading amendment of our own. We endorse the sentiments expressed by Senator Carr in his amendment, but we recognise, as our second reading amendment does, that this path of user pays was begun under the Hawke and Keating governments and simply entrenched at a rate of knots by the current coalition government.

BREAK.PARA: I am also glad to see that the second reading amendment moved by the opposition makes recognition of the Commonwealth industry places scheme, CIPS, which has been cut by this government. Under that scheme industry funded 40 per cent of a university place while the student and the Commonwealth made up the remaining 60 per cent. The loss of this scheme will hit specific institutions harder than others. For example, Charles Sturt University is losing 1,076 places, Deakin University is losing 505 places and Swinburne University of Technology is losing 528 places. It certainly puts paid to the government's rhetoric that somehow we are seeing an additional allocation of places, be they undergraduate or others, around the country this year.

Substantial losses like this cannot be overcome. It has been suggested by this government that the rationalisation and restructuring program will go some way towards addressing the loss of places like CIPS places. Certainly, while we welcome that package, it will not address any of the other symptoms of the coalition's savage budget cuts. We welcome the admission by the coalition that there is a funding crisis in our universities across the country, with regional and remote institutions being hit hardest, but this package will not go far enough.

We have heard a lot from the minister who has responsibility for enrolments. I am surprised to see that still the minister insists that enrolments—that is, the final enrolments in institutions—certainly are stable or up in some places, but would not a better indicator of demand for higher education places be applications for enrolment? As has been said many times in this place, certainly by the Australian Democrats, applications for enrolment in tertiary education around this country this year are down. They are down across the board. In particular, mature age students have been hit hardest with up to a 17 per cent decline in some states and territories in relation to applications for enrolment.

I was stunned to see the minister's press release last week which claimed that universities were `thriving' in light of all the information we have had from institutions and repre sentative organisations that this is not the case. In fact, I note that today's paper refers to 36,000 overenrolments. Certainly the government has been quite keen to encourage overenrolments, especially if it does not have to pay the full HECS liable load cost. I think it is outrageous that institutions have not only had to deal with funding cuts but are now expected to cater for massive levels of overenrolment, never mind the impact that this has on course quality and teaching standards.

So we have not heard the real story of what is going on at universities from the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. We do know that 10,000 fewer mature age students have applied for places this year; that is, they were turned off from applying for university. They did not apply for enrolment this year, and I would bet my bottom dollar that it was the prohibitive cost of studying that has meant many of these students did not pursue the enrolment process.

I take the University of Newcastle as an example. Presumably, this is an institution that would be targeted by the rationalisation and restructuring package, but many of the changes that have already taken place—the cuts that have been made—have radically affected this institution. So even these kinds of programs are not going to provide enough resources to make up for the cuts that have already been suffered. I will refer to just a few of the staffing and funding cuts which have to be taken into account. These cuts are a direct result of the government's budget changes last year.

In the faculty of art and design, nine academic staff have been lost; in the faculty of education, 15 academic staff and three general staff have been lost; in the faculty of engineering, 11 academic staff and 20 general staff have been lost; in the faculty of medicine and health sciences, 14 academic and 30 general staff have gone; in the faculty of nursing, there is $340,000 worth of cuts, and six staff and three general staff have gone; in the faculty of science and maths, 18 academic staff and 13 general staff have gone.

These universities are not thriving, contrary to the minister's claims last week. The Uni versity of Newcastle is not thriving with 95 academic staff and 198 general staff being made redundant. It is shameful, and blame can be directly attributed to the federal government for these radical cuts and regressive changes.

So the university may have fewer staff but, as the minister continues to maintain and certainly today's papers and overenrolment stories confirm, enrolments have been maintained. In fact, overenrolments in some institutions are incredibly high, class sizes have jumped, student contact hours have been reduced, and tutorial times and access have been reduced. This is the reality; these are the consequences of rising enrolments.

The library at the University of Newcastle has cut its budget by $900,000 and up to 21 library staff may be lost. So I am curious to hear the minister's response to that case study of a particular institution which has suffered from funding cuts over the last 12 to 18 months.

Continually, there is this focus on final enrolments. When are we going to hear from the government an explanation for the drop in enrolment applications, in particular the drop in enrolment applications among mature age students? When I asked the minister in estimates whether she was concerned about the number of enrolments and perhaps that it was not such a benefit to have overenrolments in institutions that had suffered so many cuts, she replied:

. . . if you have a lecture theatre in which there are—just for the sake of argument—20 spare seats, and you have got the lecturer, then the additional cost of overenrolling and filling up those seats is negligible, because you are only talking about extra course materials. Your infrastructure and all the rest of the stuff is there, the lights and everything are on in any event.

The lights may be on, but what if nobody is home when a student needs assistance? What if there is a lack of resources, tutors or lecturers to help? What use is that? It takes more than a few spare seats and a light on to fill those extra 20 places and to run a university—something that I think this government is yet to grapple with, let alone comprehend.

In many cases, the staff needed to ensure meaningful assessment are no longer there—certainly, at the University of Newcastle. Libraries have been cut and important means of educational assistance and support are going. Certainly at the University of Newcastle this is the case, and this is not an unusual situation. The staff levels are such that there are not the human resources to accommodate any extra students.

In the Hunter region, the education sector employs more people than BHP. So this government is responsible for the enormous upheaval and trauma as a direct result of funding cuts by this government in previous budgets which face all those who live in that particular region. Whether it is their own job that is lost or whether it is a family member who is denied access to education or any one of the many activities, such as research and development which flow on from campus life, that region is affected. It is not an isolated example. The destruction and pain in regional Australia can also be seen at the Northern Territory University.

The Northern Territory University has been forced to abandon its English department. It is extraordinary that in the Northern Territory, as far as we know, there is not an English literature department or access to English literature at an undergraduate level. This decision has been made in response, apparently, to the coalition's funding cuts. It has already been instituted over the recent semester break.

Staff from other disciplines, none of them related to English literature, will now be required to take on the existing load. That is not my idea of quality in education or access to courses and stability needed for universities to develop and, indeed, to thrive, to use the minister's terminology. So now we have an education sector where a university does not have an English department, in the case of the NTU, and where an entire territory population does not have an English department.

This afternoon I will be going to the Australian National University where they are facing the closure of their classics department. So it is not an isolated case. This is not just restricted to regional universities. The quality of our education is under threat and yet students are paying more for this privilege. That disdain for equity and fairness is also contained in another measure in this bill.

On 15 May Senator Vanstone issued a challenge to the Australian Democrats and the opposition to vote down—dare we vote down—the introduction of a 25 per cent discount for up‐front payments of HECS debts of over $500. If the media reports are correct—and I am always willing to place a little degree of scepticism when reading the media—then the minister stated that this change was good news for students and that this would not favour those richer students—that is, those students who had ready access to wealth or cash.

The introduction of a 25 per cent discount for payments over $500 is only fair in the context that this same discount is already available for those students who have access to the wealth required to make a full and up-front payment of their liability before the census date. We described it as a bit like a mugger leaving you a tip.

For the majority of students who cannot afford to pay their HECS upfront this is a regressive measure. You only have to look at the statistics of the types of students who are making up-front payments to realise that. As recently as 1995 there is public policy advice on this that clearly shows that the students who have the ability to make those payments tend to be older, professional and, in many cases, working students. We do argue that it rewards those students who have access to wealth more so than others. That is the overwhelming direction of this government.

We now have a higher education system where students are not charged according to their eventual earnings but they are charged a combination of the cost of their course and their expected earnings, their potential earnings. I do not think that happens anywhere else in the world. The differential HECS is a tax on the income a student or a graduate may never earn. It is a system where someone doing secretarial studies or science is charged at the second highest level of HECS.

I acknowledge that the Labor Party created the HECS system where up‐front payment was rewarded to such a degree that the wealthy were afforded a substantial advantage. So I do acknowledge that this government is perhaps trying to evenly distribute or make more widely available some of those discounts that were introduced by the former government. But it is an extension of a privilege that is not available to those students who do not have money.

Not content with lowering the threshold at which people repay their HECS debt to 27 per cent less than average weekly earnings—a measure which came into effect on 1 July—an additional burden which again raises the ire of HECS debtors against this government, they have now decided to make it easier for those people with money. If you cannot afford the up-front discount on your band one HECS debt for a three‐year degree you will owe $10,069. If you can afford to pay it upfront it will be $7,425. At the other end of the scale, take band three, the HECS debt at the end of three years is $17,682. The amount that you will have to pay courtesy of the discount for payment upfront is $12,375.

Put simply, on graduation a student who has no choice but to defer their payment will have a HECS bill 43 per cent greater than the payments made by their more wealthy classmate. So if the person standing right next to them in the graduation ceremony has more money they will have less of a debt. According to Swindler's List, a recent study, that I am sure the minister is familiar with, by the Deakin University Students Association:
People earning well below average earnings could pay nearly 70% more for the same degree as someone earning $37,263 and more than three times the figure of someone who pays their HECS upfront . . .

The government argues that they are not rewarding those with access to money. Since most women will earn less than and take longer than men to repay their HECS debt, `. . . more women will pay much more for their degrees than men'. That is the finding of Swindler's List. We know that women are less likely to repay their HECS debt. By the age of 30, they are five times less likely than men to repay their HECS debt. I am sure those statistics have altered only slightly since the NATSEM modelling of 1992. It is a bit ironic considering this week is blue stocking week when we not only commemorate the first female academics but we seek to remove the barriers to participation and entry into higher education for women.

I was also amazed to hear the rhetoric in this chamber on Monday when the minister responded to a dorothy dixer about the fact that this government was not intending to leave young people with a great amount of debt because they had cleared the so-called budget black hole. This generation is the debt generation. More than ever before, young people are leaving universities, schools and so on with debts on their heads—debts the size of their parents' houses if you take into account a combination of HECS and Austudy loans.

If you are a poor university the government is saying to you, `We will offer you a small amount of the moneys that we ripped away from you last year,'—in the form of the restructuring package—`but we will continue to rip you off for the next four years anyway.' If you are a poor or average student then the good news from this minister and this government is that you will get a discount on an up-front payment of more than $500. I presume that the government is hoping that the students who cannot afford $500 are not able to do the sums to see that yet again they are the ones who are being hit hardest and missing out.

I feel that the government is rubbing salt into the wound. I have said that we will support this measure today because we will do anything to give some people an opportunity to repay their HECS debts, but what we object to vehemently is the fact that it is constantly the rich who are rewarded. Whether it is by this higher education policy under this government or the former government, the discounts benefit those with ready access to money.

It added salt to the wounds when the minister dared us to vote down this measure. She added a double dare claiming that students have a tendency to want to complain and therefore we should support the measures. That tendency has never been more justified than it is now. Students have the right to complain when they are still waiting to receive an Austudy payment. No‐one can convince me or them that it is appropriate that students who applied for their Austudy, say, in January or February should still be waiting for it in the middle of the year. We do have many examples of people who were still waiting for their Austudy notice of assessment in, say, June or July. They are still waiting today for reassessments or appeals. So the media attention may have been moved on, but I can assure you that those students will never forget how they were treated by this government and how this government handled their affairs.

These changes are indeed like the mugger leaving you a tip. Australian universities have been mugged of six per cent of their operating grant from now until the year 2001 and now they are being given a tip of $26 million in the restructuring package. Students are being told, `If you have ready access to wealth, we will give bonus too.' That is another slap in the face for those who are not able to pay.

Unlike the coalition, the Australian Democrats believe in intergenerational equity. We believe in social justice, the right to a fair go and to participate fully in society regardless of wealth. That includes access to education regardless of background. We will support this bill today, but we will continue to do our utmost to restore quality and accessibility to the education system. I move:
At the end of the amendment, add:
"and

(e) notes that these cuts have been made to a higher education sector which was already under immense pressure as a result of the funding decline of thirteen per cent of Equivalent Full Time Student Units over the thirteen year term of the Hawke‐Keating government".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Denman, Sen Kay

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in the second reading debate on the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1997 . There appears to be a perception that, over the 13‐year period that the Labor government was in power, there was a winding down of support for tertiary education. Nothing could be further from the truth, as funding was massively improved to this sector of education. By the close of the previous government's 13‐year period in office, doubling of the tertiary intake was attained. That was no mean feat. I mention this because I am concerned that, as we all know, this government has been tinkering in the tertiary education sector; the result of which could not be better exemplified than by the introduction of this bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot fathom to what end this government has targeted the tertiary education sector so vigorously. The whole manner in which the universities have been treated by the government is saddening. We built up the tertiary sector over 13 years, and the government seems to be on track to destroy it within half that time. The government claims that, because of their efforts, they have strengthened the framework of this sector. It is claimed that this bill builds on this strong framework by supporting rationalisation of programs and joint development of infrastructure. We have now witnessed a massive cutting of funds, and savings made by changes to HECS. That will cause a curtailment in growth that I expect will be felt in the years ahead. It is difficult to gauge the effect of these cuts on the nation as a whole. Certainly, rural Australia has felt the changes.

The strong framework that this government talks about having built is a furphy. We know that institutions are struggling to attract investment capital for new technologies and teaching materials. We now know that the demands have become so great because of these cuts that the only way to get universities back up to speed and competing internationally is by a large injection of Commonwealth government funding.

The funds provided under this bill are a step in the right direction, but they are a drop in the ocean as to what is required to clean up the mess that this government has initiated. Our young people have experienced and continue to experience first hand increases in their HECS charges with the introduction of the double whammy of lower repayment thresholds. It is difficult to see how the implementation in this bill of the budget proposal of a 25 per cent discount for partial up-front HECS payments of at least $500 or more will assist many of those struggling students and families who do not have adequate funds.

As has been said, students from lower socioeconomic bands who require assistance will not get it. There will be a shutting out, as in the old days, of those individuals from these bands. It is a shame, because it will not assist in developing our intellectual base. The cuts to the operating grants will not necessarily be felt immediately; they will have more of an impact in the years ahead. The cuts to operating grants have not stopped, either. In the year 2000, a further funding reduction of one per cent, realising $47.3 million, will be imposed.

It has been a tough period for young adults with these cuts and savings being realised. They are in the front line. It must be hard for students, for example, to pay up‐front fees for attendance at optional study sessions. But then it has not been easy for the hardworking mums and dads who only want the best for their children in what is becoming an increasingly competitive environment.

I understand that there are now 25 per cent fewer non‐fee paying university places available than there were a couple of years ago. I do not know how accurate that figure is, but it is very disturbing. I expect that parents from wealthy backgrounds will not be too concerned, but it is certainly going to be difficult for those parents who are less fortunate.

It has also been a tough period for our vice‐chancellors. They are alarmed about the way this government has caused future investment in the sector to be placed in doubt. The university administrators will find it difficult to put into place concrete plans to cope with the cuts because of the absence of an allocation of funding amounts beyond 1998. There is no doubt that there must be accountability in how we spend the tertiary sector dollar. But, for the federal government to cut to a stage whereby that cutting fundamentally damages the sector resulting in the necessity for there to be a redressing of the imbalance by introducing measures such as those contained in this bill, defies explanation.

This bill does not go anywhere near far enough to assist higher education institutions that have been crushed and will be further crushed, as I have explained. My home institution, the University of Tasmania—which should be playing a leading role in ensuring that our youth in regions like the North West Coast of Tasmania remain and receive quality education—has suffered because of the reduction of 160 jobs. All the social and economic commentators within the state are advising that a major problem is the retention of our young adults at tertiary level, so it is sad that the budget cuts have been levied so hard on the island of Tasmania.
Let us hope that the provisions in this bill will at least go some way towards ameliorating the damage caused. But, unfortunately, I will not hold my breath.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1997 is not one on which I feel enthusiastic about voting either for or against because both are problematic. Voting `no' votes against slight increases in funding and the discount in clarification of the debt. There are potentially some positive measures, but I will explain what some of these issues are.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill does three things: it provides an additional discount for students making voluntary contributions of $500 or more towards their HECS debt; it makes amendments to supplementary funding; and it clarifies when students' HECS debts can be waived. First of all, the provision of an additional discount for students making voluntary contributions of $500 or more towards their HECS debts. You need to have some basic economics to look at this kind of measure.

This is not the first time that such measures have taken place. I remember seeing similar things under Labor. You have to wonder about long-term planning when it is necessary to bring forward expected payments of such a nature. It does not mean that extra money is coming into the system. Of course, when you give extra discounts, the total revenue that is coming in will in fact be less. It is a bit like what happened a few years ago when a great many health clubs in Australia got into financial trouble. Although they were gaining revenue by selling life memberships they found out in the end that they had so many people on life memberships they were not getting in any new revenue.

We have a similar kind of problem in this case in that what you have is an expected repayment at some stage. When you get short of money, you try to draw in that expected payment earlier but, of course, that leaves potential problems in the down years for that expected revenue which will no longer be coming at a later date. It is simply shifting the problem. It is not providing extra revenue; it is shifting the problem to later years.

We have had long-term concerns about providing incentives for richer students to pay off their HECS debt. Although it reduces their debt, which the Greens (WA) support, it does not reduce the debt for all students, only those who can afford to pay. We then end up with a situation where poorer students who cannot pay their debt are suffering the full debt while students who can pay receive a 25 per cent discount or more on their HECS debt and are paying far less. This clearly is not an equitable repayment system.

A related issue is the level of HECS repayments. Four per cent, five per cent or six per cent of a middle income is more than a tax on some people repaying their HECS debt involuntarily. One of my constituents put the high HECS repayments threshold as the reason why he and his wife may go bankrupt over the next fortnight. With the increase in the HECS repayment threshold from 1 July, the bank will foreclose on them with more money coming out of their bank accounts involuntarily. This puts enormous pressure on families where the ex-student trying to pay off their HECS debt is the sole income earner for the family. This is where the HECS debt does not just affect the person who is receiving an education but it also affects their ability to support their families.

In this case, the sole income earner also paying the debt is a woman with a husband and children.They believe what the federal government is doing is very unfair. When she took a degree under the HECS system she believed the government at the time that the HECS repayments would be affordable for people, but they are not. It is now an open matter that HECS is a tax on education, but for some that tax is crippling. It is ironic that even a conservative government which purports to represent families does not look at the impacts of the increased HECS repayments on young couples and families.

In relation to amendments to supplementary funding, the $10.2 million in 1997-98 for restructuring and rationalising activities is no sweetener. It is to help universities implement the $1 billion in cuts by sacking staff, downsizing departments and so on. The money may also be used to help ex-colleges of advanced education which ran the bulk of shared industry places to restructure courses.

The Commonwealth industry places scheme, which paid for 60 per cent of an industry place while the industry funded the rest, has been scraped. The Greens found it difficult to see why the government would be subsidising industry training at universities and hope that industry will meet the shortfall in funds if they want university level training in their sectors to continue. It is funny, isn't it, that people are being asked to pay for services which you would normally expect taxpayers' money to pay for but industry is being subsidised for training which actually benefits them.

In relation to circumstances under which HECS debts can be waived, it is important that students are not charged for units they do not complete. However, under part 4, subsection 20(2)(c), the onus is on the student to apply to the secretary but this will not function well unless students know their rights in this regard. I hope the government makes debt remission a part of the HECS literature that is sent to each student periodically about their debt so that students can act in their own interests.

Normally, the legislation that is before us provides funding for the next triennium. However, this bill provides funding only for 1998 and not for 1999 and 2000. We talk about the necessity for certainty and for some sort of security within business, but it is interesting that the university sector is being held on tenterhooks. Why is this? One view is that the government is waiting for the results of the higher education review in December 1997. The higher education sector is still in the throes of dealing with the government's 1996‐97 budget changes which cut a total of $623 million over four years from the budget.

Operating grants are to be cut by one per cent in 1997, three per cent in 1998 and one per cent in 1999. These budget changes have already had a massive effect on the student intake and socioeconomic background of students, course quality, courses offered, staff cuts and university infrastructure. At the same time, operating grants have been cut. The government forced universities to over enrol to mask the fact that the usual intake of students amongst higher scores was down. This means that limited dollars have to be stretched even further.

For those students who have been prevented from attending university because of the cost, the youth allowance changes means that if they cannot afford to study they will not have an income at all. This is a callous and irresponsible government that does not want to invest in young people unless they are all of a particular social class.

I, therefore, will find myself out of the chamber when the vote for this bill takes place. But I would like to indicate that I will be supporting the ALP second reading amendment and the amendment to that amendment that has been moved by Senator Stott Despoja for the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak against the amendment moved to my second reading amendment by Senator Stott Despoja for the Australian Democrats. This is an amendment which argues that there was a funding decline of 13 per cent of equivalent full-time student units over the 13 year term of the Hawke-Keating governments. I put to the Senate that this amendment should be opposed because it is factually incorrect.

SPEECH.PARA: Essentially, there will be those around who would always argue that there should be more money allocated than has been allocated—and I do not dispute that claim that is often made. But to state, as it does, in this amendment that there was a funding decline of 13 per cent for effective full‐time student units over 13 years I maintain is just wrong. If the Democrats were arguing that there was a funding decline of seven per cent for the operating grants if measured on a per student basis, then I could argue the toss about that. But I would essentially have to acknowledge that there was a seven per cent decline in the operating grants if you measured them on that particular scale. What that statistic does is misrepresent the total amount of money that was actually spent in higher education under the Labor government.

Higher education funding is measured on a student basis. That part is accurate, but there is a total amount of money that needs to be considered, not just one particular measure. Commonwealth higher education expenditure increased by four per cent between 1983 and 1997. That is more accurate. The increase was from $12,110 per student to $12,530 per student. But such figures take into account the full spending on higher education, not just one aspect of it.

What occurred was that the Commonwealth increased expenditure on higher education at a greater rate than it did on student places. Funding increased in real terms by 69 per cent from $3.1 billion in 1983 to $5.3 billion in 1997 under the Labor government. Over the same period, Commonwealth funded student places increased by 63 per cent from 260,000 EFTSU in 1983 to 424,500 EFTSU in 1997.

As I say, operating grants per EFTSU did decrease by seven per cent from 11,600 in 1983 to 10,730 in 1997. But this decline in operating grants, the share of the total higher education funding, is due to the dramatic increases in funding for capital and research activities under the period of the Labor government. There was a massive transfer of research funding previously included in the operating grants to the Australian Research Council from 1989, so it was a matter of changing one particular column to another in terms of the way in which these calculations were made by the department. That accounts for the drop in this particular statistic. It was a measurement change that resulted in what appears to be a drop, as indicated in the propaganda that the minister has been trying to push about in recent times.

All of the particular funds were transferred back to the universities. That is a fact. The funds into universities actually increased dramatically under Labor. Capital funding in 1997 in the last year of the triennium of the Labor government was $284 million—an increase of 440 per cent in terms of the base figure of 1983 which had capital funding of $52 million. Capital funding per EFTSU more than tripled during the period of the Labor government from $200 in 1983 to $670 in 1997. The research funding increased fivefold from $78 million in 1983 to $385 million in 1997. On a per EFTSU basis, research funding increased by 200 per cent from $300 in 1983 to $910 in 1997.

Of course, we do see the statistic pumped out every now and then in a more complete form in terms of the use of operating grants. I repeat: that figure can be accounted for simply by the changes in the calculations that were made. The measurements that were used were measuring different things. If you look at the total amount of funding spent on higher education over the period of the Labor government you see a change of 69 per cent in total expenditure by the Labor government on higher education—a massive shift in expenditure which reflected Labor's view that there should be a mass higher education sector in this country, that we should move to a democratic higher education sector in this country, and that there should be an opportunity for as many Australians as possible to go to university. I think in a large measure the Dawkins reforms were able to see that introduced.

What you saw under Labor was the increased capacity for ordinary Australians to actually attend a university. It was not perfect. I have made this point many times. We hear from the minister this red rag view that she now expresses that university should be open to the proletariat. I commend her for that. The truth of the matter is that the funding policies of this government prohibit that. They actually work in the opposite direction. We see from this government a move back to an elitist model of the 1950s that discourages working people from participating in the higher education sector in this country.

But it does the Democrats no service whatsoever to come into the Senate and put a position on the table here which is factually incorrect. It is a distortion and a distortion which I would expect from the minister but not from the Democrats. I might point to the distortion put by the minister. Recently we saw a similar sort of exercise undertaken at the estimates committee when the minister brought in a very large sheet of paper—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: I draw your attention to the fact that Senator Carr is addressing a quite specific amendment to the second reading motion. I would think in terms of relevance he would need to keep his remarks fairly strictly to the amendment proposed by Senator Stott Despoja. I do not think that something the minister said in estimates could possibly be termed relevant to this quite specific debate. I think Senator Carr, from memory, has already made a very eloquent contribution to the second reading debate in general terms. He should restrict his remarks to the quite specific terms of the Democrat amendment.
—You need to speak directly to the amendment, Senator Carr. There is no point of order.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I am speaking directly to the amendment, which says that there was a decline of 13 per cent equivalent full‐time student units over the 13 years. The amendment makes this claim. It is a claim that the minister has propagated at recent estimates committee hearings. It is a claim which was advanced in what I would have thought was quite an expensive little exercise which tried to get the department to run out these distortions, to suggest that somehow the action taken by this government is to be legitimised in a manner that would suggest other than the facts—that this government has substantially cut moneys to the higher eduction sector, it has substantially undermined the quality of the university sector and it has substantially undermined the capacity of Australians to participate in university, by the removal of 21,000 places from the higher education sector.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result, it has seen a drop in Commonwealth contributions from her department, as a whole of government expenditure, from about 11.1 per cent to about 8.7 per cent. As a priority, this government is spending less and less on education. It is lowering that priority as we see each successive budget measure being introduced. It is a commitment that this minister has fully supported.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order as to relevance. You have already directed Senator Carr to address his remarks to the amendment. The amendment does not refer in any way to the subject that is now being canvassed by Senator Carr. It is an amendment by the Democrats which refers specifically to funding under the previous Labor government. If Senator Carr wants to remark upon the percentage decrease in per capita funding under his previous administration, we welcome him doing that, but he must be relevant to the amendment. You have already ruled on that point of order. I would ask you again to draw Senator Carr's attention to the relevant standing order and ask him to address his remarks to the amendment.
—The amendment does cover a broad area but I will ask you, Senator Carr, to relate your remarks directly to the amendment.

—Thank you very much, Mr Acting Deputy President. What I was indicating is that the minister tried to propagate this myth, tried to propagate this distortion, tried to propagate this untruth that there was a decline in expenditure under the Labor government—a proposition which is quite contrary to the facts and is quite contrary to the fundamental logic that one would expect a minister to have understood. And she produced a chart which suggests concentrating on operating grants rather than on the equivalent full‐time student units, which is the basis of funding across the full gamut of higher education expenditure.

SPEECH.PARA: What this chart highlighted was that, under her government, there has been a decline in the operating grants measured on an EFTSU basis, a decline which is quite significant and quite clear for all to see. It gives the lie to the suggestion she constantly makes that, somehow or other, higher education funding has not been cut. Her own department's figures prove that what she has been putting to this Senate is quite clearly wrong. There has been a substantial reduction in expenditure, a substantial reduction in commitment and a substantial reduction in the priority that this government gives to education.
I would urge the Senate not to support Senator Stott Despoja's amendment. It is quite clearly wrong. I would ask the Senate to support the second reading amendment as proposed by the Labor Party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a few brief remarks.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. Would Senator Stott Despoja mind quantifying for us what `brief' means? We can grant leave for a particular time limit.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I am happy to be restricted to one minute, if that is acceptable.

TALK.START.PARA: —I reject most of the assertions put forward by Senator Carr. However, if he is true to his word, he will be willing to accept the second reading amendment moved by the Democrats with the amendment to the amount of funding. However, I do state that the National Tertiary Education Union and many other advocacy and representative organisations widely use the 13 per cent figure because it is indeed correct. It is even in the coalition's policy document—not that I expect that to sway Senator Carr, but it is a widely accepted figure in relation to the amount of funding decline under the former government in relation to EFTSU places. I do seek leave to amend the amendment so that in the third line, instead of `of Equivalent Full‐Time Student Units', it reads `per Equivalent Full‐time Student Unit'. But I am happy to leave the amendment because the facts are correct, contrary to Senator Carr's assertion in a blatant attempt to be an apologist for the former government, which did introduce user pays education in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1997 does a number of things. As senators have outlined, it has provisions relating to price movements for a number of university grants, the introduction of a 25 per cent discount for partial up‐front HECS payments of $500 or more, streamlining of arrangements for students applying for the remission of their HECS debts, and the introduction of the government's rationalisation and restructuring program.

SPEECH.PARA: In response to comments made by senators, I want to make a number of brief comments on these changes. Senator Stott Despoja leaves me in a constant state of confusion as to what her views really are. On the one hand, Senator Stott Despoja puts out press releases saying, `Oh, this move by the government to give people a 25 per cent discount if they pay their HECS up front and can only pay $500 is unfair. This will benefit the rich.' On the other hand she says, `Well, if other people who pay all their HECS up front can get a 25 per cent discount, then in that context it is fair because, if you haven't got the money to pay all of your HECS up front, why should you miss out on the discount?'

We understand that. That is why we have introduced this change. Not everybody has the money to pay all their HECS up front. We want to help people who have less money and give them the same opportunity to get a discount. Senator Stott Despoja seems to understand that. She says, `In the context of this other discount being available if you pay it all off up front, then we will allow it and support it,' but in the next breath she rushes out and says, `This is advantaging the rich.' However, the whole purpose of this amendment is to ensure that more people can choose to have the option to pay a portion of their HECS up front and still get the discount.

BREAK.PARA: While I am on the subject of HECS payments, I will respond to some of Senator Margetts's comments. Senator Margetts rightly points out that some people, in any event, will not have the money to pay up front. Even with the greater access we expect to get by virtue of this change—and we are grateful for the support of it—some people will still not be able to pay up front. I understand that. But as I am advised, and as I understand it, the reason why the discount is provided up front is that it is roughly the equivalent value of giving a student a long‐term, no real interest rate loan.

Many people in this chamber will understand that the HECS debt is the contribution you make to your education; it is not the full cost. You do not have to pay it up front. One of the most creative aspects of Labor's time in office was the introduction of HECS, with the realisation that people could not necessarily pay up front, and thus allowing paying it back later and not putting a real interest rate on it.

If you want to borrow money to buy a house, a car, a motorbike or whatever, you will not be able to borrow it with no real interest rate unless you borrow it from your family—from your mother or grandmother or someone. A bank will always want a real interest rate. Giving young Australians a loan, in effect, to cover their HECS contribution and saying, `You don't have to pay this back until later,' and not having a real interest rate on it, is a real gift. I understand that the value of a no real interest rate loan that can be paid off over a very long period of time roughly equates to the 25 per cent discount.

That would obviously change depending on what real interest rates were at any particular time—and we only have to remind ourselves how high they were under Labor. I remind Senator Margetts that that is the reason that has been given to me for pitching it at that level. In a sense, both groups get a benefit: the student who wants to pay up front forgoes the opportunity of a long‐term no real interest rate loan and, in exchange for forgoing that, gets 25 per cent off HECS. However, I understand the difficulties you were referring to.

I turn now to operating grant funding per student. The Labor Party cannot have it both ways. We have produced a graph which has already been incorporated in Hansard. That graph shows that when Labor came into office it structured university funding so that operating grants—otherwise generally described as funding primarily available for teaching, although I understand that that can be disputed—were reduced per student.

You could cut a lot of money from universities tomorrow and, if you cut the equivalent in students, your funding per student would be the same. Equally, you could give a lot more money to universities—and there is no doubt that the higher education sector has been the beneficiary of more public funding for a very long time—but if you put in a bigger increase of students than money, you would debase the funding per student.
I know, and we all know—although perhaps the boys in here don't know, but all the girls know because we are good shoppers—

TALK.START.PARA: —What a sexist remark!
—When we are ahead we are allowed to say we are ahead. Have a little bit of a sense of humour, Senator Carr. Just try to relax a bit and enjoy life more.

BREAK.PARA: A good shopper will always be able to confirm that, just because you pay more for something, it does not mean you are getting more. I know that the amount of dollars you spend on something is not always an indicator of quality, but it is one indicator of quality, and it should be taken into account. The facts are that, while more money was put into higher education—and nobody doubts that—the real test of how much is available to teach your son or daughter going to university is what the funding is per student. On that basis, the Labor government failed.

In operating grant terms, funding per student was around the $12,000 mark when Labor came into office in 1983. You took it down to under $11,000—to about $10,800 or $10,900—in 1991. That was the funding per student, so there was less money per student to teach them. Without doubt, you then started to repair the damage, but the changes we have made have largely been misunder stood in the community, and misunderstood as a consequence of the sorts of comments peddled by Senator Carr. It is true that this government has made significant savings in higher education. It is not true that we have cut money drastically from universities. Both of those statements can be true. Anyone who understands higher education funding will appreciate that.

What we have done is broaden the base of funding. We have asked students to pay more, and students are now paying more. But universities around Australia have undoubtedly got more money this year than they had last year. The university sector is estimated to have—we can all argue at the edges—some $33 million more this year than last year. The savings we have made—in a sense, reducing the contribution we put in—have been achieved by getting the students to pay more, not by cutting money from universities.

When universities say, `We will have a one per cent, three per cent, one per cent and one per cent cut over four years,' what they are saying is that it is a cut to the money they thought they were going to have. If someone said to me, `You're getting a cut in your pay,' or if someone went up to a man or a woman on the street or a person on the Balmain ferry or in a Clapham omnibus—which is what I think it used to be described as—and said, `You're getting a cut in your pay,' they would think and I would think that you meant a cut in this year's pay. They do not think you are talking about not getting a pay rise they were hoping to get. In effect, I think that is a fair way to characterise what has happened to universities. They are not getting the pay rise they thought they were going to get. Their plans for their future operating grant funding have been cut, but this year they end up with more money than they had last year.

On that basis, I find it very, very difficult when universities say, `We have to shut this department because of what the government's done.' I want to say, `Hold on. Universities have got more money than last year. Why is this so?' Universities have to be responsible for managing themselves and what they do. You do not want a federal education minister trying to run 37 universities.

I come briefly to Senator Stott Despoja's remarks about the Northern Territory not having a full range of courses available. It is this government's view that there should be more diversity, freedom and choice in the higher education sector. We think the changes we have made have encouraged universities to follow that path. It was a farce from day one to suggest that we had a unified national system, that 37 universities around Australia were all the same. They never were and they never will be. More importantly, this government is prepared to say, `We don't want them to be.' We want them to be different. We want each university to follow the path that it feels is special for its course.

I am pleased to see that in Western Australia, for example, the universities are getting together and, as I understand it, moving very closely towards having a real focus on exploration, mining and petroleum research. What a perfect example of what Western Australia—the mining and exploration state—would want to focus on. If you said to me, `Would you be sorry if every university in Western Australia didn't offer an MBA?' I would say, `No. Why do we want every university offering the same thing?' So they will not all be offering the same thing. They will have to cut down.

If you are a smaller university and you try to offer everything to everyone, my prediction is that you will not be successful at it. You have to pick your niche and be good at that. That is what has to happen. So there is not an expectation that students will simply be able to walk into the university next door and do whatever subject they like and that universities have some obligation to offer every course. That makes them all the same. It makes them all plain. It does not allow any of them to pursue their particular paths of excellence.

I think I have covered most of the points I wanted to respond to. I did want to highlight, as I have said, that operating grant funding per student has been kept stable by us. I think that is vitally important. We have increased research funding—as you know, Senator Carr—over and above the increases that Labor put into it, which were falling to decreases, incidentally, in your out years. We have, nonetheless, in a very difficult budgetary climate, managed to put in more, as we have in a number of areas. In particular, I would like to highlight in this debate that we have managed, in this very difficult budgetary climate, to put more money into indigenous higher education, and I welcome the support on all sides for those commitments.

I come lastly to the rationalisation and restructuring program that is dealt with in this bill. It has been presented by some as some sort of sweetener that the government dreamt up after the changes it made last year. Clearly, it has been presented as that by people who either wanted to deceive or could not be bothered reading last year's budget documents, because we indicated in the very beginning that we would be looking to a rationalisation and restructuring package.

When you encourage more freedom in universities, when you encourage more choice, when you encourage change, when you give more flexibility to universities, there is going to be some change. If you are a larger university or a larger corporation with greater wealth, obviously you can withstand change financially more than others can, and we recognised that from the very beginning. Change can be expensive, and people who need to accommodate it but who do not have as great a resource as others may need assistance. So we indicated in the very beginning—this is not some last-minute budget suggestion for this year; we indicated this last year—that we would be putting forward such a package.

We have committed $26 million over the next four years to fund this program. It is being funded to assist higher education institutions to reposition themselves through the rationalisation of courses and infrastructure. We want that to be happening. We do not want every university to try to be the same as everyone next door.

This program will help universities achieve long‐term efficiencies and enhance the effectiveness of the provision of higher education. That is what this is for. It is an important part of the government's commitment to regional communities. They are the universities that do not have the same resources as the big metropolitan universities.

As I have said before, regional universities are a very vital part of Australia's higher education system, and they highlight the differences that there are. How stupid was it to say that we have a unified national system and to pretend that a small regional university would be the same as a large metropolitan one. It was just crazy from the beginning.

Ten of the 36 publicly funded universities in Australia are located in regional and rural areas. Some of these institutions are, understandably, amongst the smallest universities in Australia, but all of them are as important to us as the biggest. That is very important to repeat: they are amongst the smallest, but they are as important as the biggest. When you realise that the theme for our education policy and direction is freedom, diversity and choice, you will understand that we are very keen to ensure that diversity in the sector is promoted and protected, and that means the small are as valuable to us as the big.

The Northern Territory University, for example, is a vital part of the economic infrastructure of the Northern Territory. Without it, access to benefits of higher education would be severely restricted. University campuses are a vital part of the life of other regional communities like Launceston, Lismore, Dubbo and Ballarat. In these regional areas, university campuses improve access to higher education. A campus in a regional town can, in fact, increase interest. Simply having it there can increase interest in university study.

The funds from this bill will allow projects which can strengthen the viability of small regional institutions. You only need to speak to Shane Stone or Minister Adamson in the Northern Territory to see how strongly they would urge the federal government to implement this scheme because they realise the vital part that the Northern Territory University plays in the Northern Territory. I would not say that you are sick of the representations from them, but sometimes a point is made and it does not need to be repeated. That is fair enough. The people from the Northern Territory always argue their case strongly.

The investment that the Commonwealth makes to these communities does, in fact, flow on to the economy of the regions. As has been recognised by a recent report to the West committee, all studies suggest that the activities of regional universities produce significant increases in regional economic activity. This government recognises how important universities are to regional communities. Through this program, we are standing by these communities to ensure that they continue to have access to higher education. We are safeguarding access to higher education for regional Australia. Universities which are less able to finance restructuring from their own resources will be given priority under this program. This includes the small to medium sized higher education institutions that are located outside state capital cities.

There is nothing more I want to say other than to simply repeat: universities have more money this year than they had last year. The cuts were to their plans for future funding, not to the money they have this year. They will end up with a bit less in total in a couple of years time, but the important point is that operating grant funding per student has effectively been maintained at 1995-96 levels, which is good news for higher education. That is, of course, recognised by students.

That is why, even though we are providing more government funded undergraduate places this year, we have trimmed the number of postgraduate courses we are prepared to pay for, but we are providing more government funded undergraduate places this year than last year, and we will provide more again next year. Despite that increase in the number of government funded undergraduate places—that is, HECS places—universities have overenrolled. That tells you that students around Australia, young Australians, understand that higher education is a very good investment under this government.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that Senator Stott Despoja's amendment be agreed to.
—The question now is that Senator Carr's amendment, as amended, be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Carr's ), as amended, be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.
