That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1997, which we are considering, seeks to ensure the continuing excisability of all beverages which contain distilled alcohol, including spirits, regardless of their alcohol content. The government has introduced this bill in response to what is known as the CUB, Carlton and United Breweries, sub ZERO case. CUB challenged the Customs Service declaration that sub ZERO was a spirituous beverage for the purposes of sub‐item 2(H) of the tariff act schedule. CUB was successful at both the AAT and the subsequent Federal Court appeal which held that sub ZERO was not a spirituous beverage and therefore was not subject to excise.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill seeks to reverse the Federal Court decision and make such beverages subject to excise, effective from 3 February 1996, by removing the term `spirituous beverages' from the schedule and ensuring that the liability to pay excise is imposed upon all beverages which contain distilled alcohol, except fortified wine.

The problem with this bill is that in the government's usual ad hoc sloppiness when it comes to tax related legislation they have created an anomaly within what are known as the P5 food standard categories under which these designer drinks fall. This anomaly is created due to the fact that, while designer drinks that are made from a distilled alcohol base—they are also known as RTDs—will be subject to excise, those made from a fermented alcohol base will not.

As usual, this government proposes to do nothing and in the process encourage product substitution and a revenue loss to the govern ment. The economics legislation committee has conducted some hearings into this, and I would like to acknowledge the work of my Senate colleague Senator Hogg, who was involved in those hearings. I believe he will be speaking on this issue in the second reading contributions.
What is noteworthy about the report is that the chair of the Senate committee—a government senator, Senator Ferguson—said in his recommendation:

In making the recommendation that the bill proceed, the committee agrees that any loophole in the principal legislation that allowed a class of alcohol beverage to escape the revenue net should be closed.

Here we have a situation where the government's own chair of the committee which inquired into this bill has pointed out the ludicrous situation that exists in the bill. So what does the government do? It ignores him. It is obvious to us that Senator Ferguson is eminently more sensible than the minister and can see the glaring anomaly that the government has created but refuses to fix. I note that Senator Ferguson is here in the chamber and I give him due credit; he was particularly wise on this occasion in respect to the legislation we are considering.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are ruining my future.

—The only way I can probably help you, Senator Ferguson, is to ensure the resignation of a few ministers or government parliamentary secretaries. And you should be in the promotion stakes. On the performance on this legislation you should be up there, Senator Ferguson.

SPEECH.PARA: Why would the government want to pursue a bill that will actively encourage product substitution and therefore the legal avoidance of excise tax and as a consequence a multimillion dollar loss to government revenue? This highlights the farce that this bill represents.

The government is rapidly demonstrating what a joke it is when it comes to farcical legislation. We have had the government maintain a charade for many months that the new $1.4 billion supertax was in fact a surcharge and not a tax. In the recent context of the goods and services tax debate, we have had the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) refer to his concept of a GST as a BBIT. I notice he was very careful on this occasion to avoid using the description: a goods and services surcharge.

We have error upon error, mistake upon mistake, when we get down to the application of this new tax—this is in respect to the new superannuation tax. Due to its failure and incompetence, the government cannot even collect tax from the defined benefits schemes, yet they now parade around as the party of efficient and fair tax reform.

If the government wants to demonstrate its tax reform credentials, here is a golden opportunity on a very basic piece of legislation to show those credentials, but I doubt that the government will take the opportunity, as so far it has not demonstrated any propensity to do so in any way, shape or form.

I do not know whether Senator Campbell, who is handling this legislation for the government, has read the economics legislation committee report. He was not in here when I referred to it earlier, but he should examine the analysis of my colleague Senator Hogg—who, as I said, did an excellent job at that committee—and also particularly the recommendation of the committee chair, Senator Ferguson, who did draw attention to the problems with this particular legislation.

I move on to the social consequences of this bill. At a time when there is increasing community concern regarding both alcohol and drug abuse, particularly by young people, this bill in its present form is socially irresponsible when it comes to encouraging moderate alcohol consumption by young people.

It is worth noting that the University of New South Wales in its submission outlined three principal concerns relating to the bill. Firstly, the bill would see high alcohol content RTDs produced from a non‐excisable alcohol base from which no excise will be paid, while low strength RTDs produced from a distilled alcohol base will be subject to excise duty at the same rate that applies to full strength spirits.

BREAK.PARA: Secondly, from a health perspective, all RTDs should be taxed in accordance with the alcohol content so as to encourage moderate and responsible alcohol consumption. Thirdly, the bill does not establish a taxation system whereby a progressive excise is levied upon all P5 beverages in accordance with their increasing alcohol content.

These three concerns basically encapsulate all that is wrong with this legislation. From a social perspective, it is manifestly irresponsible of the government to be promoting the consumption of high alcohol excise‐free RTDs compared to low alcohol excisable RTDs.

This bill ensures that young people, who are very price sensitive, will choose the cheaper, high alcohol product as against the more expensive low alcohol product. This is an absolutely ludicrous position and a recipe for disaster, as the community struggles to confront the all too common problem of binge drinking and general alcohol and drug abuse.

I would have thought that this government would be doing everything in its power to ensure that young Australians are encouraged to drink alcohol in moderation rather than in excess. Yet when presented with the opportunity to do something socially responsible as well as be consistent in terms of tax treatment of light alcoholic beverages, the government presents the Senate with a bill full of anomalies.

The anomalies are, firstly, that it is detrimental to government revenue; secondly, it actively encourages product substitution to avoid the excise tax; thirdly, it makes higher alcohol products much cheaper than low alcohol products. By inference, this has been criticised by the government's own chair of the committee which inquired into the bill, Senator Ferguson.

The bill has all these faults and the government presents it to the Senate expecting it to be passed in the interests of good public policy. If this is the best the government can do under the pretext of correcting a taxation anomaly in the excise tax regime, I cannot wait to see the outcome of the Prime Minister's secret tax reform task force.

If the government cannot even get it right on the basic taxation of RTD products in the P5 food standard, what hope have we got? What faith should the Australian people have in the government overhauling the Australian taxation system and Commonwealth‐state financial relations? The mind boggles as to what the Prime Minister's secret tax reform task force is going to come up with based on the legislation we have before the Senate.

There are a number of amendments before the Senate regarding this bill. The Greens, I believe, have circulated an amendment which will close the anomaly that the government refuses to acknowledge even exists. From my understanding, the amendment will introduce a two‐tier excise taxation regime so that any product classified under the P5 food standard that has an alcohol content of five per cent by volume or less, regardless of the alcohol source—be it from fermentation or a distillation process—will attract the same excise at the rate of $15.89 per litre of alcohol. Products which have an alcohol content of greater than five per cent by volume will attract excise at the rate of $31.59, when mixed with brandy, and $36.99, when mixed without brandy, per litre of alcohol.

Labor considers this proposal to be eminently sensible. Frankly, I am surprised that the government has left the Greens, hopefully the Democrats, Senator Harradine and Labor to clean up their mess. This measure will, in effect, see the introduction of a progressive taxation regime based upon alcohol content as opposed to being based upon the production source of the alcohol. Consequently, less excise will be paid on lower alcohol products than on higher alcohol products. Labor believes this is an entirely appropriate approach to the problem at hand. It also demonstrates a degree of social responsibility which the government was either unwilling or unable to address.

A further amendment before the Senate is a Democrat proposal, a simple amendment which will remove the proposed retrospectivity from the bill and make the commencement date 3 February 1997 instead of 3 February 1996. The opposition is sympathetic to the intention of the Democrats and to why they have moved this amendment. However, the opposition will not be supporting it for the following reasons.

Labor does not support retrospective legislation lightly and the government should not take this as a sign that the opposition will support retrospective legislation as a matter of course—far from it. Retrospective legislation should always be used rarely and should be the exception rather than the norm. The reason why Labor has chosen to support the retrospective approach contained in this bill is that simply not to do so would mean a windfall gain to RTD manufacturers of $12.6 million. So they would be able to claim back the excise which they have already paid based upon the sub ZERO ruling. It is not that different in principle, frankly, from the other problems we are faced with as a result of the recent High Court decision with respect to state licensing fees, which I understand we will be considering, perhaps this week.

The simple fact is that this money does not belong to the manufacturers; it belongs to the consumers. As the manufacturers have no practical means by which to return this money to their rightful owners, we unfortunately are left in the position of supporting the best of two bad options which will see the government retain the excise it has already collected. This being said, we would hope that what is now in effect a windfall gain from the government of $12.6 million will be put to good use, to help restore in some manner some of the programs that the government has savagely cut in the last two budgets.

I suggest the government look in this context at employment generation programs, which this government seems to have taken delight in cutting, thus helping ensure that unemployment—which remains an intractable problem to which this government has no answers or solutions—is at least addressed with respect to this windfall gain of $12.6 million.

One other possible use for the $12.6 million would be for the government to devote it to drug abuse programs. We think it entirely appropriate, given the current debate on drug abuse—alcohol is a drug, albeit a legal drug that should be used responsibly—that drug abuse is another very important and socially desirable alternative area to which the $12.6 million windfall gain which the government will obtain from the opposition's support of retrospective legislation could be devoted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —The first thing I would like to say is just how disappointed I am with the way in which the government has dealt with the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1997 . As soon as I had the opportunity to examine the bill, I noted a number of problems. I immediately referred it to the Senate Economics Legislation Committee. Looking back, I am very glad I did so. Once again, the Senate Economics Committee secretariat did a first‐rate job. The quality and objectivity they bring to their task is always extremely helpful to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Submissions to the committee and witnesses at the public hearing on 30 May 1997 identified numerous problems, problems which could have been fixed prior to tabling of the bill in the Senate and, even more to the point, prior to this very debate. Unfortunately, the political will to do so was missing and remains missing. I fear the shadow of macho Treasury intransigence when we need the substance of practical pragmatic commonsense. Fortunately, the minor parties and the opposition and, in this particular bill, my colleague Senator Margetts, have not lacked the political will to attempt to repair the government's legislation.

I will quickly run through what I think are the key problems with this bill. The first is the issue of retrospectivity. The bill makes the changes effective from 3 February 1996, yet the changes were announced in the Commonwealth Gazette on 3 February 1997, which was the day they were made effective by the excise tariff proposal No. 1 of 1997.

Why is the government seeking to backdate the changes? Such backdating offends every principle concerning unjust and unjustified retrospectivity that the Senate holds dear. The answer is simple: the government wants to retain revenue that it has already collected. The problem stems from the fact that the collection of this revenue was not in accord ance with the law of the day as interpreted by the Federal Court.

In 1994 when Carlton and United Breweries commenced manufacture of sub ZERO, they argued that it was not excisable. The Australian Customs Service disagreed and imposed an excise. Not surprisingly, CUB appealed the ruling with the AAT—the Administrative Appeals Tribunal—and were vindicated. As a consequence, the government returned the excise moneys collected from CUB for this purpose.

Customs, however, have ignored the implications of the AAT decision and continued to impose excise duty on all other similar low alcohol beverages. In the meantime, they appealed this decision with the Federal Court and lost. The government is now refusing to accept the implication of decisions by both the AAT and the Federal Court; namely, that the excise was not dutiable on such beverages under the law at the time. It is insisting that its interpretation of the law was correct and not the interpretation of the AAT or the Federal Court.

The government is insisting that, by backdating the law to 3 February 1996, it is simply clarifying what it believes was the status quo on that date. It seems to me that the Federal Court has already clarified what was the status quo on that date. In fact, it cannot really be argued that excise was payable until 3 February 1997, when the government changed the law with its announcement. It is a longstanding principle of the Senate that it will generally accept changes the government makes to the collection of revenue from the date of the announcement.

Of course, it is no surprise that the government does not want to hand back the $12.6 million it has collected retrospectively in this manner. The government has sought to add moral persuasion by saying that, if it handed this money back, it would represent a windfall gain to the industry because it is unlikely to be passed on to the consumers of the product. It is true that it would be unlikely to be passed on to consumers. Such taxation returns, Senator Sherry, never are. Governments are unable—and the industries which receive the excise returns are unable—to pass them back to each individual consumer. It is a nonsense to think they could.

However, the money should go to the person who was legally entitled to it at the time, which is the company. That person is the manufacturer who has paid the money under protest and who has been vindicated by both the AAT and the Federal Court. If the money is retained by the government, it will constitute a windfall gain to the government since the government is not legally entitled to those moneys, unless, of course, we pass this bill unamended and change the law retrospectively.

Although the industry has not made much fuss about this issue, I do not think it should be ignored. Organisations such as the Institute of Chartered Accountants and the Law Council of Australia have pointed out the dangers. They argue that it sets a very unpalatable precedent by effectively leaving the interpretation of law to public sector officials.

Those officials are not, with great respect and regard for their other abilities, renowned for their fight for civil rights, for personal liberties or for justice; the parliament and the courts are. There is no point challenging a ruling or interpretation by Customs officials in a court of law knowing that, if you win, the executive government and their like-minded bureaucrats will override it by means of retrospective legislation.

Retrospectivity is warranted if rorting, fraud or illegality were involved. In this case there is no suggestion of this at all, nor is it the case that large revenue losses are involved. Handing back the $12.6 million which the government is not entitled to will not result in serious repercussions for Australia's exchequer or its economy. For this reason, I will be moving an amendment to make changes effective from 3 February 1997, which is the day they were brought into effect by the excise tariff proposal and the day they were notified in the Commonwealth Gazette. I note, however, that I am likely to lose that.

The second issue I would like to raise is that of substitutability and associated concerns. As the bill stands, it fails to rectify a tax anomaly which is perpetuating the growth in designer drinks which do not incur any excise duty. The taxation of beverages in the P5 category is anomalous. I feel the government should use the opportunity afforded by this bill to rectify the situation.

The government, while acknowledging the anomaly, is refusing to rectify the situation. It simply wants to ensure that the proportion of a beverage comprised of distilled alcohol be made subject to excise. It wants to do so even though it will provide a competitive advantage in terms of excise duties for ready‐to‐drink products containing fermented alcohol as distinct from distilled alcohol.

Evidence has been produced showing that many drinks of this type already on the market are imported from New Zealand, giving them a further competitive advantage which detrimentally impacts on our balance of trade. Moreover, domestic manufacturers, such as Bundaberg Distillers, who are competing in the same market will be encouraged to substitute foreign fermented alcohol for distilled alcohol from Australia in so-called ready‐to‐drink or premixed beverages—for example, rum and cola—in order to minimise tax.

Bundaberg Distillers have also indicated that, as they do not have brewing facilities at their plant, they would be encouraged to import fermented products from overseas. In time this will have a negative impact on Australian investment. In the long run this will result in significant revenue losses. It has been estimated that the Commonwealth could face a revenue loss of about $30 million over the next three years if substitution occurs. I have been unable to understand why the government is happy to see this happen.

Unfortunately, this is a government which has yet again lost sight of the long run and focused on the short run. Decisions to abolish bounty assistance for the computer, book, machine tools and robotics industries, decisions to reduce the 150 per cent tax concession for research and development, and decisions to wind back the export market development grants programs are all examples of short run decisions. The Democrats told the government it was wrong and industry tells the government it is wrong, but that macho intransigence prevails.

BREAK.PARA: Those were the decisions to ensure that, in the short run, budget savings would be improved. The fact that in the long run they will have the opposite effect has been of little concern to this government. So it is not surprising to see the same short-sighted approach being adopted yet again.

Thirdly, I would like to stress that, if the bill goes through unamended, it will also fail to impose an incentive to produce lower alcohol beverages. This issue is of significant concern to health and community organisations, a number of whom made submissions to the Senate committee inquiry on this point. Health and community organisations share the above concern because they want drinks taxed progressively in accordance with their level of alcohol and not in accordance with the method of production. They see this as being important from a health perspective because it encourages moderate and responsible alcohol consumption.

The University of New South Wales has suggested the bill be amended so that a progressive excise is levied upon all P5 beverages in accordance with their alcohol content. This is a position shared by the Alcohol and Other Drugs Council of Australia. In the majority report of the Senate committee inquiry into this bill, government senators acknowledged the relevance of the concerns raised by industry and community organisations and the potential adverse social and economic consequences. Yet they did not recommend that the bill be amended to rectify identified problems. Instead, the majority of the committee recommended the bill be passed unamended and that a further inquiry take place. In other words, they toed the Treasury line.

The Democrats see no reason for these matters to be the subject of an identical repeat inquiry. This would simply be a waste of time and resources. Moreover, it would be unfair to witnesses and those who made submissions and it would also be unfair to subject industry to unnecessary delays and uncertainties in resolving acknowledged concerns. I also regret that valuable Senate time will be wasted needlessly today. I have been forced to speak out on this bill because of the ap proach the government has taken. Had they tabled a bill which was properly thought through this would not be necessary.

While the Democrats support the specific measures of the bill, with the exclusion of retrospectivity, we want the anomalies in the excise regime rectified. The amendment of the WA Greens attempts to do this with regard to category P5. I have encouraged the government to do the necessary groundwork and extended an offer for dialogue. Despite the much better attitude of the new Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs (Senator Ellison) they have collectively decided to bury their heads in the sand, in my opinion.

Fortunately, my colleague Senator Margetts has done the government's work for them. She has devised an amendment which seems to resolve a number of the problems I have raised. It also has the approval of industry and community and health organisations. For this reason, I will be supporting the amendment to be moved by the WA Greens. I will also move an amendment to remove the retrospective provisions of the bill, which I hope will win the support of the Senate after senators have heard my arguments.

It has been my view that this bill concerns practical matters and should have been resolved by the government. It is a sad reflection on this government when minor parties in the Senate, operating with minimal resources, are forced to do the corrective legislation which should have been quite possible for the government and for a major government department to do, especially after the very helpful work done by the Senate Economics Legislation Committee and its witnesses.
In conclusion, I will read to the Senate a letter I wrote to the new Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs on 25 July 1997. It reads:
Dear Senator Ellison,
This bill is yet to be debated, but the amendments have been circulated.

My impression of the Senators views at the Senate Economics Committee hearings into this bill were that they felt that the issues were of a practical not a political nature. Unfortunately the Majority Report did not reflect that feeling.

May I recommend that you consider reviewing the submissions, the Hansard Hearings record, the Majority and Minority committee reports, and the circulated amendments. When I discussed the matter in June with officers from Customs, they felt that with the expectation of the Bill being debated last Senate sitting, that it was too late to change course.
The Winter break provides a breathing space for the Government to reconsider its position. I would certainly be willing to attempt to facilitate an early and amenable resolution of this Bill.
The minister and his department came to me this week and I regret to say that we have no progress in terms of changing the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The major issue here is the fact that so‐called designer drinks currently pay no excise. This is because they fall outside the definitions designed to put different excise rates on different sorts of drinks. These designer drinks are a new phenomenon, developed in part precisely because they fell through the cracks of the excise regime. They are also ways for brewers, primarily of beer, to utilise surplus capacity and alcohol.

SPEECH.PARA: As drinks, they have been something of a worry to the health community and those social agencies with a focus on young people. This is because, unlike traditional drinks, these alcoholic drinks emulate common non‐alcoholic soft drinks—drinks consumed by children. They are effectively alcoholic lemonade, alcoholic cola and alcoholic soda water. Not only are they alcoholic, many are actually very strong—substantially stronger than beer.

The marketing of these drinks, such as sub ZERO and XLR8, has definitely been targeted at youth, and female drinkers have been especially well attended to. In short, there is a major marketing effort to develop a new class of drinkers in the 18 to 25 age group. Given the problems of alcoholism and the particular success companies have had in promoting drinking and smoking to women, it is socially problematic. It is more so because of the association with kids drinks and the tendency to think of them in similar ways and knock down quite a few of these potent drinks, which are usually bought by the bottle rather than by the glass as a standard drink. I do not wish to penalise these drinks especially heavily but it is clearly time to stop favouring them by allowing them to escape tax treatment. My amendment would assure that they are taxed.

The primary issue in relation to the tax treatment of these drinks under the excise act is that they fit no clearly defined category. They are an industrial product rather than a product of a traditional pre‐industrial process such as brewing, wine making or the making of spirits and liquors. They fundamentally just get ethanol, either distilled or fermented in some combination, and whack it into a carbonated soft drink or fruit juice. It need not be sourced from grains, hops, grapes, honey or anything specific. Other drinks are defined by the source of the alcohol and the process used to make the drink. The ethyl alcohol in designer drinks could conceivably be produced chemically or from sawdust using genetically modified bacteria—doesn't that sound yummy. The manufacturers will use whatever is cheapest and if one source is taxed and another not, that may determine the source.

It is clear that it has been the intention of government to tax alcoholic drinks produced for sale on the open market. Government has even gone after home brewed drinks when home brews started to be sold in shops as a number of recipes, with the materials and facilities for brewing it. This was taken as a commercial operation and a tax applied. It was never the intention of government to create a special category of tax exempt designer drinks. I think that has been clear from the outset.

The government decided, perhaps unwisely, that it did not need to create a new class of drinks to apply excise to the new designer drinks. It announced that they fit in the current classification as a spirit. Clearly they have little relation to spirits as the community instinctively define them: very strong alcoholic drinks distilled from natural plant products. Admittedly, the process of spirit manufacture now bears more resemblance to chemical processes than to traditionally produced goods.

BREAK.PARA: For example, Bacardi is known in the Caribbean as `rum industrial'. It is something made chemically from refined sugar. Real rum is `rum agricol'. It is made from mashed sugar cane and, like good wine, partakes of the minerals and trace elements found in the soil, and the growing conditions. Apparently connoisseurs can tell by taste what side of what island a rum comes from. Industrial rum or whisky, or whatever, does not have such qualities. It is a strong alcoholic drink, typically around 30 per cent alcohol, made by distillation of fermented plant mash. I am not a rum drinker, but I have heard these distinctions made loudly.

I think it is indicative of what has happened and is happening in the industry. I understand Australian rums are usually more like rum agricol than like industrial rum. These new drinks are nothing like traditional spirits. They are made from alcohol produced in one way or another, and the alcohol is then taken and whacked into lemonade, fruit juice, soda water or cola. They are an entirely fabricated product, which is where the government came unstuck.

Predictably, the designer drink manufacturers appealed against the government, claiming—in my opinion, correctly—that these drinks were not spirits. The judges found for the designer drinks and against the government. The government then tried to redefine `spirits' to catch the designer drinks. It moved away from the definition which was instinctive and culturally understood—the common‐use interpretation of the term. It tried to say that a spirit is anything containing distilled alcohol. The designer drink manufacturers immediately converted to using fermented alcohol. It does not matter where their alcohol comes from; it is not a natural outcome of a natural process relating to what gives the drink flavour. It is usually simply a blank bland alcohol which is added to a drink. The source only matters in commercial economic terms. For the drink, it makes no substantial difference.

On the question of retrospectivity—this relates to Senator Murray's amendments—it is my view that this is a case where it was the clear intention of government to tax these drinks. They did in fact impose such a tax. This was challenged, and a legal loophole was found after the government was taken to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. I do not think closing this loophole from the point it was legally created fits the same category as retrospectively applying a new measure. I do not accept the arguments about retrospectivity in this particular case. I think the issue is about how to successfully tax these drinks. Nevertheless, in my first amendment, I set the commencement for the new P5 based classification at the time of royal assent. It is clearly prospective, not retrospective. I have also noted Senator Sherry's comments in relation to the issue of retrospectivity.

There is no reason such drinks should not be taxed. It is entirely consistent and equitable. These are commercial and highly competitive products. They should not continue to get a major tax break unavailable to their competitors. Within the Excise Act there are discriminations parliament has seen fit to apply. Beer, cider and wine are taxed at a lower rate than spirits. In part, this reflects the social desirability of discouraging the drinking of strong liquor. Wine is treated differently from beer. This reflects the differences in production, employment and return to local economies. It reflects a difference in industry profiles and economic outcomes. There is some special treatment for traditional drinks with very small markets.

There is no special case to make designer drinks tax exempt. They are industrial commercial products. They are alcoholic drinks. They are products intended for a mass market. Their industry profile is similar to that of beer. They are a particular social problem to the extent that they encourage binge drinking of high strength drinks by young people. There is no reason to exempt them and significant reason to include them at a fairly high relative rate of tax.

I accept that the government intended to tax these drinks, thought it had a mechanism to tax them and announced that they owed tax. Tax was paid. Subsequently, a judicial case decided that there was a loophole and that, under the letter of the law, these drinks were not taxable under the existing legislation. This is not a conclusion that they should not be taxed or that the government was wrong in its intention. It was wrong in the letter of the law that it used.

Unfortunately, the government is now trying to rewrite the law and make an ineffective classification effective. It has already failed in this. When the government announced its new measure to catch these drinks in the tax net, the manufacturers simply changed the process. The government measure will generate no revenue from designer drinks.

I am tired of this designer drinks issue. A couple of years ago there was a clear consensus on how to tax them: through the use of the P5 food standard on drinks. It is clear and unambiguous and catches any commercial alcoholic drink not in another category. It does not matter what industrial process they use; they will be taxed. It will create stability and a measure of predicability in the market. I think it will be a welcome relief not to have to continually rejig production to take advantage of vagaries in the tax system.

The amendments I will put contain a simple two‐tier approach to taxing designer drinks. It is a model that got the basic approval of the committee looking at this bill. It would certainly catch these drinks, and it could be administered. It does not affect any of the current classifications. I am not suggesting changing all classifications; I am suggesting creating a new classification.

As well as creating a classification that could be applied to designer drinks regardless of the process, my model has the advantage of being a two tier system based on alcohol content. The lower tier—for drinks with less than five per cent alcohol—is set at the beer rate. This is because such drinks are equivalent to beer, both in manufacture and in their alcohol content. They are probably direct competitors with beer.

Primarily as a health measure, however, drinks with an alcohol content above five per cent would be taxed at the spirit rate. They are not classed as spirits, but they are taxed at the same rate per unit of alcohol content. Hopefully, it will be a major disincentive to high strength alcoholic pop, and an incentive to keep alcohol content below five per cent. Most mass market beers and ciders are less than five per cent alcohol. This market measure was supported by various health agencies.

This is not an issue the Greens will be spending a great deal of time on because we cannot. It is not a political issue from our perspective; it is an issue of simple commonsense and one that will protect government revenue. It is also an issue that will benefit the community both through providing revenue and reducing problematic alcohol consumption.

There is really not much more to say on this measure. Most players in the drink industry support this as a means of finally determining what will happen. The alternative is to refuse this amendment and to try yet another measure next year. It is likely to be another different measure, whether or not it is as effective, because it would look too stupid to reject this and then bring it back next year.

I have no agenda other than to resolve this and a belief that the P5 standard is the method for clear resolution. While I think the two‐tiered rate system is good on social and health grounds, I am not tied to any particular rate of tax nor to any particular commencement date. I think the level and timing of tax applied is far less of an issue than that some category be developed to allow this class of drinks to have excise applied. I would like to see this issue resolved. I do hope that our amendments will be passed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I speak on the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1997, I indicate that I have declared on the register of interests that my sister‐in‐law is a director of Southcorp which, I believe, is involved in P5 limited productions. Let me assure you that in no way has clouded my view here today as I am renowned as a red wine and beer drinker and do not touch P5s.
—And a teetotaller. Does that count?

—And a teetotaller as well. Having got all those interests out of the way, I think it is worth while to take a few minutes in this debate to register my very great concerns about the bill that the government has brought forward for debate today, particularly the effects that will be felt by sugar producers in Queensland. I will come more particularly to that later on.

SPEECH.PARA: If the government is serious about being fair and fair‐minded in this issue, then the first thing it should do is concede that the proposition that is being put forward by the Greens is, in effect, a fair solution to the problem that we are presented with today. The fact is that equity in its greatest sense would dictate that the amendments of the Greens should be passed and passed overwhelmingly by this chamber so that we can get rid of this curse once and for all. There is no doubt that it is an anomaly that is now starting to hang around like a bad smell and should be disposed of as quickly as possible.

The essence of the argument addressed by this piece of legislation is: is alcohol alcohol? The fact is that alcohol is alcohol, and I will go into that later on in this debate. What is of concern in this piece of legislation is not the fact that it is alcohol but the source of the alcohol, and the source of the alcohol being either fermented alcohol or distilled alcohol. Of course, the particular concern for the producers in Queensland is that they are primarily involved in the production of distilled alcohol. They are not primarily involved in the use of fermented alcohol.

As I understand the evolution of this total argument, the brewers of beer and the like from fermented products found that they had an excess of alcohol to their needs and wanted to use that excess of alcohol in some other means of production. Thereby came about the P5 ready‐to‐drink products that we now see on the market. At the same time we had the distillers producing ready‐to‐drink products by way of a different process and this attracted an excise. In effect, we had two drinks which were ostensibly the same in terms of alcohol and alcohol content but they were being taxed under a different tax regime.

Having said that, substantial evidence was given at a hearing of the Economics Legislation Committee which I believe unequivocally supported the fact that there should be a fair regime in the way in which P5s are taxed. Whilst the report of that committee does not show unanimity—there was a minority report by the Labor Party and the Australian Democrats—nonetheless the government should take cognisance of the weight of the evidence that came before that committee.

We should look, firstly, at the cost to the industry, particularly in Queensland. It was pointed out that Bundaberg, which is the focus of this industry in Queensland, will suffer badly. Bundaberg is already a region which suffers badly from unemployment. By proceeding with this bill, the government will do nothing more than exacerbate the unemployment situation.

This was clearly spelt out by Dr Muller, who was appearing for the Bundaberg Distilling Company—he is also the chairman of the District Tourism and Development Board. At page 75 of the Hansard, he is reported as saying:

We would point out that Bundaberg currently has one of the highest unemployment rates in Australia. The Wide Bay region is recognised as being one of the most economically deprived areas in Australia, currently with an unemployment rate of 17.2 per cent, compared with the national average of 9.8 per cent. We believe that any impact whatsoever on local economic activity can only be of serious detriment to our region.

Dr Muller was very much of the view that the action being taken by this government would do nothing more than add another blow to the unemployment problems that currently exist in the Bundaberg region. Further on in the hearing that day we heard other instances of the economic effects spelt out. Mr Woodward, the Director and General Manager, Business Development, Bundaberg Sugar Ltd, and the Director of Bundaberg Distilling Company, said—and this shows the impact of what the government is doing:

Just as an indication, sales of molasses to Bundaberg Distilling amount to $1½ million to $2 million in the current year. We know that there is going to be a knock‐on effect if the bill, as proposed, goes through.

The reality is that if this bill goes through then the production of distilled alcohol into ready‐to‐drink products will cease or will more likely go offshore. So we have a direct economic impact on the Bundaberg area. But it is interesting that Mr Woodward goes on to say at page 78 of the Hansard of the legislation committee meeting of 30 May:

Southern Sugar Manufactures is an association of about five or six different sugar milling companies, which includes the Sugar Milling Cooperative in northern New South Wales, ICIS Sugar Milling Cooperative, Maryborough Sugar, Rocky Point, which is privately owned, and ourselves. That association can see that the knock‐on effect of this can potentially impact on the molasses sales in the region. They have thought so strongly of the issue that they have written to the committee as well.

It is not just something isolated to one particular company. There are broader interests in the outcome of this particular piece of legislation. Then Mr Woodward went on to sum up—and I think this is the real crux of the whole argument. He said:

In summing up, both for Bundaberg Rum and Bundaberg Sugar, in particular, but also the other sugar millers and Bundaberg tourism, our message is pretty clear: fix up the tax anomaly and don't put into law an incentive for the production of low tax hybrid products.

I think that really spells out what the government have missed on this occasion: they have an anomaly, they have to fix the problem up and what they are doing is not addressing the problem. The issue is that you have two different types of ready‐to‐drink products that are going to end up being taxed at a different tax regime. All this will do is severely impact on an area that is already the subject of quite difficult problems in terms of unemployment in that region of Queensland.

It seems to me there is no debate about the fact that alcohol is alcohol in this case. We also had medical evidence before the committee on 30 May which clearly showed that it was a sound proposal to have the sort of regime that is being advocated by the Greens as a taxing regime for these P5 drinks. There is no doubt about that at all. They supported the concept that we had in the P5 drinks a measurable quantity of alcohol and people were therefore getting, if one could say in crudest terms, a prescribed dose of alcohol. There was no mixing and matching; there was a prescribed dose.

If we can accept the Greens amendment, that will give us two regimes of taxation and those two regimes of taxation will see that we end up with a fair system by which the two different forms of drinks are taxed. More importantly, I think we must accept that this is a responsible approach being taken in terms of the health of young people and others in our community if we can get a fair and equitable system of taxation for the P5 drinks.

The last thing I want to make some reference to is the fact that if the government were to accept the Greens amendment they would not in any way be breaking their promise, which they generally hold so firmly to. They do not like breaking promises. They have become experts at it in the past, but this is one case where they would not break a promise to introduce a new tax on the beer and wine industries. Neither of these industries will be affected by what we see being put forward by the Greens today.

The fact of the matter is—and I will quote from what I said at page 84 of the 30 May hearing—that I believe the proposal being put forward by the Greens `quarantines the government's promise not to impose any new taxes on the wine industry, the non‐grape fruit wines and wine products. It purely quarantines it to the P5 bracket.' The fact that some people have enjoyed an advantage previously does not mean that that advantage should not now be withdrawn. Again, quoting from my comments of that day:

That seems to me to be an eminently reasonable approach to take. Of course, the anomaly that is created here is the difference between those that are fermented and those that are distilled. Of course, what we are trying to do is bring a level playing field into place otherwise, as the evidence that was put before us today shows, those that may well be distilled currently will downgrade the amount of distilled product within the product itself and go to a fermented base so that the government will lose whatever income they have counted on there.

The fact is that the evidence which came out at that hearing showed beyond doubt that people will seek to get around whatever regime the government put in place. I do not think the approach of the government is either logical or responsible. I do not think it addresses the anomaly, and I do not think it fixes up the problems that we are confronted with.

BREAK.PARA: I want to refer to this last quotation because I think it really sums up what happened at the hearing. After I had made those previous comments, the chair said:

Can I just reinforce what Senator Hogg highlights. Already we are seeing ready‐to‐drink designer drinks being imported from overseas which fit into this category of non‐excisable and into the lower range. I think there were two or three drinks from New Zealand that they put in front of us that are already being imported, and they are made from the fermentation process. I do not think there are any of us who would like to think that there was encouragement given to allow an imported product to come in and compete directly with ours because of a differentiation in the way it was treated on a tax basis.

Interestingly, the parliamentary secretary who was present said, `I do not disagree with what you are saying.' So the fact is that the government are really at odds with themselves. Really, they should be embracing the approach that we have adopted—the approach to categorising the P5s as outlined in Senator Margetts's amendment. I believe that is a fair and equitable approach. It will remove some strain in the Bundaberg region. The testimony before the committee clearly outlined that people felt there would be further unemployment in that area if the government were successful in having their bill passed by this chamber. I implore the Senate to knock back the legislation as proposed by the government and to support the Greens' proposal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1997 partly because my name has been mentioned, in my capacity as Chair of the Senate Economics Legislation Committee. I feel there are some matters that have been raised to which I should respond. Let me say at the outset that I do not resile from anything I said during that one‐day committee hearing. I do not think there is any senator in this chamber who would not want to do everything possible to make sure that we prevent the potential abuse of alcohol, particularly by younger people, who are those who tend to be the consumers of ready‐to‐drink and designer drinks. I do not think we would want to do anything that would make it more likely that they would have a cheaper form of alcohol available to them, particularly where drinks with a higher level of alcohol are available at a cheaper price than those with a lower level of alcohol.

SPEECH.PARA: I think we need to remember that this bill was designed specifically to close an existing loophole which had been brought about because of a High Court decision. The legislation committee inquiry heard a lot of evidence. I do not think anybody could be anything but sympathetic towards such evidence, because of the nature of the current taxation treatment.

What was said in the recommendations of the committee's majority report was that the bill should be passed now in order to close this loophole. It is a matter of remedying something which was brought about by a High Court decision, and it is an instant remedy. The issues that have been raised by Senator Sherry, Senator Hogg, Senator Margetts and Senator Murray are issues which we thought, on balance, deserved some further inquiry, because there were a whole range of issues which could not be looked at in a one‐day inquiry by a legislation committee which was dealing with one piece of legislation.

I am sure there were people who would have liked to make submissions regarding what we intend to do at some stage in the future with regard to the taxation of ready‐to‐drink and designer drinks who did not have an input that day. In fact, the input to the inquiry was concentrated particularly on distillers and on people involved in dealing with alcohol abuse, whose evidence was very compelling.

I am pleased to note that one of our recommendations was that the loophole should be closed immediately. That is why we wanted the bill to be passed. However, the majority report noted a number of serious concerns raised by the industry. We know those concerns are there, that they are genuine and that they do have to be addressed. But we also said that the tax treatment has social consequences. We recommended that the matter should be the subject of an immediate review by government and that the review should look at the equity of tax treatment between ready‐to‐drink products and designer drinks in the P5 category, with reference particularly to three areas which I will not outline at present.

A Greens amendment was proposed before that inquiry was held. The third part of our recommendations referred to the possibility of introducing common taxation treatment for RTD products with an alcohol content of more than five per cent, and one for those with less than five per cent. It is interesting that the Greens have amended their amendment so that it contains only those two categories. We think they are trying to do things a little too quickly. I understand why they have come up with that scheme—below five per cent and above five per cent—and I do believe it has some merit. But I am of the view that we should have more time to consider this matter and that more people should have the opportunity to have some input.

Senator Hogg said he might interpret this proposal as not being a new tax, but the government might interpret it differently. We have said consistently that there will be no new taxes in this term of government.

TALK.START.PARA: —You've broken that already.

—Senator Sherry says we have broken it. That is an argument that we have had for a long time. You believe that; we do not. Senator Murray said that the report only toes the Treasury line. Senator Murray, you ought to know that those of us who were on that committee did not just toe the Treasury line. We did have a view of our own, which is why the report was couched in such terms, because we tried to find what we thought was a reasonable position for the government to take in light of the fact that they said their immediate concern was to close the loopholes in the bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Along with other senators, I am particularly concerned to say that I think the buying of ready‐to‐drink and designer drinks in a ready‐to‐use form will actually control the abuse of alcohol. It will control it in a way that might not otherwise be possible, particularly in the case of young people who mix their own drinks and who do not know how much alcohol they are mixing in their drinks. So there is a case to be made for ready‐to‐drink and designer drinks where the amount of alcohol taken in is measured, thus avoiding situations where people mix their own drinks and put a lot of alcohol in them. As I said, this particularly affects people of a very young age. That is another important issue that we support in this very critical area.

I will close by saying that the committee made this recommendation because the immediate purpose of this bill is to close an existing loophole. We want to do it straight away. We think all the other measures which have been raised—some of which I have sympathy for, as senators will know from my comments at the hearing and in the report—are matters for a later stage following further input from other people and organisations. The government at some future time can then make a decision based on all of that evidence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contribution to the debate on Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 1). At the outset may I thank Senator Ferguson and the Senate Economics Legislation Committee for the work they have done on this bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Might I say that the call for an inquiry contained in the committee recommendation predated the recent announcement by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) that there will be a comprehensive debate on tax reform and that the government will lead it. In view of that statement, it is the government's view that any inquiry into excise on alcohol should be looked at in the context of a comprehensive tax debate. I appreciate that this is an area of some complexity. That is mirrored in the report of the Senate committee and by the differing standpoints taken by various parties in the Senate.

The government is not inclined to support the amendments foreshadowed by the Greens and the Australian Democrats. It is perhaps better that I go into the detail of the reasons for that opposition when we go into committee. Suffice to say that this bill, as Senator Ferguson pointed out, is designed to correct an anomaly brought about by the sub ZERO decision. That is the purpose of the bill, and there is no wider purpose than that.

Regarding the Greens' amendment, the government is of the view that, if it were to support that, it would be in breach of its undertaking not to introduce any new taxes. That undertaking was given prior to the last election.

As to the question of retrospectivity, that was dealt with by the Senate Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills which, in its usual manner, looked at the subject very well and thoroughly, but the government is of the view that this bill clarifies the position in the form that people understood it to be prior to the sub ZERO decision being handed down. I think perhaps the detail of our opposition to the amendments of the Greens and the Democrats should be given more so in the committee stage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 2, page 1 (line 11), omit "3 February 1996", substitute "3 February 1997".
(2) Schedule 1, item 5, page 7 (line 2), omit "3 February 1996", substitute "3 February 1997".
(3) Schedule 1, item 5, page 7 (line 16), omit "3 February 1996", substitute "3 February 1997".

I will not address the Democrat amendments at length because I have covered, in my speech on the second reading, my grounds for proposing that retrospectivity apply from the date of the government's announcement and not from the date of February 1996. There are two principal reasons. Firstly, it is a Senate and a parliamentary principle not to approve retrospectivity except in instances of fraud, illegality or exceptional circumstances, and, secondly, it is a Senate and a parliamentary tradition—and a correct one—that retrospectivity in terms of revenue raising announcements should apply from the date of the announcement and not from some prior date determined by courts or any other mechanism.

BREAK.PARA: If I may, I will draw attention to those elements which we regard as requiring attention in terms of retrospective effects. Firstly, there is the element of natural justice, where retrospective legislation offends against the principles of natural justice and trespasses upon the basic tenet of our legal system that those subject to the law are entitled to be treated according to what the law says at the relevant time and according to what the law means at the time as declared by the courts.

The second area is that of uncertainty, where retrospective legislation brings uncertainty to the environment in which the community and business operate. The third area of retrospectivity concerns personal rights and liberties, where retrospective legislation has the potential to trespass unduly on the personal rights and liberties of people. The next area concerns the circumvention of recovery proceedings, where retrospective legislation defeats the judicial process by circumventing recovery proceedings to the financial disadvantage of the claimants.

The next area is an unusual area for commentary in the parliament. It is the area of sovereign risk, whereby retrospective legislation raises the perception internationally of sovereign risk in Australia. Sovereign risk is the principle that laws cannot bind the sovereign, and the government, by taking a stand such as this on sovereign risk, risks being seen as irresponsible and Australia runs the risk of being seen as an unsatisfactory place to do business—in other words, you are changing the rules of the game retrospectively.

In relation to transparency, retrospective legislation is not transparency, since it is based on past liabilities. Mr Feil, representing the Institute of Chartered Accountants, argued in evidence to the Senate Economics Legislation Committee that Australia cannot create uncertainty in its legislation on a retrospective basis and continue to encourage multinational and national companies to invest in Australia. My amendment fixes all those problems, and I commend it to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to take a lot of time on the issue of alleged retrospectivity, but I do wonder if Senator Murray could deal with the issue that I raised in my speech during the second reading debate. The approach Labor has taken is that there was a tax that was legal until the court ruled otherwise in the sub ZERO case. We have a lump of money collected that cannot be refunded to consumers. There will effectively be a very significant amount of money kept and retained by the producers, which is an unexpected profit.

SPEECH.PARA: Can Senator Murray differentiate on this occasion between his approach and the problem we are faced with from the recent High Court decision in respect of licensing fees and charges by the states, which were ruled illegal? How does Senator Murray differentiate between those two, accepting that I think the principle is the same—that is, the return of moneys to consumers, which is just not possible? How does Senator Murray propose to deal with that particular problem that has arisen from the High Court case?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I did try to do that in my speech on the second reading debate. I raised my voice, Senator Sherry, when you were speaking to your advisers—as you are now—in the attempt to attract your attention, because I did deal with that particular issue.

SPEECH.PARA: There are three issues I think you raised. The first one you did not raise explicitly. The first issue is that this is not the first time that revenue raising measures have been challenged in the courts and found not to apply and restitution has been made. If you look back at those situations—and I have not got them all in front of me, so do not ask me to itemise them—it is very seldom possible, when restitution of revenue is made, for that revenue to go all the way back to the consumers, because the consumers of products are so varied and so many that it is impossible for the company concerned to restore them.

For those who say that that results in a $12.6 million windfall gain to the companies concerned, I say, `Yes, that is true, but it was money that never did belong to the government in the first place. Anyway, when the companies get it paid back to them, it will go straight on to their bottom line and the government will get the 46 per cent company tax,' so you are not entirely a loser on the matter. So perhaps the net effect is around $6 million. The third aspect that you relate to is the much more complex and difficult one of the High Court's decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was the Federal Court; it was my mistake.

—Yes, the Federal Court and the High Court. Frankly, I do not have enough expertise in that area to respond to you on my feet—and I do not have any advisers I can call on for that particular aspect—but it is my view that this is an issue which has been dealt with adequately by the courts before. It has never caused a constitutional, management or government problem and fixing the date of retrospectivity, as I have in terms of the date of the announcement, has ample precedent and would cover the problem that has been outlined.

SPEECH.PARA: I have understood clearly the argument Senator Sherry put—indeed, the argument Senator Margetts put—but I think the greater risk you establish of allowing a precedent to go through on retrospectivity should overcome any qualms you might have about giving money to a number of companies that you might not be sympathetic to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I would just like to reiterate that I am unable to support Senator Murray's amendments in this regard. It is not actually a precedent, in as much as it is not the first time the Senate would have agreed to something which, in purely legal terms, may have been seen to be retrospective but in fact created the intention of government, rather than whether or not they had written it correctly in the letter of the law. It has happened on several occasions.

SPEECH.PARA: So in that sense, it is not a precedent. On a number of occasions, the arguments that were given in relation to the difficulties and the expectations that people had about tax liability have been taken into account when that decision was made. Therefore, I am unable to support these amendments on this occasion.

Senator SHERRY (Tasmania—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (12.06 p.m.)—I will conclude this issue on this point. Senator Murray, I still see a particular problem with your approach, given the recent High Court decision—yes, it was the High Court—in respect of state licensing fees and charges.

Effectively, the Senate will be asked to rule on the gains that have now been ruled unlawful by the High Court in respect of a tobacco distributor, I think it was, who took the case to the High Court ultimately. We will be presented with legislation that effectively prevents the states from benefiting from what has turned out to be illegal charges by states for a very, very significant number of years. That legislation—via a fairly circuitous route, but the only route legally—will ensure the Commonwealth imposes a regime of excises on those businesses in the states retrospectively. I cannot see any difference in principle between that problem we are going to be confronted with—and which Labor has given in principle support to—and the issue we are dealing with here.

That is one of the reasons why we will be supporting what could be—and what you have argued is—retrospective. We see these as exceptional circumstances. I am certainly not happy and comfortable about allowing exceptional circumstances to blow out beyond reason but, having considered this and discussed it with some of the industry people, I am not even sure the industry were seeking that. As I recall my discussions, or it might have been one of the submissions, I do not think the industry were expecting a refund of the money—certainly some elements of the industry were not expecting a refund of the money. It is not as though we have a situation here where significant elements of the industry are saying, `Whoopee, we won a court case. We can grab all this money.' So I think in those circumstances Labor has taken the correct position, and we will certainly still support the government on this aspect of the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sherry, I sympathise with you struggling with this a bit as we do, because that High Court judgment is so recent that all the ramifications are difficult to grasp. I did indicate in the second reading debate that the industry had not campaigned for these moneys to be refunded. The Democrats' approach this issue as a matter of principle—a matter of Senate principle, not a matter of industry equity.

SPEECH.PARA: I think one of the best ways to respond to your probing rather than your questioning is to indicate the New South Wales Labor government's approach on this matter. With regard to refunds due to the liquor retail industry, at first they refused to refund the money, as you know. Senator Sherry, I understood that the refusal by the New South Wales Labor government was based on legal and financial advice.

That they eventually decided to refund the money was a political decision because of the community pressure for equity to be established. They are going to refund that money throughout the country to proprietors of retail and wholesale establishments, who will be incapable of passing that money on to all the individual consumers who buy from them.

So we are into a bit of a messy discussion here as to what you can and cannot do and as to how it operates. That is why I have tried to stick very firmly to the principle we should be following. I do not think we need to say much more. I think what has been said needs to be said, and that is it. Let us go to the vote.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —For its part, the government will not be supporting the Democrats' amendment. The government takes on board the comments made by Senator Margetts and Senator Sherry and has some sympathy with those senators on the sentiments they expressed. I would also add to that the comments I made in my response to the second reading debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 2, page 2 (after line 4), at the end of the clause, add:
(5) Items 1A, 4A and 4B of Schedule 1 commence on the day on which this Act receives the Royal Assent.
(2) Schedule 1, page 3 (after line 5), after item 1, insert:

PARA.TAB: Insert:

TAB.TAB: Standard P5 means Food Standard P5 in the Australian Food Standards Code, 1992.

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Schedule 1, page 6 (before line 1), after item 4, insert:

PARA.TAB: Repeal the item, substitute:

SPEECH.PARA: 2. Spirits; Beverages containing distilled alcohol

ROW.ENTRY: Beverages (other than beverages comprised solely of fortified wine and other than beverages which are covered by Standard P5) containing distilled alcohol, n.e.i.

To the extent that the distilled alcohol in the beverage is attributable to the presence of brandy—$31.59 per litre of that distilled alcohol. To the extent that the distilled alcohol in the beverage is attributable to the presence of anything other than brandy—$36.99 per litre of that distilled alcohol
Spirits for fortifying Australian wine or for fortifying Australian grape must, subject to regulations
Spirits for industrial and scientific purposes, n.e.i., subject to regulations
Spirits for scientific or educational purposes, subject to regulations: (1)For use in universities (2)For use in approved technological colleges or other educational institutions prescribed by by‐law
Spirits for use in public hospitals, or for use in the manufacture of medicinal preparations for use in public hospitals and universities, subject to regulations
