PARA.TAB: Insert:

BREAK.PARA: 2A. Beverages covered by Standard P5

ROW.ENTRY: Beverages which are covered by Standard P5 and which do not contain more than 5% by volume of alcohol.
Beverages which are covered by Standard P5 and which contain more than 5% by volume of alcohol

To the extent that the beverage contains distilled alcohol which is attributable to the presence of brandy—$31.59 per litre of that distilled alcohol. To the extent that the beverage contains any alcohol which is attributable to the presence of anything other than brandy—$36.99 per litre of that alcohol.

BREAK.PARA: Amendment 1 sets a commencement date for my amendments from the date of royal assent. Therefore, they are not retrospective. Amendment 2 states that standard P5 is the same as the Australian food standards code.

Before I speak about these amendments, though, I want to say—despite what the government representatives have said here today, Minister—why it does not make any sense to wait until another time. My understanding from the committee was that there was not a great deal of angst being shown. There was not any indication that there was going to be a whole lot of new information being provided which would change what could otherwise be a very sensible solution to the problem.

The government is often telling the Greens and making statements in the press about what we do with time in the Senate. We have actually spent several hours on this issue in the Senate which, quite clearly, could have been avoided by a sensible approach by the government. Not only have we spent several hours trying to sort out the government's problem, but the government is suggesting that we go through the process again, not only in a committee stage in another review—which the industry do not seem to be calling for, and it is not necessarily from the community—but in the Senate. If we have to come back again to try to sort out the problem in the future, that means more hours. As I have suggested, I can imagine that it would be too difficult for the government then to adopt the approach we have presented to try to be helpful now.

So, if you are serious about programming time, it is hard to understand how you are actually suggesting drawing out a process simply on the vague idea of not being seen to be creating new taxes when, quite clearly, we have argued that people are not suggesting that there is a new tax being created, simply a more sensible approach to the same tax.

Amendment 2 states that standard P5 is the same as that in the Australian food standards code. The P standard is for alcoholic beverages, and the P5 standard is for alcoholic beverages not elsewhere standardised. This excludes beer and beer products, cider wine and wine products, sparkling wine, fruit wine, vegetable wine, fortified wine, reduced alcohol wine, meads, spirits and liquors. All of these are classified in other food standards. None is covered by P5, so the use of P5 should not affect them or change the tax treatment of any of these products.

But P5 will cover the new designer drinks, however made, unless they are actually redesigned to become beer or cider or spirits. In that case they will still be taxed according to their appropriate classification. The use of the P5 food standards assures that all alcoholic drinks will be subject to excise under one classification or another. Amendment 3 basically deletes whatever P5 drinks might otherwise fall into the spirit classification. I think there is a compelling argument that all P5 drinks should be taxed at the same rate, regardless of the source of their alcohol. They are all sold in a similar way, to a similar market, and made in a similar way, and I think there is no advantage or rationale to pushing manufacturers to use fermented rather than distilled alcohol. The product will remain essentially the same in either case.

Amendment 3 asserts the new P5 category. The rates of excise change from the beer rate for drinks of five per cent or less alcohol content, and at the spirits rate where there is more than five per cent alcohol. This puts higher alcohol designer drinks on par with the tax applied to mixed spirit drinks like `Bundy and Cola', all of which would be taxed at the spirits rate since they have around six per cent alcohol while the lower alcohol drinks would be taxed at the beer rate, seeing as they mainly compete with the beer market and are about the same alcohol content.

It leaves open an option to the manufacturers of premixed spirits to make low alcohol variations with a level of alcohol lower than any currently available. I do not see this as an undesirable option, nor do I see their treatment as inconsistent with the rest of the act. I note that the Alcohol and Other Drugs Council of Australia, in their evidence to the committee on this bill, supported our tiered approach to alcohol content on these drinks. I also note that the committee recognised that the bill will do nothing to rectify the current problem with regard to designer drinks. That is what I mentioned, with regard to Senate time, at the beginning of my presentation. I will remember this next time someone is ranting and raving about waste of Senate time. At least both minority reports suggested that something be done and my amendment was considered, and seen generally, to be on the right track.

I further note that, while it seems appropriate to take a tiered approach in this case based on alcohol content, our position largely reflects the fact that these are relatively synthetic manufactured products and alcohol levels may vary dramatically. Traditional alcoholic drinks, however, have a nature where the alcohol content does not generally vary markedly. Spirits are taxed at a high rate because spirits are by their nature high alcohol drinks. The tax treatment of other traditional drinks reflects both alcohol content and industry or use variations. I believe this is appropriate. It is inappropriate to simply tax all drinks at the alcohol level. I commend my amendments to the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was going to ask the minister—assuming that your legislation is passed—about the government ensuring that the excisability of beverages which contain distilled alcohol continues. What do you do in the event of producers switching from a distilled alcohol base to a fermented alcohol base, where there is absolutely no apparent difference in the product?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised, Senator Sherry, that producers have that option now of switching from distilled alcohol to fermented alcohol and that this bill would not prevent that happening.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is precisely why we indicated we are supporting the Green amendment. As I understand it, now that the government has confirmed that it will be taxing distilled alcohol and reversing the Federal Court decision, we are going to see producers switch away from a distilled alcohol base to a fermented alcohol base. There is an obvious financial incentive because the tax collected will be less.

SPEECH.PARA: My follow‐up questions to you, Senator, are: firstly, is the government concerned or not at the potential loss of revenue by people producing, or producers producing, either the current RTDs or some new brand of RTDs based on a fermented alcohol base, and the subsequent revenue loss that will result as a flow‐on of the switching in the production base from distilled alcohol to fermented alcohol? Secondly, do you have any estimated revenue loss, or estimates of revenue loss, as a consequence of the switching effect, which we know is already occurring?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to Senator Sherry's question: the government is unable to predict exactly how this will develop. One has to look at the market penetration of the fermented alcohol and how successful that will be. That is really getting into the crystal ball stage. The government, therefore, cannot predict what sorts of revenue implications there would be in this and it is hard to estimate that. I am unable to answer that question because of that aspect: how do we know how the particular product will fare in the marketplace?

SPEECH.PARA: But the government is of the view that, if it were to change the regime here in relation to fermented alcohol, it would be placing itself in a position where it would be breaching its undertaking to the people of Australia that it would not bring in any new taxes, and that is an overriding principle in this case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not a new tax. This excise has been there until the Federal Court decision. I will deal with your overriding principles a little later.

SPEECH.PARA: Minister, your legislation reimposes the tax on distilled alcohol. We have bottles of product made from distilled alcohol, and we have bottles of product that is not identifiably different in terms of taste or colour—the only thing that is different is the fancy name on the outside of the bottle—that is made from fermented alcohol, with the same alcoholic content. And yet what you are suggesting is that there should be a different tax treatment of those essentially the same products—only the base from which they manufactured being different.

Minister, surely you would have to accept that if producers can produce the same alcohol, the same colour, the same taste, and just vary the name on the outside of the bottle—they can even produce the same alcohol with the same name on the outside of the bottle—I put it to you that there is an obvious incentive for a producer to switch from a distilled alcohol to a fermented alcohol base, because the taxation of fermented alcohol under what you are proposing will be less. As a consequence, the government must lose revenue. This is not just a matter of the Greens amendment for social equity and tax; it is about protection of the existing tax base. I think any logical producer listening to this who can quite easily move from distilled to fermented alcohol base would do that, because they gain financially, since they would be paying less tax. As a consequence you must collect less tax.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not take issue with what you say, Senator Sherry. However, if we were to support the Greens amendment we would be treating fermented alcohol differently from the way it has been treated to the present day. That would be the introduction of a new tax—something we promised the people of Australia we would not do. I do not think I can put it any more simply than that.

—I would also like the minister to comment on this. There will be changes to the tax regime to sort out the difficulties associated with the recent High Court decision in relation to state and federal revenue collection. Will it not make that transition easier if we have sorted out some of these problems in advance rather than add yet another change onto a problematic decision which then has to be changed again later? If we have helped to sort out some of these anomalies now, will it not make it easier in the transition when those other changes need to take place?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —The essential aspect to this involves a question of tax reform. Recently the Prime Minister announced that the government would lead the debate in a comprehensive way in relation to the question of tax reform in Australia. If we tinker with one aspect of excise on alcohol, which in turn is a subset of another aspect of taxation across the whole spectrum of taxes, customs duties and excises, then I would think, Senator Margetts, that we could well be revisiting this in the debate that we are going to have on tax reform generally.

SPEECH.PARA: It is like having a giant canvas before you and you are just dabbing the oil on a corner of that canvas whilst the rest of it remains untouched. That is why the government took the view in relation to the suggestion of an inquiry by the Senate committee that we leave that until the comprehensive debate on tax reform. The Senate committee suggestions will no doubt stand the test of time and will be looked at in that debate. To tinker with it on this basis the government considers to be unwise.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am going to have to state the obvious here. This bill is tinkering with a tax. You are asking us to fix up a problem. You are actually changing the definition, so we are already doing that tinkering. You are saying that you would like us to tinker in one way and not another. We are trying to say, `Let's tinker in a way that actually helps to solve a problem.' I do not really want to delay the Senate any further, but I think we are getting down to semantics.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can briefly reply to that. This bill is rectifying an anomaly brought about by a decision handed down by the Federal Court. That is not tinkering; it is remedying a situation which has come about by legal interpretation. That is something quite different, with respect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —One can only congratulate the minister on his valiant attempt to support this legislation as a whole and to argue against the amendment that is now before us. As I see it, as a government bill it simply ensures that the proportion of a beverage that is distilled alcohol will be subject to excise. The taxation of beverages in the P5 food standard is anomalous, as we all agree. This bill presents an opportunity to correct this. As Senator Margetts said, the bill is tinkering, if you like, with the current situation. If we are going to tinker, we might as well deal with the anomalies.

SPEECH.PARA: Unless we do that, as Senator Sherry has said, the producers will simply substitute fermented alcohol for distilled alcohol, thus eroding the collection of excise by the Commonwealth—unless we believe, and it is hard to do so, that distillers are so public spirited that they will not take the opportunity of minimising their taxes.

Unless we amend this legislation in the way that Senator Margetts has proposed, high alcohol content drinks based on fermented alcohol would continue to be non‐excisable and, therefore, more appealing to young people. That is my feeling about the matter, from what I have heard young people say. Senator Margetts's amendment simply seeks to base excisability on the level of the alcohol content, rather than on its derivation, whether it be manufactured by fermentation or distillation. It seems entirely sensible and logical to me, and I propose to vote for the amendment.

I would like to thank and acknowledge—often we do not do this—the work done by our committees and the people who made submissions to the committees. I see Senator Murray nodding. He was at the Senate Economics Legislation Committee to which this bill was referred. That committee, as usual, which was chaired by Senator Ferguson, received quite important submissions which I found very interesting. As a matter of fact, I found the material from United Distillers very useful in getting a grasp of what it was all about. I notice that Senator Jacinta Collins wrote a minority report on behalf of the opposition. I am extremely grateful to those who work on these committees—I am on some of them myself. It does help independents and minor parties particularly. No doubt the major parties and the Senate as a whole benefit from the work of our Senate committees.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank again my colleague Senator Hogg for the work he put into this committee report. Also, like Senator Harradine, I thank the various organisations and individuals who presented submissions to the committee. Minister, as I understand it, your election commitment said that there would be no increase in existing taxes and no introduction of new taxes. Is that correct?
—That is how I recall it.
—In view of consistency, how do you rate the government's new half a billion dollar superannuation tax on higher income earners in the context of that promise?
—I don't think that is relevant to this debate.

—If I may spur you on, Senator Sherry, it is the understanding of the Senate Economics Legislation Committee, and it is our understanding, that far from introducing a new tax, what Senator Margetts's amendment does is protect the revenue base by at least $30 million. I would think that is just good housekeeping, good management and good husbandry, to use the old‐fashioned term. I would like to know whether your promise not to introduce new taxes should also include preserving your old tax base and your revenue base.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —Might I add a point. The opposition has not raised this point but I think that there is a problem with the Green amendment in relation to clause 2, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Standard P5 means Food Standard P5 in the Australian Food Standards Code, 1992.

This is another aspect of the amendment which the government has trouble with. It links the P5 into the food standards code, which is subject to change from time to time. These changes could well occur with no consideration of the effect it might have on the Excise Tariff Act, which is designed to tax various products. This has some relevance to the point which Senator Murray just raised in protecting revenue. It could well be, if the food standards code were changed and changed without parliamentary scrutiny, you could have a negative effect on revenue. Who knows? That is an aspect that the government finds to be of concern in relation to this amendment and it is another reason why the government cannot support the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —On that point, I understand that the food standards code would need to be approved by some person responsible for those standards—potentially a health minister or a minister involved with consumer affairs, and so on. In the end, one would have to think that minister would take a responsible approach—unless it is totally independent, and you could give me some advice on that. Unless I am totally wrong, if there is ministerial approval of some sort required for the changing of the standard code, then that minister would take into consideration the implications of revenue. Even if it is not coming to the parliament, then I would think there would be some responsibility taken at a departmental or ministerial level which would take into consideration the revenue implications of such changes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney-General)

TALK.START.PARA: —My initial advice is that the food standards code is adopted by the Australia New Zealand Food Authority, ANZFA. That, I am advised, is not reviewable.

SPEECH.PARA: The criteria in consideration in setting that food standards code would not entail any question of revenue, as I understand it. So that the person, albeit a very responsible person, making that decision would not be having regard to how it might affect revenue. That would be beyond their purview. I think that highlights the flaw.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I think this is a fairly spurious argument. The P5 standard means other drinks. If it does not fall under the `other drinks' classification and if there is a change in that classification, it will fall under one or other of the classifications.

SPEECH.PARA: It is actually clearer now. It is less likely to cause a revenue implication now that drinks will fall under one or the other classification. So the change from `other drinks' to something else will simply mean that it gets taxed at another rate instead of this rate. So the reality is that it is unlikely to fall between the cracks as it used to before. It actually creates greater certainty not less certainty in relation to standards.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, you have criticised the Green amendments for linking the rate of tax excise to the Australian food standards code. I draw your attention to page 4 of the explanatory memorandum, which says:

SPEECH.PARA: This sub‐item presently imposes excise duty on liqueurs. In order to be eligible for the concessional rate of excise duty, a liqueur is required to be prescribed by by‐law. This requirement existed mainly for health reasons and for classification purposes.

However, since the term "Liqueurs", which is defined in the Schedule to the Tariff Act, is now controlled by the Australian Food Standards Code 1992, the need for liqueurs to be prescribed by by‐law no longer exists.

So we have a situation where already liqueurs are now controlled by the Australian food standards code. What we have at the moment in respect to liqueurs is no different to the approach the Greens are taking in their amendments and are linking in a broader but consistent way the level of excise to the Australian food standards code.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand the point you are making there, Senator Sherry, but I think the point of distinction here is that liqueurs are also defined in the schedule to the tariff act. What we have here in clause 2 is a situation where standard P5 relies solely on that definition as stated in the clause. It would appear there are two aspects which govern liqueurs: the definition in the schedule and the food standards code.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —It says—and I just read it out—that it is now the food standards code that regulates—
—As well.
—No, not `as well'—now. My reading of it is that it has replaced it. Whether it is both or one, the fact is that it is consistent with the Greens' approach.

BREAK.PARA: I indicate that we are, obviously, supporting the Green amendments. We do not see this as a new tax. It is an existing excise tax whose base is being eroded due to new developments in industry and which we believe from all the evidence presented to us will result in a substantial loss of revenue to the government. We see that as being totally consistent with the principles that your government took to the election to ensure that these sorts of anomalies and loopholes would be closed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats indicate that they will be supporting the WA Greens' amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Ellison) read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson, Sen Kay

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak today in the matters of public interest debate about a $30 billion market. Each year the United Nations and multilateral development banks outlay $30 billion, creating new total investments of around $65 billion in recipient countries. Australian companies are getting some of this, but there is no reason why we should not be getting a lot more of it.

SPEECH.PARA: During my upcoming visit to the United Nations General Assembly as a parliamentary adviser, one of the things I will be looking at is how Australia and Australian businesses can more effectively tap into this market.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you on a junket, are you? Three months—three months, Senator. How did you get it?

—The politics of greed, Senator Schacht. The activities of the UN and its associate organisations represent very significant opportunities for internationally competitive firms. Each year, UN agencies contract out activities worth about $3.7 billion. I was amazed at the extent of this business when I started reading, researching and preparing for the trip. In the back of my mind I kept thinking of the potential opportunities for businesses in my own state of Victoria and for Australian businesses in general.

SPEECH.PARA: When one reads through the general business guide for potential suppliers of goods and services to the United Nations it is staggering to read the vast and varied opportunities that are available for supplying UN agencies. They purchase such things as food, drugs, medical equipment, vaccines, vehicles, communication and industrial equipment, tents, Tilley lamps, hoists, computer, software and sea and air fright. If you think of a peacekeeping force, there are many things that would be required from enamel plates and cups and saucers to a mass of other items. All of these are areas in which Australian companies already work and produce and areas in which we compete well.

In 1995, Australian companies won $33.7 million worth of business in UN contracts. This was a big increase compared to the $18.9 million secured in 1994. This increase really demonstrates the potential market that is waiting to be seized upon by Australian companies. It is also a testament to the increasing competitiveness of Australian companies. While I say this, there is of course scope for an improvement in these results. There is still room for many more Australian companies to become involved.

In 1995, the value of procurement business won by Australian firms overall also increased significantly, although it must be noted that fluctuations occur from year to year. Not only was there an increase in UN contracts awarded to Australian firms, there was also an increase in World Bank disbursements to Australian companies totalling $US242 million in 1994-95 compared with $US139 million in 1993-94. Australian companies won contracts funded by Asian development banks totalling $US142.5 million in 1995. That compared with $US42 million in 1994. Figures do fluctuate from year to year, however they show the magnitude and the great potential for Australian businesses.

When one analyses these multicultural procurement results, it highlights the worldwide spread of Australian companies. Australian firms are looking beyond the immediate Asia-Pacific region or traditional markets for procurement opportunities. This is of specific significance in regions such as Africa, Latin America, Eastern Europe, Central Asia and the Middle East. While these results are encouraging for Australia and Australian firms, we need to work hard to maintain and improve them.

While I have been concentrating on the positive figures and aspects, I cannot stress enough the importance of improving Australia's involvement. Close analysis of the figures contained in the trade and outcomes objective statement, tabled in parliament earlier this year, indicates—for example, in relation to multicultural development banks such as the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank—that a large proportion of the procurement business reflected only a few large commodity contracts. So even though the figures were higher it was due to a couple of large commodity contracts.

While we are doing better and doing well we must maintain these figures and do better. In relation to procurement businesses, the figures in the outcomes and objectives statement show that Australia's share of procurement contracts falls behind many other countries. In 1995, Australia's share of procurement while an improvement at $US33.7 million was still around 0.8 per cent of total UN procurement contracts worth $US3.7 billion. This means that we were 20th behind other countries such as the Ukraine, Panama and the Netherlands. The top six are the US with 17.83 per cent, Italy, Croatia, the UK, France and Germany.

As Australia contributes nearly 1.5 per cent of the UN's regular budget on time, the government would like to see Australia's percentage of UN business continue to im prove significantly. Based on these figures, when we compared them to other countries, it seems very clear that there is plenty of room to raise Australia's profile amongst UN agencies as a supplier of quality goods and services.

In light of the results I have just mentioned, the government is working hard to improve these figures and develop its trade and multilateral procurement strategy designed to help Australian companies do just that. The trade outcomes and objectives statement, which I mentioned, outlines the government's strategy. This statement for the first time sets out benchmarks of our performance on trade policy. It met a pre‐election commitment and is an important part of the coalition government's strategy to strengthen trade and foreign investment performance and to bring benefits to businesses and to the Australian community.

Our capacity to create new jobs and our ability to raise the living standards of all Australians depends on increasing our national wealth through trade. For example, between the September quarter 1995 and the September quarter 1996, Australia's GDP rose by 3.8 per cent in real terms. About one‐quarter of this increase was provided by the growth in net exports of goods and services. Increased trade is necessary to help sustain GDP and, very importantly, as it is an issue which concerns all Australians, jobs growth.

As part of the government's trade strategy, detailed in the outcomes and objectives statement, the minister set out the high priority which the government places on our efforts to assist Australian companies in winning contracts let by UN agencies. The strategy comprises two main elements. The first, Austrade and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade are active domestically in encouraging Australian companies to take up multilateral procurement opportunities. Austrade's export hotline is a valuable source of information. If you are making wheelbarrows in Ballarat or hoists in Bendigo, how do you know that the UN buys those sorts of things. That is the sort of information we have got to get across.

BREAK.PARA: In March last year the government established the Multilateral Procurement Unit within the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. This unit reinforces the government's efforts to develop and implement its multilateral procurement strategy. The unit has engaged relevant state business bodies and produced a number of publications outlining how to go about taking advantage of multilateral procurement opportunities. The second strategy involves overseas staff from both agencies assisting in the essential task of collecting early information about project opportunities. These staff in our various Foreign Affairs and Trade missions around the world also work to establish close links with procurement officials in UN agencies and with executing agencies in borrower countries for bank financed projects.

While I am attending the United Nations General Assembly I will be meeting with the Australian staff involved in this strategy to see what is being done and to learn more about how Australian companies can get a bigger slice of the UN market, so that I can be of as much assistance as possible to Australian firms when I return to Australia.

I have already had extensive contact with the Committee for Melbourne. I think this is a good news story that ought to be told. The Committee for Melbourne, which was established to promote business and business opportunities in Victoria, identified the fact that Australia is not as involved in UN procurement as it possibly could be. It identified the firms in Victoria which sell products—

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't forget that you represent all of Australia while you are there, Kay. You're also representing Australia over there.
—I am also a Victorian senator, Senator Schacht. I do not need your gratuitous advice. I am sure I will do it much better than you ever could.

BREAK.PARA: Because the Committee for Melbourne is committed—as are we on this side of the chamber—to jobs growth, it decided that we should be getting more of that action. The committee identified a number of firms—I think it is over 200—that sell the sorts of things the United Nations buys. The commit tee invited the businesses and procurement officers from the United Nations to a seminar so that the procurement officers could tell those businesses how they could get into the loop: how they could put in tenders, how they should put in their tenders and when the UN advertises. That was incredibly creative.

Do you know what we found out after 13 years of Labor? The Committee for Melbourne asked the UN procurement officers, `Do you have a conference every year?' They said, `Yes, we do: the World Health Organisation, UNICEF.' `Where do you have them?' `All around the world—wherever we're invited.' `Have you ever been invited to Australia?' `No, we've never been invited to Australia.' So the Committee for Melbourne invited the UN procurement officers to come to Australia to give Australian firms the opportunity to find out about the sorts of things that the United Nations buys.

That is the sort of pro‐active creative project which will make sure that we increase employment opportunities in Australia. It will give small businesses which might not otherwise get into the loop—the company that is making wheelbarrows in Victoria, the company that is making freeze dried food in Tasmania—an opportunity to find out how they can get into the system and become part of this worldwide procurement process.

The Committee for Melbourne and other Australian corporations, with the support of the Minister for Trade (Mr Tim Fischer) and his department, were successful in securing for Melbourne the United Nations Inter‐Agency Procurement Group Meeting. This meeting will be held in Melbourne in 1999. It will be the first time this meeting has been held in Australia. I congratulate Minister Fischer and his officers and also the Committee for Melbourne for this achievement. Holding the meeting in Australia will be invaluable in promoting Australia and Australian businesses. It will build on the momentum which has already been generated through promoting Australia's involvement in UN business.

I hope while I am at the UN to meet with procurement officers from both Washington and New York in order to make myself known as a conduit and a liaison point so that when they come to the conference in 1999 there will be somebody that they know.

There is a growing awareness among firms of the extent of the business and activities of the United Nations. It is vital that Australian businesses maximise future opportunities in the UN system. It is obvious that UN agencies are keen to diversify their sources of supply. Australian products and services are of world‐class standard. It is important that we show the UN this. It is also important that Australian companies increasingly develop links with the UN and its agencies. To do this and win contracts, our companies will have to be well informed and pro‐active.

UN officers have indicated that there does not appear to be a high level of awareness among Australian firms of the procurement procedures followed by UN agencies. Also, many companies are not responding to invitations to bid. By doing so they run the risk of not being asked to bid again. Companies also need to ensure that they complete their tender documents thoroughly and meet tender deadlines so that they are not disqualified at an early stage. These might sound simple matters, but they are matters that businesses must get right if Australian firms are to successfully compete for business.

While I am at the UN I will endeavour to find out all I can about this process so that I can pass the information on to businesses in my state and in other states—as I have already done, Senator Schacht, by alerting former Senator Bronwyn Bishop to the issues that might be able to be addressed through her portfolio. I cannot stress enough to businesses in Australia that I will do the same thing for them; I will not just promote businesses in Victoria. Although involvement in multilateral procurement can mean long lead times and substantial financial commitments for Australian businesses, the rewards are potentially great.

The UN and the multilateral development banks are some of the world's biggest customers. Australian companies cannot ignore this fact. With the involvement and strategy of the Australian federal government and the support of Australian businesses and organisa tions like the Committee for Melbourne, I am sure that our share of UN contracts in multilateral procurement can be increased, and that it can also contribute to jobs growth.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: South Australia: Leader of the Opposition

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in the matters of public interest debate concerning an issue relating to South Australia in particular—politics in South Australia—which has broad ramifications for all Australia. The issue is the fact that in South Australia the Leader of the Opposition of South Australia took out a defamation case against the Premier when the Premier called him a liar.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of the case being lodged in the court, as of Friday last week a number of documents relating the court case are available. I went to the Supreme Court registry, paid my $70—I think it was $70—and got four documents. The documents are available to any member of the public in South Australia or Australia who wishes to pay the money to get those documents as part of normal procedure.

The reason I did that was that, at the end of last week, in South Australia a number of media outlets—television stations and the national paper, the Australian—published detailed extracts from those documents which were available from the court about this case, a case which has quite significant political implications for both Mr Rann and Mr Olsen.

The newspaper that did not publish them was the Adelaide Advertiser. I was astonished that that paper did not cover something so significant to the politics of South Australia. The chief of staff of the paper informed me that the paper had taken legal advice that these documents may not have full privilege and that, therefore, the Adelaide Advertiser could be sued at a later date. No other media organisation in Australia had had similar advice, and they were more than happy to report in detail and accurately from the documents available.

I have discussed this with the Adelaide Advertiser. Its legal advice came from the legal firm Minter Ellison, which just happens to be the legal firm which provides advice on this matter to Mr Olsen, the Premier of South Australia. When I raised that matter with the people at the Adelaide Advertiser, they said that they were aware that the firm acted for both of them. They were concerned about the conflict of interest but they had spoken to the firm and the firm assured them that the lawyer dealing with advice to the Adelaide Advertiser had absolutely no connection with and was completely separated and walled off from the lawyer handling advice to Mr Olsen. Therefore, they said that they did not believe that there was any conflict of interest. I appreciate that the Adelaide Advertiser was so forthcoming in explaining that position to me during our recent telephone conversation.

I said to the people at the Adelaide Advertiser, `If it is a matter that you are concerned about on the legal advice that you have, the one thing I could do is to table all of these documents in the Australian Senate. As they are freely available to any member of the public in South Australia, I will table them in the Senate so that there can be no doubt about it, and therefore you can publish what you like and the public of South Australia can make a judgment.'

Mr Acting Deputy President, I wish to table five documents. The first is dated 30 June 1997 and is from Mr Rann. It is a court document giving his side of the case. The second is dated 29 July and is from Mr Olsen, in reply. The third document is from Mr Rann, dated 20 August, further explaining his case. The fourth is a reply from Mr Olsen of 21 August. The fifth document, also from Mr Olsen, explains his position and denies Mr Rann's allegations. I seek leave of the Senate to table these documents.

TALK.START.PARA: —No.
—Leave is refused.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I am astonished. These documents are publicly available to anyone in Australia who goes to the Supreme Court registry. The government whip has very stupidly denied my tabling even a public press release that Mr Olsen issued—not in the court but separately—in reply. He will not even let me table Mr Olsen's public press release which he did not go to the court with. This is how stupid the government's position is in refusing to allow me to table these documents.

SPEECH.PARA: It also shows that clearly the government Senate whip has taken advice from somewhere that Mr Olsen has a weak case and has to be protected, so the case that is available in the court documents cannot be made available to the people of South Australia. The importance of this case is that, for the first time in my memory and maybe in Australian political history, one political leader has taken a defamation case against another political leader and the court will decide who is telling the truth.

If the court decides in favour of one or the other—and I do not know which one it will be—the loser will have his political credibility absolutely shredded. This is not a slight argy‐bargy argument across the chamber in the Senate. That is why this is a matter of such public importance in South Australia. As the case unfolds, the people of South Australia, even today, should have access to this information. I am disappointed that the Adelaide Advertiser took legal advice that said it could not publish any of the material, when three television stations in Adelaide and the Australian openly published details of these documents at the end of last week and in Saturday's press.

Nevertheless, I now have no option other than to read extracts from these documents into the Hansard, and I will continue to do so for as long it takes to put these in—including in adjournment speeches, et cetera. In particular, I will read extracts from Mr Rann's document that he lodged with the court on 20 August 1997. The extract from the document reads:
PARTICULARS OF MATTER UPON WHICH BELIEF BASED
2.1 On or about the 21st February 1995 the defendant advised the plaintiff in the corridor outside the Chamber—
the defendant is Mr Olsen and the plaintiff is Mr Rann—

that the then Premier of South Australia, the Honourable Dean Brown ("Brown") had misled the House concerning that identity of a donor to the Liberal Party, Catch Tim Limited. On the same occasion the defendant agreed to talk further with the plaintiff on the issue.

2.2. Shortly after the events referred to in 2.1 hereof the plaintiff telephoned the defendant in his Parliamentary office at night. A conversation ensued in which the defendant advised the plaintiff that Brown had misled the House and must, as the Treasurer of the Liberal Party at the relevant time and a member of the Liberal Party's fund raising committee, have known the identity of Catch Tim and all other donors. During the course of the conversation the defendant referred to one Vicki Chapman ("Chapman") and indicated that Chapman would be asked by Brown to "take the rap" for the Catch Tim donation. The defendant urged the plaintiff to pursue the matter in the House as the plaintiff was "getting close". The defendant also advised the plaintiff that "You should pursue the Rob Gerard connection". Rob Gerard ("Gerard") is the Managing Director of Gerard Industries Pty Ltd. The defendant also said "You might want to talk to Dale Baker in respect of this". Dale Baker MP ("Baker") is and was the Member for MacKillop and a Government Member in Parliament at all material times. Baker was at the relevant time the Minister for Primary Industries. Baker was at all material times a known supporter of the defendant.
2.3 Following the telephone conversation referred to in 2.2 above and, in or about the first week of March 1995, the plaintiff telephoned Baker.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. I hesitate to raise a point of order at this time as, by convention, it is intended for discussion of matters of a non‐controversial nature. Mr Acting Deputy President, with that apology, I seek your ruling. I understand that Senator Schacht is reading from court documents from a court case that is currently in train. I seek your advice—and, through you, the clerk's advice—on whether this is sub judice and whether it is appropriate for this matter to be canvassed in parliament.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —In this instance I refer to Odgers's Senate Practice :

INTERJECT.PARA: It would be an undue restriction on the freedom of the Senate to debate matters of public interest if debate were to be restrained simply on the basis that matters may come before a court in the future. Thus the fact that writs have been issued, which does not necessarily mean that proceedings will ensue, does not give cause for the sub judice convention to be invoked.
That was a ruling by President Sibraa. In view of the fact that Senator Schacht has, in addition, referred to documents being public documents, I can see no reason why he should not continue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for that. In your ruling you indicated that, where a court case may be involved in the future, the issue of a writ therefore does not prevent discussion in the Senate. As I understand it, from having listened to Senator Schacht, this is more than a writ. As I understand it from Senator Schacht, there has been a writ filed, a statement of claim, and a defence, and I understood Senator Schacht to say that he was actually reading from a reply to the defence. If that is the case, it is not a court case of the future; it is very much a court case of the present. The pleadings are quite detailed and it is part of the court process that these details that are pleadings do proceed.
—So much for free speech from you lot!
—Order!
—I am only interested in the rules of the Senate.
—Senator, stick to the point of order.
—I am seeking your ruling. On the basis of the ruling you have just made, I would have thought it was self‐evident that Senator Schacht should not proceed.
—That was illustrative only. The principle behind the paragraph I have read is that the matter is not before a judge and jury. I do not uphold your point of order.
—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. The document continues:

SPEECH.PARA: 2.3 Following the telephone conversation referred to in 2.2 above and, in or about the first week of March 1995, the plaintiff telephoned Baker. Baker said words to the effect that he had heard that the plaintiff "had spoken to John (meaning the defendant)". Baker expressed a preparedness to answer questions concerning Catch Tim Ltd and also said that the plaintiff was at liberty to run proposed questions to Brown past him. Baker thereafter regularly provided information to the plaintiff on the issue of Catch Tim and political donations generally. The plaintiff by telephone submitted proposed questions to be put to Brown in the House to Baker for vetting and Baker suggested changes to those questions to improve them. Baker invited the plaintiff to focus upon the original source of the donation made to the Liberal Party through Catch Tim Limited. Baker advised the plaintiff to pursue the issue of the identity of Moriki Products in the same context as the plaintiff had pursued Brown in respect of the identity of Catch Tim Limited. The plaintiff formed the belief that in so assisting him Baker was acting as the agent of the defendant in order to embarrass Brown.

2.4 In or about mid‐March 1995 two sheets of paper containing questions regarding Political Donation issues were received at the plaintiff's office in Parliament House. The questions were in the nature of proposed questions to be put to Brown in the House. The plaintiff formed the belief that the sheets of paper had been forwarded by either the defendant or Baker on the defendant's behalf.

2.5 In or about the third week of March 1995 the plaintiff telephoned the defendant in his Parliamentary office in the evening of a Parliamentary sitting day. The defendant told the plaintiff words to the effect that Brown had had a meeting with Gerard prior to the previous election during which Gerard promised to bankroll the Brown campaign by arranging donations from friendly overseas companies with links to Gerard Industries Pty Ltd.

2.6 Kevin Foley MP ("Foley") is and was the Member for Hart and a Senior Opposition Shadow Minister at all material times. Foley is and was at all material times in a position of trust in respect of the plaintiff. The plaintiff was entitled to and did place reliance upon information provided to him by Foley. In or about later 1995 and during 1996 Foley advised the plaintiff that the defendant as the then Minister for Infrastructure was providing information to Foley in respect of a major outsourcing contract with Brown was negotiating and signed with a company known as Electronic Data Systems (EDS). Foley advised the plaintiff that the defendant had told Foley that Brown had signed the EDS deal, had been a weak negotiator, and had not secured the best possible deal for South Australia. During 1976 Foley did in Opposition strategy and policy meetings attended by the plaintiff and others provide information described by him as coming from a senior Government source. Outside of such meetings Foley advised the plaintiff that the defendant was the senior Government source referred to.

2.7 On or about 14 October 1996 the defendant spoke with Foley by telephone. During the course of the conversation the defendant said to Foley "Have you checked your mail lately?". Shortly thereafter Foley inspected his mailbox in Parliament House. In the mailbox, in an unmarked envelope, was part of a document believed to be from the Cabinet Sub‐committee for Information Technology. The document was partially cut up to remove marginal and source notes. Foley advised the plaintiff of the circumstances of the receipt of this document.

2.8 On or about 15 October 1996 in the early morning the defendant telephoned Foley. The defendant gave information to Foley of and concerning the issue of the location of EDS's head office in Adelaide. Such information formed the basis for questioning of Brown in the House that day and related to location of EDS headquarters in the old News building on North Terrace, co‐location of the Department of Information Industries in the same building and the proposed Delphin Lend Lease development planned for Technology Park. Foley advised the plaintiff of the circumstances of the receipt of this information.

2.9 On or about 22 October 1996 the plaintiff telephoned the defendant. The plaintiff enquired of the defendant as to what Brown was doing with the Adelaide City Council. The defendant confirmed an expressed belief of the plaintiff that Brown had made the Adelaide City Council a leadership test for himself. The defendant advised the plaintiff that Brown had told members of his Party that he would put the Labor Party under pressure on the issue and that the Labor Party would give way. He further advised that he believed that Brown had no idea as to what a proposed triumvirate to take over the Adelaide City Council would do but that Brown wanted to look strong "like Jeff Kennett".

2.10 On 4 November 1996 the defendant (by his office) telephoned Foley at Foley's electorate office. Foley was not present and the defendant left a message. Shortly thereafter the defendant did speak with Foley and the topic of the EDS contract was discussed. On or about 5 November 1996 Foley received an anonymous mail item. The document was a letter dated 14 October 1996 from Brown to Hansen & Yuncken. The letter was embarrassing to Brown. The letter suggested that Brown had misled Parliament on 15 October 1996 when answering questions put to him by Foley. The document was provided by Foley to the plaintiff. The plaintiff formed the view that the defendant was seeking to undermined Brown's leadership. The plaintiff formed the view that the defendant was the source of the document.

2.11 On or about 6 November 1996 Foley received an unmarked envelope containing cut up sections of what appeared to be a Cabinet submission relating to the EDS North Terrace building. The document disclosed inconsistencies in answers given by Brown to questions in the House on the issue. Foley provided the subject document to the plaintiff advising that the document was from the defendant.

2.12 The defendant spoke with the plaintiff again on the topic of the Adelaide City Council on 10 November 1996 following an event at the Power House Findon associated with the Greek Orthodox Church.
