SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coonan, Sen Helen

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise as a matter of public interest the implications for tax and industry policy of global electronic commerce. Few Australians would argue with the need for fundamental tax reform in this country. While the emphasis may vary and the preferred tax mix may differ, the potential for emerging technologies to erode existing tax revenue is truly breathtaking—so much so that no debate on tax and industry policy can fail to address the challenges of cyberspace.

SPEECH.PARA: Put simply, if we do not find solutions to the economic imperatives of the Internet, any tax reform might well be out‐ of‐date before it is implemented. These problems are not confined to Australia alone.

All countries are under the threat of borderless electronic commerce undermining the foundations of sales tax, capital gains tax and intellectual property as the basis for imposing withholding tax. The implications of information technology for the broader economy are profound, and the sense of urgency conveyed in the information industries task force report The global information economy: the way ahead should not be ignored.

In today's terms, harnessing the growth engines of the IT world is about competitiveness—getting the policy settings right to build infrastructure and to encourage investment. In tomorrow's terms, maximising the capacity of information technology will be about survival. The exponential growth of electronic commerce points to the reality that there is another tiger economy on our doorstep.

No longer a vision of what was merely imaginable beyond 2000, the information superhighway is rapidly transforming the way we do things such as banking, purchasing and communicating. Doing business over the Internet was virtually unheard of just a year or two ago. Since the World Wide Web was invented in 1989, electronic commerce has grown exponentially. Based on the 1995 Internet retail sales, worldwide electronic retailing is currently valued at $US300 million. Web commerce increased by 500 per cent in 1996 and is expected to grow at 400 per cent in 1997. Industry analysts expect Net trade to reach $100 billion to $150 billion by the year 2000.

The four factors driving growth in electronic commerce are the increase in the number of users, the high disposable incomes of typical Net users, the growing confidence in the Net as a medium for trade as the privacy and security of on-line transactions are secured and the growing convergence of electronic commerce technologies around the Net. The most rapid growth in electronic commerce has been in business to business transactions, currently estimated at about $US1 million. According to industry sources, by the year 2000 around 20 per cent of all software will be delivered on-line as well as 20 per cent of travel bookings in Australia and upwards of 50 per cent in the United States.

The release of the Goldsworthy report is timely in promoting an understanding of what is required to facilitate Australia's transition to an on-line economy. The research undertaken by Professor Goldsworthy should not, however, be read in isolation. Its implications and subject matter reach far beyond the relevance of the PC market—incorporating business, taxation, privacy laws, industry policy and training.

The matter of most significance to business and the community is the implications of the superhighway for job creation and employment. The 1996 OECD report Technology, productivity and job creation identifies knowledge, especially technological knowledge, in industries such as telecommunications, pharmaceuticals, new materials, environmental technologies, computers, education and software as the main sources of economic growth and job creation in member countries.

Whilst armed with the knowledge that the IT field represents the source of new jobs in Australia and the best chance we have of reducing unemployment, industry sources suggest that United States companies are, on average, about two years ahead of Australian companies in adapting to Net based electronic commerce. Further, the Goldsworthy report typecasts Australia as a declining player in the global IT field, representing two per cent of IT users and only 0.3 per cent of producers.

Hopping on board the IT superhighway is not just about keeping up with the Joneses, however. It is about putting Australia forward as an active participant that has the means to participate and influence the shape of the emerging global economy as opposed to being a passive spectator alongside the global IT giants.

With a collaborative review of the research undertaken by the Mortimer report, the Golds worthy report, the soon to be released Cutler report and the Australian Taxation Office Internet and electronic commerce project, we will soon be in a position to map out the way ahead for Australia's on-line economy. The treatment of electronic commerce as merely a modern day means of doing business, however, raises some serious questions.

Fundamental to these questions are the implications of electronic commerce for Australia's taxation system. Firstly, the full impact of borderless electronic banking has not yet been felt. Currently, Australia's claim to taxable income is based on the residence of the taxpayer and the source of the income or gains. However, as electronic commerce further erodes national borders, creating a virtual global marketplace in cyberspace, how is a government able to identify and trace who, what and where taxable activities are occurring? Unfortunately, a Net address does not identify the user or users with the same geographical proximity as does a postal address. How realistic is it that authorities will be able to track down cyber tax evaders?

Further, the Australian tax system enshrines the principle that the source of income is located where the economic activities creating the income occur. Given the global nature of the Net, how is the source or sources of income to be determined when taxable activities have taken place in a number of different jurisdictions across cyberspace? What evidence would be required to establish a permanent connection within a particular jurisdiction? If a permanent establishment is found to exist in a particular jurisdiction, how much of the income and expenses arising from global trading activities could be attributed to this jurisdiction?

Secondly, given President Clinton's recent commitment to a tax free trade zone on the Net, what technical and policy limitations will inhibit Australia from collecting taxable revenue from electronic commerce if, indeed, it were thought desirable to do so? Can the tax system of a solitary government be effective and enforceable amidst the tax shelters and hideaways of cyberspace?

Thirdly, if electronic cash is analogous to paper cash, how will transactions be sourced and traced in the absence of intermediaries and on-site tax collectors? What audit techniques, for example, would need to be implemented to avoid perhaps rampant tax evasion? Even if there is evidence of a transaction, how will authorities determine the nature of the transaction, which is, in effect, sent in the digitised form of binary numbers, without infringing individual privacy?

Fourthly, within a global marketplace with no traditional legal structure, will copyright and intellectual property rights still apply? How will these rights be monitored and enforced? To what degree will these concepts be relevant when the content has been altered, manipulated or even adapted? How will a company's identity be verified? What forms of protection will be afforded to protect individual brand names from being passed off as the real thing? Assuming that these issues can be resolved, the Net presents unlimited opportunities for Australian business and consumers.

In the wake of the contributions from Mortimer, Goldsworthy and Cutler, I look forward to investigating the implications of the expected growth in electronic commerce as a member of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts inquiry. The committee will inquire and report on the impact of Internet commerce on many areas of potential effect. The committee will consider amongst its terms of references the expected growth in Internet commerce and the findings and solutions proposed by the task force on electronic commerce, which are being prepared by the Australian tax office.

The quantity, value and types of goods entering Australia under duty and sales tax free limits and the commercial entry thresholds will be another area that will be considered. As well, it will look at the opportunities for Commonwealth agencies to improve services to the business sector and to the general public arising from growth in Internet commerce.

Two issues which I am eager to develop during the public accounts inquiry are the benefits of electronic commerce to small to medium enterprises and ways in which the new technology can increase labour flexibili ty. The Net is a cheap and effective means of reaching suppliers and markets that would otherwise be closed to small business.

One of the greatest advantages of the Net for Australian small business is its ability to erode the tyranny of distance, enabling the establishment of overseas market presence without the capital costs of a physical office. The opportunities available are such that businesses and consumers are rushing to connect to the Net. In January 1997, there were 57 million Net users worldwide, of whom 1.5 million were Australian. By the year 2000, the number of users is estimated to triple to about 150 million.

I have to inform the Senate that, if recent reports are to be believed, generation T has now been born. These are the techno tots and the cyber kids who have embraced the information superhighway and envisage that the Net will be used for such diverse purposes as to e-mail Santa, to elect the US President and to become mandatory for good living.

Research by US futurist Thom Blischock indicates that 98 per cent of people born after 1983 have used a computer. Generation T spends an average 4.4 hours per week on the computer, 18 hours watching television and seven hours on the telephone. The enthusiasm for the new technology is not dependent, however, on age. A recent trial of PC and Net training for people over 55 was met with unprecedented demand. Perhaps there is hope for all of us.

The Net makes home based work an attractive option for people with disabilities and parents who prefer to work from home. The possibilities of electronic commerce are virtually unlimited. It is clear that those countries that can quickly overcome the difficulties of ensuring security, privacy, intellectual property and revenue collection will lead the rest in terms of wealth and jobs. It is a challenge, I believe, that we all must be prepared to meet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop, Sen Mark

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to discuss in this matter of public interest the emerging debate on industry policy and observe at the outset that industry policy has changed fundamentally since the last election. There is a realisation that there has been a significant shift in the focus to provide sustainable growth. Of concern to Australians is that, as a nation, we are not meeting the new challenges in a global environment.

SPEECH.PARA: The social contract between the government and its citizens is lacking vision and a coherent strategy. The result has been a failure on the government's behalf to create the desired increase in living standards, job security and an engaging future for our children. Fundamentally, government has tended to be caught up in an industry policy debate that was relevant during the 1980s but is not so now. Significant macro-economic and micro-economic reforms during the 1980s have meant that much of the focus of industry policy debate today is irrelevant.

It is fair to argue that Australia has progressed from a nation that survived on the price of its commodities to one that realised its manufacturing base and, today, its services industry are critical to future success. This has been as a result of significant policy changes throughout the 1980s and early 1990s. However, realising the changing nature of the Australian economy is only half of the challenge facing government. The implementation of appropriate industry policy is essential to ensuring that future success and security.

Policy implementation has been a major concern in this sector. I mean two things by this. Firstly, Australia has continued to focus predominantly on an approach of utilising and promoting current comparative advantage as a way of attempting to improve Australia's trading position, our economic outlook and our long-term future. Secondly, Australia, and in particular this government, has relied and is relying on an economic policy rather than an industry policy to improve our world trading position. These two approaches have done and will do little to rectify the current problem with which Australia finds itself confronted.

Firstly, I will address the ills of focusing Australia's industry and economic policy on the notion of comparative advantage. Comparative advantage is premised on the notion that a country's engagement and success in a market should be determined by its natural resources and skills. These resources and skills create an immediate advantage in the respective market for the nation. Unfortunately for Australia, however, our natural resources and skills lie predominantly in the area of commodities, which has for some time now been producing a diminishing return for Australia. This means that we are leading the world in areas of trade that are of declining value.

The impact is twofold. Firstly, our return for investment is declining and, secondly, our imports increase as we outsource and buy products and skills that have been produced and provided offshore. Generally, these imports are in high growth areas, thus improving our trading partners' position at our own cost. The real success in comparative advantage will stem from creating an environment that identifies and facilities comparative advantage in long‐term, high growth industry sectors, rather than immediate comparative advantage but with little future prospects.

Secondly, I will address the failure of government to formulate a strategic and integrated industry policy. After significant macro‐economic and micro‐economic reform change in the 1980s, government has continued to focus on these issues of economic policy. However, with much of that work completed successfully over the last 10 years, government now needs to address new areas of policy reform. Economic policy can no longer be a substitute for industry policy. Government is relying on fiscal control, budget surpluses, low inflation and moderate wages growth to attract investment and to provide a level of growth that will both increase employment levels and living standards.

Industry policy does not rely solely on macro‐economic settings or micro‐economic reform. It actively participates in creating an environment in which industry and investment will prosper on an industry by industry basis. Economic policy can assist in creating an appropriate environment in which to conduct industry policy, but this cannot be confused with industry policy itself.

BREAK.PARA: To provide a participatory environment in which industry is engaged, industry policy is based and should rely upon a number of factors. Firstly, it must be strategic. This means that government and industry leaders in partnership must devise a plan for identifying and entering high growth and high return industry sectors. There must be clear criteria in order to identify those industries that Australia wishes to be engaged in. This requires a fundamental rethink of the nature of participation in the economy. It requires government to view its citizens not solely as consumers but also as producers. This means that the community has an interest in forgoing short‐term cost reduction based upon current areas of advantage. Instead, our community relies on the creation of comparative advantage in long‐term, high growth and return industries that provide employment and security.

As producers are reliant on growth for employment, it must be seen as a priority by the community to forgo short‐term consumer gain for long‐term advantage. In doing this, government is setting itself up to take advantage of a range of industries that will be long‐term producers, with increasing value. There are a range of criteria that are required for success in this selection process. These will be industries that will have a significant lifespan that will benefit Australia and Australians in the acquisition of technology, knowledge, research and development and public and private research.

Equally, these industries will exist where there is a high elasticity of demand. The desired industries should be export orientated, possibly with the government prepared to fund entry into the world market through national savings as an investment mechanism in Australia's future. The desired industries should also be value adding. This would increase the value of the export and decrease the cost of the final import where there is a direct correlation.

Finally, the industry should have a high level of return. This would be true to both investors and employees who see their living standards increase as the result of success and return levels of production. Thus, the com munity reaps the reward as producers via job security and increased wages, rather than as consumers via product cost reduction.

It must be understood that a strategic policy is compatible with an integrated policy. I mentioned earlier that economic policy can assist with creating a helpful environment for industry policy. Australia cannot afford to continue past policy trends of concentrating on one aspect of a problem or providing a one dimensional solution. To this effect, industry policy is in partnership with a range of other government policies. For example, part of this integrated approach may address issues such as import replacement.

Australia has focused on this remedy heavily in the past. However, it did so in a vacuum. The international market is much more complex in this approach as indicated. A multifaceted approach is required.

As part of an integrated and strategic policy, import replacement can be an important tool in the formulation of a successful industry policy. A failure to address all relevant issues that impact industry can, however, result in overall failure.

Once having identified these criteria and desired industries, the government must turn its attention to how best to implement and administer this. As previously mentioned, there are a number of immediate policy areas that can be used to assist industry growth. Tax policy, predominantly in the area of research development, stands out as an obvious choice. Such a policy allows industry to invest in areas that are identified as future long‐term growth industries. If government desires the identification of those industries, it must provide the incentive for industry involvement.

Bounties such as the ships bounty, which were vigorously supported by the ALP, is an obvious example. This policy, which in the end was supported by the government, allowed a current Australian industry leader with long‐term growth prospects to remain competitive, rather than putting it to the torch of neutral economic policy. These are, however, fundamentally areas of policy that are reactive rather than part of a strategic plan to assist industry. The initial approach to the bounty by the government and then the backflip due to electoral pressure highlight this reactive approach.

There have been two significant recent contributions to the focus government should take with regard to industry policy. The first of these was the Goldsworthy report that looked into the information economy. It made a number of recommendations regarding the role of government in this newly developing industry. Those recommendations were summarised in the following way: appointment of a cabinet minister for information industries; establishment of an industries council; a 200 per cent R&D concession; feasibility studies funded by an information economy development fund; coordination between three tiers of government; outsourcing to maximise development benefits; establishment of a purpose designed attraction agency for the industry; and some taxation reform.
Essentially, this was a report that encouraged government involvement and assistance in industry. Tom Burton explained in the Financial Review, and I quote:
The message from yesterday's report was clear: if the Government wants to snare a greater share of the global information industry it is going to have to pay for it.

The Mortimer report was of a similar opinion. This recommended: the support of successful industries; appointment of a high level investment advocate with $1 billion to sell Australia internationally; annual assessment of business assistance by parliament; and a focus on exports, investment, innovation, competitiveness and sustainable development.

Generally, these reports are on the right track. They seek to involve government in industry policy as a supporter of Australian industry. There are two concerns from these reports, however. Firstly, there may be an over reliance on the information economy which, at best, will include about 15 per cent of employment opportunities. In this sense, it may be a false hope to the government.

Secondly, there is an emphasis on assistance of industry and government intervention, but no real strategic plan on how to go about this or to give effect to particular outcomes. The long‐term focus required in planning industry policy can come from one main initiative: that is through the creation of an independent investment agency. This is not a new idea. It has been used successfully around the world, predominantly in South‐East Asia.

The success of that agency will depend on a number of criteria. They are: the agency must receive high levels of guaranteed government funding for a specific period of time, yet be allowed to remain independent; the agency must be wide reaching, based both on an industry and a sectorial approach; its performance must be tied to objective measurements; the primary objective must be to assist government and industry in identifying long‐term, high growth industries and to identify possible barriers of entry to the market; and it must be linked to growth targets.

The establishment of the agency, however, is not all that is required. A great deal of trust or faith must be placed in that agency. There will be a requirement for it to fully consider the agency's recommendations based upon that agency's expertise. The proposal for such an agency is contrary to the traditional, neutral economic and industry theory subscribed to by most governments of the past. However, if Australia's position at the moment teaches us anything, it is that the classical theory subscribed to is not working. One only has to look at the tiger economies of Asia to identify the structure and system required to facilitate this long‐term growth. Clearly, then, our industry policy requires a radical rethink of the role of government, both in the role it directly plays and the way in which it facilitates involvement from other quarters.

It is encouraging to read reports that the government is considering a further change in industry policy. However, the government needs to understand that the debate is more than the level playing field versus government intervention. The policy required is that of a different paradigm. The producer versus consumer approach is required in order to be prepared to make the decisions that will bring success in the future. The creation of advantage for the future requires a much more strategic approach than current day industry policy thinking has allowed for. The policy approach must focus much less on immediate cost advantage and much more on growth sectors of the future and government's role in facilitating that growth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing matters of public interest and I believe that one of the most important matters of public interest would be the credibility or otherwise of ministerial statements. I want to deal again with the very serious question of whether or not the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams), who is the first law officer of the Crown, in a statement on 8 April of this year, relating to X‐rated videos and the NVE classification, delivered himself of a statement which is demonstrably false.

SPEECH.PARA: I raised this matter with the leader of the government in this chamber (Senator Hill) by way of a question. I refer to that question, which is in the Hansard of 25 August 1997. I quoted from the Attorney‐General's statement which stated:

The Federal Government has decided to ban X‐rated videos and create a new category for non‐violent sexually explicit videos which will contain tighter guidelines in order to exclude demeaning material.

I asked Senator Hill whether he was aware that such material should already be excluded by law under the national classification code. Certainly the Attorney‐General should have known that. I asked him:

. . . Does this not mean that the responsible minister, namely the first law officer of the Crown, has failed to ensure that current X‐rated material conforms to the demeaning provisions of the national classification code and that, by this statement, the Attorney‐General has misled the public since the establishment of an NVE category is clearly not necessary, as he says, `in order to exclude demeaning material'? . . .
Senator Hill responded yesterday—I will not deal with his response on Monday, because it was a question without notice—after referring the matter to the Attorney‐General. He said:

. . . The Attorney‐General has noted that the joint press release referred to must be viewed in its entirety as not only reflecting the government's decision but also providing information to the community about what the proposed new NVE category is likely to contain . . .
If that is not a non‐answer, then I don't know what is. Clearly, it is a virtual admission that the Attorney‐General did deliver himself of a public statement which is demonstrably false.

Let us go to the second paragraph of the statement if the government is not prepared to admit openly—although, inferentially, it has—that he was wrong. The second paragraph of the Attorney‐General's statement said:
The decision fulfils the Government's commitment to ban X‐rated films and address community concerns about the availability of any sexually violent and demeaning sexually explicit material.

Officers of the Attorney‐General's Department admitted before a hearing of the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee that such material should not now be in the X category. Yet the Attorney‐General says that not only is the NVE to be established in order to do something which the minister or his officers should have done in respect of the X‐rated category, but also it is done to address community concerns about the availability of sexually violent and demeaning sexually explicit material—material that should already be excluded from the X category.

One wonders why the government has, on the recommendation of the Attorney‐General, proceeded in this way—on the basis of misinformation; on the basis of statements that are patently and provably incorrect. Because of the odium attached to the X category, Canberra's porn merchants have long sought the switch to the NVE label. In fact they welcomed the decision of the federal Attorney‐General to establish an NVE category and were able get around a clear election promise by this government to ban X‐rated videos.

The joint select committee on video materials received evidence that the pornography in the X category engenders in the minds of the habitual viewer a callous and manipulative orientation towards women, and a perception of women in general as highly promiscuous and available. This is the sort of material that we are dealing with. One would have thought that the Attorney‐General of this Commonwealth should state the facts. Instead, he has misled the community. He has not misled the parliament as yet but, obviously, if one were to believe the statement, it would mislead the parliament. No doubt his colleagues have also been misled.

It is a matter of great concern, because we are on the verge of this material going into the homes of Australians via the Internet. The technology is available, of course, and will be quite readily available in the next two years for real time videos to be shown through the Internet. This is something that should be considered very seriously by the parliament and the government.

Apart from the question of those issues in particular, I wish to reiterate my concern that the government has not focused on the clear fact that the Attorney‐General, the first law officer of the Crown, on an important social and public issue, has delivered himself of a statement which is provably false. I ask the government to take that matter on board in order to restore the credibility of statements that emanate from ministers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Hill, the Leader of the Government in the Senate representing the Prime Minister. Minister, are you aware that the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet have put together a list of fringe benefits that senior public servants can access in order to repackage their salaries and thereby avoid your government's new 15 per cent superannuation tax? Such fringe benefits would include a motor vehicle up to the value of $55,000, laptop computers and mobile phones. Does the government support salary repackaging by senior Prime Minister and Cabinet officers to avoid the new 15 per cent superannuation tax? If not, what action will the government take to ensure that their new 15 per cent superannuation tax is not avoided by their own employees?
—I must have missed that one. I will find out—
—You miss a lot these days, Hilly.
—I do not think I miss much at all but I apparently missed that one. I will find out the detail of that and come back with a considered response.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator, surely you should be able to rule out on the one hand the government introducing a new superannuation tax and on the other hand employees of the Prime Minister seeking to avoid the government's new superannuation tax. Does the list of fringe benefits that can be used to avoid your government's new 15 per cent superannuation tax have the approval of both the Secretary to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Mr Max Moore-Wilton, and the Prime Minister?
—I will not accept the premise of the question until I have ascertained the facts. I have said I will check on that and come back and give you a considered answer.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Knowles, Sen Susan

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill, and it relates to the issue of tax reform.

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought you'd be interested, but you'll be even more interested with the question because my question relates to the issue of tax reform. No doubt the minister's attention has been drawn to recent proposals by certain people about the introduction of death duties, the introduction of property taxes and claims that Australia is actually an undertaxed country. I therefore ask the minister: would he care to explain the different approach of a coalition government to that of the people advocating such new taxes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly have not missed this information. It is very important that the Australian public understand exactly where the Australian Labor Party stands in the tax debate. I know there is a little hesitancy to come forward at the moment but a little exploration will give considerable insight as to the position of the ALP. Mr Evans, the shadow Treasurer, now deputy leader, said last year, Australia is `so undertaxed—' so undertaxed—`by any relevant international standard, there is a case for having some overall revenue increases.

ANSWER.PARA: Madam President, you will recall that the Sunday before last he decided to add to that. Consistent with his recognition of last year that we were undertaxed and deserved tax increases, on the Sunday television program he called on the states to address their difficulties by increasing death duties, property taxes, state income tax surcharges and increased payroll taxes as well. This is the shadow Treasurer calling for increased taxes in this country—payroll taxes, income taxes, death duties and property taxes. There it lies.
Is that also the view of others in the ALP? What about Mr Tanner, one of the rising stars, the shadow minister for transport? What did he say? He said:
We should have an inheritance tax or some tax of that nature.
So Mr Tanner believes in inheritance taxes for Australians as well. He continued:
Deemed capital gains tax on death is another option in that regard . . . there should be a return to the 60c in the dollar tax rate for people earning over $75,000.
Senator Faulkner, he is one of yours, the rising star in the Labor Party. He went on to say:
I think our overall tax take at the moment has become too low. I am quite happy to state that I think the total tax is too low.
So it goes on. We have Mr Carr implementing bed taxes in New South Wales. What did Mr Goss, who is another aspiring Labor leader coming down here to Canberra, he hopes, say? He said:
We need to be looking at taxes. We need to be looking at the black economy.
Mr Tanner went on to say that he wants to extend sales tax on services—`A restructuring of sales tax, extending it to certain services and rationalising its existing incidence would be logical.'

BREAK.PARA: The hypocrisy. Firstly, they want taxes to rise—property taxes, inheritance taxes, income taxes and payroll taxes. Secondly, when you look at what Mr Carr said, when you look at what Mr Beazley has said in the past, and when you look at what Mr Tanner says now, they say you should be looking at broad based indirect taxes as well. So why won't the Labor Party leadership in Mr Beazley come clean and say that, in fact, the policy of the Labor Party, if it ever gets back into office, will be increased taxes and a new broad based indirect tax?

That is what your government did, Senator Mackay. It is okay for you to stand up here and say we forget the past, we rule off the past. Your policy was clear—I thought your policy was clear, maybe it is not—that where it is in the interests of the taxpayer the government will make the appropriate decisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I did not get an answer to my question. I understand that what happened at estimates was that the government ran the argument that the ownership of buildings is not a core government business. Isn't it core business of government to gain maximum value for taxpayers? Isn't your justification for outsourcing every possible government function based on this? Why have you then embarked on a measure which is clearly going to cost the taxpayer dearly in the medium to long term?

—Senator, again, I hate to draw on old history but it was your government which started outsourcing. Don't stand up here and try to lecture us and say, `Isn't it awful a government is outsourcing?' Senator Mackay, read the history of your own party. I know your own party has great difficulty in deciding where it stands on any issue. Senator Mackay, it was your party that started outsourcing.
—Answer the question!
—I am answering the question. I am absolutely answering the question. Senator, if you wish to forget your history, we do not. We will remind you of your history all the time.

—My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. I refer the minister to the outdated taxation system which the coalition government inherited when it came to office. Minister, what problems exist with the current system and how important is it that Australia pursues taxation reform and less tax?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator Watson, for the question. There are two questions which the Labor Party seeks to avoid and really hates. The first question is: what does the Labor Party stand for? No-one knows the answer to that question. I certainly do not. The second really hard question for the Labor party is: where does the Labor Party stand on tax reform?
—I know where Gareth Evans stands.

—I do not know where the Labor Party stands on tax reform. We know where Wayne Goss stands on tax reform and, as my colleague Senator Hill said, we know where Gareth Evans stands on tax reform. We know that Gareth Evans supports death duties but we think Kim Beazley does not support death duties. It all goes on and on. Even the Young Turks want tax reform. John Faulkner is not a Young Turk so he probably does not want tax reform. Senator Sherry is getting close to that margin and we do not think Senator Sherry wants tax reform.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to my answer to Senator Mackay, we can judge from history what is the Labor Party's attitude to tax. The Labor Party's attitude to tax can be summed up in two words—more tax. That is what the Labor Party stands for. That is exactly the point that Senator Hill made about Gary Evans.

BREAK.PARA: When Labor were in office they increased wholesale sales taxes, they increased petrol excises, they increased the Medicare levy, they increased the wholesale sales tax on cars, they increased company tax. There is great amusement in the Labor Party at this because the one thing you really like and really love is to increase taxes. That, I might say, is the one thing the Labor Party is good at—increasing taxes.

There are some real problems with the current tax system. The current tax system has real problems in relation to the high levels of marginal tax on personal income. There are problems with the wholesale sales tax system, as anyone who has been close to this system clearly knows. What is most peculiar is that the Labor Party refuses to join in this tax debate. What we have is a scattergun approach day after day with various members of the Labor Party moving in and moving out of the tax debate as they are corrected by their leader, Kim Beazley.

The coalition is very clear on its principles in relation to tax reform. We want a system which will encourage people to work, to save, to invest. We believe there is widespread support in the Australian community for tax reform; there is no question about that. As I said, we support a constructive debate on tax reform.

TALK.START.PARA: —You said that about the surcharge—it is a tax on super.
—I will come back to you on that one in a minute. It is a great tragedy that the Labor Party refuses to join in. One of the Young Turks said that we want to tax the wealthy.
—Who are the Young Turks?
—One of the Young Turks said that, Robert Ray.
—You taxed their super.

—But what did Senator Sherry want with the 15 per cent surcharge? Senator Sherry did not want a surcharge to be placed on higher income earners and he convinced the Labor Party of that. Thank you for the interjections.
—Senator Kemp, your time has expired. You ought not to refer to Mr Evans in the fashion you did during your answer to the question.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney‐General, Senator Ellison. Minister, what does the government anticipate the spending for the final month of the firearms buyback to be? Does the government anticipate a surplus from the Medicare levy? What will the size of the surplus be? Is the $63 million spent on administration too high? When the government conducts an audit of the scheme, will it include an audit of the administration expenses incurred by state and territory governments?

—I thank the honourable senator for his question. As was recently stated in the press and by the Attorney‐General, just under half a million firearms have been handed back and the program is going very successfully. That program has been advertised across the country. A recent Newspoll revealed that a high percentage of firearms have been returned. Three‐quarters of the illegal arms have now been returned. With regard to details as to funding, I do not have those available to me. I will refer the matter to the Attorney‐General and get those details to you.

—My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service. Is the minister aware that this morning on the radio Dr Kemp said that it takes four people in the Public Service to provide the same service as one person in the private sector? What was the source of these figures? Which departments or agencies was he referring to? Do you agree with Dr Kemp's statement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answer, firstly, is no, I did not hear it. Secondly, I have not heard of the proposition. Thirdly, I could not give you any indication of my attitude until I did. Fourthly, I would need to see the transcript and get a precise formula tion of the words used. So I am afraid I cannot really take it much beyond that.

—Minister, by not disowning Dr Kemp's figures, are you saying that one teacher in a private school does the work of four in a government school? Are you saying that one nurse in a private hospital does the work of four in a government hospital? Are you also saying that one worker in a private child‐care centre cares for four times as many children as a worker in a community based child‐care centre? If so, what is your evidence and, if not, will you apologise before further long‐term damage is caused to our Public Service by Dr Kemp?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —All I can say is that it is not a very good attempt. It is really a classic example of having a blind ideological commitment to a position. You are determined to put it on the record, irrespective. Even if I trotted out everything you ever wanted to hear, you would be wanting me to re‐endorse it, underline it and generally put it up in lights.

ANSWER.PARA: I cannot take the matter much further. I am sure that whatever proposition Dr Kemp espoused was a very carefully thought‐out one. I am sure we will be able to provide you with further elaboration. It might be a lot easier next time if you contacted his office, if you want to know what motivated a particular statement, rather than asking me to somehow second guess. Beyond that, I am afraid I cannot help you.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney‐General, Senator Ellison. Minister, are you aware of comments made by the New South Wales Privacy Commissioner, Mr Chris Puplick, that the proposed national privacy scheme recently released by the Commonwealth Privacy Commissioner would `become an embarrassment'? Are you aware that Mr Puplick stated that the Commonwealth's proposal would lead to each state developing their own inconsistent privacy laws? Are you also aware that 15 consumer, privacy and legal organisations have resolved to boycott consultations with the federal Privacy Com missioner because of these voluntary privacy proposals? Finally, has your attention been drawn to Mr Puplick's comments that the federal Privacy Commissioner has been forced to develop her proposal on the basis of what she thinks is saleable to the Howard cabinet? Why is it, Minister, that a weak voluntary privacy scheme is the only proposal that is acceptable to the Howard cabinet?

—I thank Senator Bolkus for that question. A weak privacy regime is not acceptable to the Howard government. I am not aware of the comments by the New South Wales Privacy Commissioner that you mentioned. There is no influence by the Commonwealth government of the Commonwealth Privacy Commissioner and there have been no instructions that any weak regime, as you put it, should be engaged in or embarked upon. I reject those comments.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, given your rejection of those comments, wasn't Mr Puplick correct when he observed:

QUESTION.PARA: Having seen the public humiliation of the Attorney‐General in this matter, in a situation where the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission itself is being gutted and filleted by the Coalition, with 43 per cent budget cuts, commissioners not being appointed, a new president not being appointed, a sex discrimination commissioner not being appointed, the last thing you would want to do if you are one of the remaining commissioners within the HREOC framework is to put something up to Government that will enable them to say "they're off on another one of these anti‐business frolics".
Minister, wasn't Mr Puplick right?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —No, he certainly was not. In relation to the Sex Discrimination Commissioner, Senator Bolkus is well aware that the Privacy Commissioner, Moira Scollay, was appointed to act in the position of Sex Discrimination Commissioner on 2 June this year for a period of three months. That acting appointment was then extended to 1 March 1998. So I reject outright that there is no‐one acting in the position of Sex Discrimination Commissioner.

ANSWER.PARA: There is no attempt by the federal government to gut HREOC and, as Senator Bolkus realised from recent estimates, HREOC is functioning. It is business as usual.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to you, Madam President. I refer to the restrictions on press photographers taking pictures in the Senate—for example, during the second half of question time—although live television coverage is permitted. I ask: will the Senate be following the House of Representatives in allowing, with prudent restrictions, pictures to be taken by press photographers at any time in this chamber?

—I recently wrote to parties and independent groups in the Senate sending a copy of the arrangements that the House of Representatives has come to with the press gallery on this matter and asking for any comments. I have had responses, which were totally different views, from two senators, and I expect to hear from others in due course. I will proceed to look at the matter when I have had the benefit of that advice.
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Could you outline what the process might be and if there is some time line towards making a decision on the matter?

—I intend to wait a reasonable time for responses to the letters I sent out. Parties must be given an opportunity to discuss it in their party rooms. I would not expect there to be any undue delay. This matter will receive attention, as it has for at least the last 12 months, and I think considerably before that.

—My question is directed to Senator Alston, the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Minister, could I ask you what was the cost of production of your department's latest CD‐ROM in the Australia on CD series entitled Tales from the kangaroo's crypt ? Could I ask you if the final product came to you for approval, or did you just approve the emblazoning of your photograph on the back cover? Are you aware, Minister, that the CD‐ROM has been described by the CD reviewer in the Australian as `ham‐fisted', `unimaginative', displaying `bleak ineptitude' in its use of CD‐ROM technology, and `a stinker'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australia on CD program I think emanated from the Creative Nation era of the Labor Party, going back to about 1994. I cannot remember now, but they threw a couple of million dollars at it and we have been generally following through on that because it was already very much in place.

ANSWER.PARA: I launched the first in the series a couple of months ago at the National Gallery—and it got rave reviews, I might say. Certainly I think it was a glowing example of the creativity of Australians. The program itself was very well patronised. There were lots of applications for grant funding, and generally I think it has been very well received. Indeed, that is one of the reasons we continued with the process. I imagine, although I was not involved in Tales from the kangaroo's crypt—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why is your photo on the back of it?
—My photo was? I do not know. Look, I was not there to cheer—
—It got an M rating!
—I resent being called mature in that context. Certainly I do not remember even authorising my photo to be used for it.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It may have been a horrible mistake. Maybe that is why the reviewer took the position that Senator Faulkner has indicated. He may have just looked at the photo and thought, `Well if that is as good as they have got, then maybe the contents of this aren't much better.' I simply do not know. I did not attend the opening; I was not involved in the launch; I have not seen the photograph. I am sure if it is a pretty ordinary one we can improve on it, and I am happy to address the issue.

ANSWER.PARA: Beyond that, I will find out for Senator Faulkner what the cost of the program was. Essentially I think it is old money that was allocated by you, and we are very grateful for that. No doubt it was provided at a time when you were still pretending there was a huge budget surplus. We have had to wear the consequences of that. Unfortunately, the money is locked in, and we are proceeding with the process.

Undoubtedly there will be variations between the CD programs. That is only to be expected. Some are better than others. As long as we do not get one about the ALP then I am sure we will not turn in a real shocker.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question of Senator Alston who says he knows nothing about this CD‐ROM, although his photograph appears on the back cover. Perhaps he could explain to us why, if he knows nothing, he issued a press release which said:

QUESTION.PARA: `With creatures such as flesh‐eating kangaroos, tree‐climbing crocodiles and the world's largest known dinosaurs, Tales from the Kangaroo's Crypt makes Australia's amazing prehistory more accessible not only to young people, but to Australians everywhere,'—

It just goes to show that you should read your own press releases, doesn't it? You also said it is `an invaluable educational tool'. All I want to know is how much it cost, why you stuck your photo on the back cover when you knew nothing about it, and are you confident that the production of this CD‐ROM has been an effective use of taxpayers' dollars?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us be clear about this; my press release made it very clear that this was about some very interesting aspects of prehistory which very many people in the population take very seriously. I am sure they will be appalled at your general response to it. I will find out what the cost is but, undoubtedly—
—You said you knew nothing about it.

—I know about the series of them; I simply said to you that I did not know about the photograph. That was the question Senator Faulkner asked. If you want to ask a wider question, you ask it. You cannot get up and ask about a photograph one minute and a press release the next and pretend that somehow they are the same when they are not.

BREAK.PARA: You may not know the difference between text and graphic, but we are more than happy to explain it to you. If you cannot tell the difference between a photograph and a press release, come over and have a word to me later. But for heaven's sake, do not ask Senator Schacht; you will get no enlightenment at all. As far as costs are concerned, we will get back to you shortly.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Minister, what is the government doing about listening to the concerns of Australian women? How widely is the government consulting with women from different backgrounds and ensuring their views are heard and considered by the government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Coonan for her question. She is one of the very many female members of the government who is making an important and very valued contribution to the policy making process of this government.

ANSWER.PARA: This government is certainly listening to Australian women and consulting with them. There are more coalition women listening and consulting to constituents now than at any time in Australia's history. Madam President, I am sure you will be personally interested to know that, as a percentage of all the women in the federal parliament, the coalition women make up something like 58 per cent. So there are a lot of coalition women listening to the concerns of Australians.

We as a government take very seriously our responsibility to consult with Australian women, who after all make up 51 per cent of the population. Our commitment to women is reflected in the record number of women MPs on the government benches. They did not get here by accident. They did not get here by quota.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is far too much talk in the chamber for people to hear clearly what is being said.

—Those opposite do not like to hear. They think they have a monopoly on the interests of women. Our commitment is not only demonstrated by the way we have got so many women into parliament; it is also reflected in the consultative processes that we have got in place.

ANSWER.PARA: Today I had the pleasure of opening the national women's round table which has brought nearly 50 national women's organisations to Canberra for consultations. Never before have they had a two-day round table. This enables them great opportunities for networking between the women's organisations and also for meeting with ministers, ministerial advisers and departmental officials. It also includes a delegation to meet with the Prime Minister tomorrow.

Previous round tables have been held twice a year for one day. Labor ministers, if they appeared at all, appeared for a very brief moment and disappeared. Women's organisations are not accustomed to having the federal Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women actually stay and listen to them. That in itself is a big plus. There is a more focused effort from the round table, because of the longer time that we have. Things can be canvassed at length and in more detail with a longer round table. It does provide, as I said before, for greater interaction or networking between the round table participants and also between members of parliament.

Earlier this year, I wrote to all women's organisations around Australia and asked them to identify, in consultation with their membership, issues which they regarded as important to women so that the agenda would reflect this and form the basis of the round table. It is an excellent opportunity for women's organisations to present their views to government and to the heart of the decision making process here in Parliament House. Relevant ministers have been invited to attend sessions relating to their portfolios, and the delegates will be meeting with ministers personally.

The discussions are wide ranging and they are interesting. Already we have spent a very interesting morning. In addition, there will be workshops on women and reconciliation and on how to access government to influence policy and access funding.

Yesterday, we held a summit in Parliament House where women from the Australian Council of Business Women met the Prime Minister. They discussed issues with him relating to the impact of Hilmer reforms—especially in rural and regional Australia—and to the potential skills deficit among young people, because in some instances, given state awards, it is more expensive to employ an apprentice over the weekend than a fully qualified staff member. What does that do for youth unemployment? They also were very keen to see the government undertake taxation reform, unlike the position that we have seen from the opposition. Australia's women are urging massive tax reform. I would like to go on if I had the opportunity. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coonan, Sen Helen

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, could you inform the Senate of any other issues that are of concern and that are being discussed at the round table today?

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition is obviously not interested in what the members of the round table are interested in.

ANSWER.PARA: They are discussing and canvassing issues of women and work and the related issues of family friendly workplaces and work related costs for women and families. They are interested in women and leadership. They are interested in appointments to boards and the development of mentoring programs in high profile business organisations. They are interested in domestic violence, which after all is the scourge of our society. They are interested in the national summit that will be convened by the Prime Minister later this year. They are interested in economic security for older women.

They are interested in getting the message through to parliamentarians and to parliamentary committees. We have helped them with the production of this little book, called Getting the message through. We have also helped them by putting together a booklet, which we have just launched today, called Australian women working together: An overview of the activities of Australian women's non-government organisations. That is useful for other organisations.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about access to women members of parliament?
—Access to women members of parliament is as well very important. Those are the things this government is doing for communication with women. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Minister, I refer you to recent reports that senior military planners are pushing for Australia to acquire long range tomahawk cruise missiles. Is it a fact that the government has already allocated $1.5 million for the conduct of a study on fitting the conventionally armed missiles to the navy's submarine fleet? Why have the funds been allocated? Why was there no public announcement of this decision, given the profound strategic and regional implications of such an acquisition? In the absence of such a public announcement, how has the potential acquisition and the allocation of funds for the study become publicly known?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I gather that the opposition is relying on media stories in this. I am advised by the Minister for Defence that a long-range stand-off capability is one option which has been suggested for enhancing our strike force in the future. But let me emphasise that no decision has been made by the government on the acquisition of such a capability at all. We already have a potent strike force of F111 aircraft and submarines. We are increasing the effectiveness of the F111 fleet by acquiring shorter range stand-off weapons.

ANSWER.PARA: It is not clear whether cruise missiles in Collins submarines or aircraft would be a cost-effective solution for Australia in the longer term. So studies on this issue are continuing. Long-range stand-off weapons are just one of the many competing priorities for defence funding. Let me emphasise that no decision has been made; studies are continuing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you say `studies are continuing'. Is that the study that is costing $1.5 million?
—I do not have any information here about the cost of any study. If it is available, I will see if I can get it for the senator.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Social Security Income and Assets Test

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Social Security. It relates to the inclusion of superannuation assets in the social security income and assets test. Minister, are you aware that, despite this policy coming into effect in less than four weeks, the Department of Social Security is still not able to tell people which investments will and will not be counted? Do you think it is fair that these people, some elderly and disabled, will have less than three weeks to make investment decisions which will affect them for the rest of their lives? When will specific details of exemptions from this policy be made available to DSS staff and customers?

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Woodley has got the wrong end of the stick. I am afraid it is not quite as he would portray. The FIS officers in the Department of Social Security, coupled with the other officers in the department, have been advising people for some months now after all this was announced last year.

QUESTION.PARA: There has been a growing interest amongst some people in the last few weeks as they realise that the start-up date is coming, and there has been a great deal of opportunity for older people to understand these issues. I might point out that in many parts of Australia the department has been running seminars to provide information for older people, at which they can ask questions and have matters followed up for them. I believe that the department has been pretty thorough in trying to get information to people, in trying to answer their questions, and in holding seminars and general discussion. As is the way with a lot of changes in legislation, however, often people are only starting to get interested themselves at the last minute.

We are very committed to looking after the customers in Social Security. The new Commonwealth Services Delivery Agency is totally customer focused. I would be concerned if older people are not getting the information that they need. If you have any specific examples, I would be very happy to take them up.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I refer to a letter dated 18 August of this year in which the department at Mount Gravatt told a person that, in fact, the department had not identified which investments will actually be exempted. Minister, I would like to ask you, in respect of your answer, whether or not the exemptions apply only to the income test and do not apply to the assets test. Could you give the Senate some indication of that, please?

—Senator, surely the exemptions you are referring to are where people have superannuation which is genuinely inaccessible. It is in those circumstances that I have the discretion on a one-by-one basis to determine if an exemption is appropriate. So it is not something that I think the department would be able to advise people on ahead of time. People would need to make application. I emphasise that it is only in the cases where—for one reason or another; that is, legal requirements of their fund or whatever—they simply cannot get access at all. So I think it would be better if you brought the case to me, and we will have a look at it.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Senator Alston. Is the minister aware that growing numbers of international screenwriters are agreeing with the Australian Writers Guild that writers must be counted as authors of films for the purposes of copyright? Is the minister also aware that the International Affiliation of Writers Guilds—which represents over 15,000 professional writers in the United States, Canada, Great Britain and New Zealand—has also objected to the exclusion of writers from the definition of `author'? What action has the minister taken to ensure that the entitlements of writers of films are protected?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —This issue is currently being addressed by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee, chaired by Senator Abetz. I know that they have had quite a number of representations and discussions on the issue. Quite clearly, there will always be concerns on behalf of those who would like to have a place in the sun. The government is anxious to address all of those concerns as much as we can, consistent with having an effective copyright regime.

ANSWER.PARA: We made it clear prior to the last election that moral rights are very important. We do want to protect the right of attribution, the right of integrity and the right to ensure that your work is not passed off as someone else's. In that context it is important, therefore, to ensure that you not only recognise those rights but that you do not, at the same time, put in place mechanisms which would effectively allow projects—quite often very expensive ones, particularly in the film industry—to come to a halt at short notice.

So they are matters that are being seriously addressed by the government. You asked me when we will be in a position to act. I imagine the first thing we will do is await the report from the Senate committee. Then we will take that into account before making a final decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, on what basis has the government reached the view expressed in the discussion paper `Proposed moral rights for copyright creators' that the director is the sole author of a film?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have indicated, there have been some concerns that the provisions in the legislation should be stronger. There is obviously a lively debate about whether scriptwriters should have rights in finished films rather than only in the scripts which form the basis of those films. I think the concern arises out of the ability to effectively obtain an injunction at the last moment if you claim that, for example, a piece of writing has been excised from the film. Whilst that might be a sensible executive decision made by a producer, it might offend the sensitivities of the originator. In those circumstances the judgment that we made was that the regime that we have included in the bill should be the one that should prevail. But, at the end of the day, we do not have a closed mind on the subject. We want to seriously address the implications of those changes and undoubtedly we will take notice of the arguments that are put up by international guilds and anyone else with an interest in the subject.

—My question is to the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Senator Alston. Minister, is the government aware of the recent ABC decision to have weekend regional weather forecasts in New South Wales, the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory read, in future, by the relevant news presenter? Was this a decision of government and has there been any community or other misunderstanding about this decision?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —The fact is that the ABC itself—in other words, unilaterally, without any involvement from government—

ANSWER.PARA: Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The ABC took an executive decision, uninspired and unrelated to anything that might have been said by government—in other words, we were not consulted in any shape or form—to require weekend weather reports to be presented by the news presenter rather than a dedicated weather reporter. That was made perfectly clear in a letter from the head of news of the ABC to the editor, dated yesterday, which said:

ANSWER.PARA: ABC News will continue to provide a weather report covering metropolitan and country New South Wales, the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory. It will be delivered by the news presenter, as it has been in every other state for some years.

It follows from that, of course, that quite clearly the weather reports will continue to be available. All those who are interested in the issue will continue to get the same quality of information that they had previously.

BREAK.PARA: In those circumstances, how can one possibly explain how the shadow minister for communications can put out a press release today saying that `the minister's decision to axe the ABC weather forecast was bordering on the insane'. This really is a very serious problem because the minister did not make any decision and the ABC weather forecast has not been axed. In other words, it is comprehensively wrong. The press release continues:
Senator Alston now goes down in history as the only minister to have banned the weather.

He asks me whether I know some Crowded House song. This is ludicrous. I simply ask whether this was Senator Schacht's own work. Were you out for a long lunch? Did you start thinking it was 1 April? Did you consult with the ABC? Of course you didn't. It is all your own work, isn't it, because you are desperately trying to get a run.

The tragedy is, of course, that you put out a release in that form and what happens? The jury is not out Senator Schacht. The jury has come right back in and what they have said is, `Comprehensively guilty of total ignorance and utter irrelevance.' The gallery comprehensively ignored this press release because they saw it for what it was—a very poor attempt at some sort of combination of humour and desperation to try and get back into the game. It does not do any justice to those who might be even tangentially interested in the issue.

I do not recall the last time Senator Schacht asked a question on communications, so it is not surprising that he does not want to take any interest in proceedings now. The only tragedy from the ALP's point of view is that he is still there. They have five ministers over there—they have 10 on the frontbench altogether. Seven of them have got trade union backgrounds.

I congratulate the recent meeting of the ACTU executive in deciding to promote Senators Mackay and Lundy, but all I can suggest is that if you want to be taken seriously, you ought to get Senator Schacht's position put before a full meeting of the ACTU congress. They will not stand for this. They simply will not cop it because you are doing irreparable damage. To go out there and talk about `bordering on the insane' simply raises the question of where the marbles are, my friend. I can tell you, in terms of Crowded House, it is not too crowded in your top packet. It simply makes Dan Quayle's spelling of `potatoe' look pretty good, I would have thought. If you wanted a bit of a briefing, why didn't you talk to the ABC? That is all you had to do. You don't have to ask me about it. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, what would be the consequences of any misunderstanding that has arisen out of the confusion in the state of mind of the shadow minister?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to say very serious consequences, Madam President.

—I raise a point of order, Madam President. We have had many points of order taken in this chamber in relation to the appropriateness of supplementary questions. I ask you, Madam President, given that you have made consistent rulings in relation to supplementary questions, to rule that one out of order. It is clearly in breach of both the standing orders and rulings that you have made consistently about the nature of supplementary questions.

—Madam President, on the point of order: all you had then, apart from a desperate attempt to try and bury one's head in the sand, was a series of assertions. You had no reasons advanced to you why a supplementary question that asks about the consequences of a matter dealt with in the question is somehow out of order. The best Senator Faulkner could say was that it was inappropriate. He did not tell you why it was inappropriate. I do not recall any standing order—
—It was about the state of mind of Chris Schacht; that's not in order and you know it.

—Senator Faulkner seems to be anticipating what the answer might be. He might be right, but that is not the issue. The issue is whether or not you can ask a follow‐up supplementary question that asks about the consequences of issues arising from the question.
—You are a deceitful cheat.
—Senator Cook, I ask you to withdraw that.
—I withdraw it, Madam President.

—On the point of order, the press release was certainly referred to by Senator Alston, and that can be commented upon. Senator Schacht's state of mind or what he might have been thinking cannot be commented upon by the minister.

—Madam President, I fully accept your ruling. I do not think anyone would be game to speculate on what Senator Schacht's state of mind would have been, but unfortunately, having committed himself to paper, he has to be judged by what is there. The consequences are very serious politically, because this is going to be a document we will be trotting around the countryside as an example of the sort of level to which opposition senators have risen—or descended.

ANSWER.PARA: For example, Senator Schacht says in this that `the sad aspect of the minister's banning the weather is the loss of a familiar face reading the weather report'. He is not interested in the quality of what is said, not interested in the accuracy of what is being said to the farmers and everyone else who relies on the weather reports—whether the pitch is going to be under water, whether the game is going to be washed out; all he is interested in is whether there is a familiar face. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Vanstone, the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, I refer to the contract entered into by your department with South Pacific Cruise Lines Ltd for $2.8 million in funding under the training for employment program. I accept your assurance last week that we will have your full and considered views on this within two weeks. But I ask: why, when the $2.8 million was raised last week, didn't you or your officers advise the committee that your department had been contracted more recently to pay even more money to this company?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I do not have advice about `even more money' being paid to this company. You rightly draw my attention to the raising of this matter in the estimates committee and to the assurance that I gave you that I certainly want to know more about this matter. I will not go over all the detail—I do not think it is the purpose of the Senate time to rehash estimates committees—but it is important for people to understand that the department, up until a period very close to the signing of the contract, was in fact dealing with a training provider with which the department has had extensive experience, William Angliss.
—So what?
—You say,`So what?' If the opposition want to be the government, they will have to win more public support and get elected. Then they can stand here and give the answers.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator O'Brien, as was indicated to you at the estimates, there was a substitution—I won't say at the last minute, because that implies on the last day—and it is that matter in particular that I want to get to the bottom of. I indicated to you that I would come back to you with a chronology of events. If there have been subsequent events to that that I do not now know about, I will certainly add that to the explanation I give you.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, reminding you that the original contract was for training to expire on 28 August, I am now reliably informed that your department has extended that contract for three weeks to 13 September, with payment accordingly, and will fly students to Jakarta—paying for their flights and a number of other things. I remind you that this is a contract with a company about which you said you had had concerns over the original contract. I ask you, if you are taking it on notice, to explain the handing over of this money to this company twice without appropriate checks.

—Senator, I have not got much to add to what I have already told you, other than to say that if the department believes that training—and that is an `if', it is in a sense a hypothetical answer—can be completed and enhanced and would otherwise be lost without a further investment, that may be the case. But as I have indicated to you, to the best of my knowledge I have not seen a piece of paper in relation to any further investment. I will get that and come back to you with it.

—My question is to Senator Vanstone, Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, this government is committed to meeting the challenge of the diverse educational needs of our community, which require innovative and effective programs to meet students' needs, particularly those of the indigenous community. Will the minister advise what assistance is available to indigenous children who present at school without previous exposure to English and what further initiatives this government is taking to improve the standard of services and outcomes for these students?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator Patterson, for a very astute question. This government is committed—as, I believe, the previous government was—to improving education, training and employment outcomes for indigenous Australians. The difference is that I think we are doing more about it. Earlier this week I attended the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people's Training Advisory Council Network Group Conference and commended the VET sector for the role that it is playing in some very successful and innovative approaches that the Commonwealth has adopted to meet the needs of indigenous students.

ANSWER.PARA: These include a number of things. Under the indigenous education strategic initiatives project, I was very pleased to secure in the last budget an additional $80 million for funding for preschool to TAFE, spread over four years to 1999. That is a lot of money to secure as additional funds in a very difficult budgetary climate. In 1997 that program will provide some $110 million to education providers and state education systems on a per capita basis to assist schools to improve outcomes for indigenous students.

Under the new apprenticeships and traineeships which we are about to overhaul, we want to shape a non‐bureaucratic, accessible, relevant training system for employers and of course for people wanting training. Within the last 12 months we have made some very significant progress in moving towards this.
