Indigenous employment programs have been maintained. Over 4,700 indigenous people commenced traineeships in 1996‐97—compared to 800 in 1994‐95. There is one of the key differences in performance: 4,700 indigenous people on traineeships under us; 800 in 1994‐95 under the previous Labor government. A further six projects are planned to start this financial year and are expected to provide positions for up to 165 apprentices and trainees.

In higher education nationally, for 1997 we have allocated $21.6 million to higher education institutions across Australia to support Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education. In addition to that, I announced last year a further $8.8 million for the establishment of five indigenous higher education centres. These centres will encourage the development of research skills and academic excellence within the indigenous community and help to nurture and promote Australian indigenous cultural heritage. The coalition government has increased funding for indigenous education across the spectrum from preschool to higher education, but we are not satisfied with that. There is still more to be done.

While most Australians take literacy and numeracy skills for granted, a significant number of indigenous students encounter very real difficulties. The government is aware that the Labor government failed to provide assistance to children from indigenous communities entering school who required additional assistance in English in order to function effectively in the classroom. I am very pleased to tell the Senate that I have announced today that a new program of support for these students is to be introduced next year. The Commonwealth will provide an estimated $6.2 million per annum for this purpose under the indigenous education strategic initiatives program. It will provide to indigenous students from non‐English speaking backgrounds and communities intensive courses in standard Australian English similar to courses provided to newly arrived migrants. It will enable students commencing their schooling to do so on the same footing as other Australian students by providing government and non‐government education authorities a once‐only payment of just over $3,000 for each eligible student. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, during question time Senator Faulkner asked me a question and I am now in a position to provide further information. The CD‐ROM Tales from the kangaroo's crypt cost $650,000 to produce. It is the second in a series of 10 CDs being produced under the Australia on CD program which was initially funded under Labor's Creative Nation statement. Funding for the program has been retained by the coalition government. The Australia on CD program is an important means of providing opportunities to private and community sector multimedia content developers. It is also an effective means of using multimedia technologies to inform Australians and the rest of the world about Australia's sport, culture, history and the environment. The first CD in the series, Under a southern sun , received rave reviews from the critiques. Tales from the kangaroo's crypt was launched by Senator Hill on 11 August at Parliament House.

SPEECH.PARA: In his critique of Tales from the kangaroo's crypt, Mark Butler makes a number of subjective judgments about which there can be legitimate differences of opinion. The article even suggests that the CD costs $29.95 for schools to purchase. I can assure the Senate that the first copy of the CD will be provided free of charge to all primary and secondary schools in Australia, as well as to public libraries, members and senators and Australian overseas missions.

Not all of the comments on the Tales from the kangaroo's crypt have been negative. I draw the Senate's attention to an e‐mail received by my department on 16 August from a primary school teacher at Holgate primary school who has responsibility for computer. In reference to the Tales from the kangaroo's crypt CD, he states—

TALK.START.PARA: —Was his name Peter Alston?
—No, that is not the name. He states:

SPEECH.PARA: It's entertaining, makes one think laterally, makes one think period. . . . It's informative and challenges us. . . . I would have no hesitation recommending it to others. Congratulations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Further to my response to a question from Senator Murray on Monday in relation to possible triggers for federal involvement in Western Australia's Fitzroy River development proposal, I can confirm that there are no known decisions of circumstances at this stage which would trigger the Commonwealth Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974. There was early advice that there was one Ramsar site within the catchment. Later advice was to the effect that this was not so and that the site is unlikely to be affected by the proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said earlier, the Western Australian government has provided assurance that any irrigation development in the west Kimberley will be subject to normal legislative requirements for such projects in relation to environmental impact assessments associated with the ecological requirements of the river system. The Commonwealth would seek to be involved in any state environmental impact assessment process to ensure that the Commonwealth environmental interests are fully taken into account.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, earlier today I was asked a question relating to the defence portfolio and some additional information has been provided to me by the minister. There is no study, as such, in defence that meets the description of the study mentioned in the Canberra Times article. However, defence studies continue to monitor missile developments and purchases around the world, as well as appropriate capabilities for the ADF.

DEBATE.TITLE: ACCESS TO HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES BY SENATORS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to inform senators of the outcome of matters I have been discussing with the Speaker of the House of Representatives conveyed as follows in a letter from him dated today's date:

SPEECH.PARA: I am very pleased to advise that I have given my approval to arrangements for distinguished visitors and Senators to be positioned in an appropriate area on the floor of the House of Representatives Chamber for the viewing of the House's proceedings. This arrangement recognises the dual role of Members and Senators in the legislative process and reciprocates the access provided by the Senate to Members. The first floor gallery, of course, remains available to Senators under the existing arrangements.
As it will take a few days to establish the ground floor gallery area, I would expect the new gallery area to be introduced from 1 September 1997.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston), to a question without notice asked by Senator Heffernan today, relating to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.

I am delighted to have this opportunity to speak to this issue, which Senator Alston raised, commenting about my press release. What he fundamentally failed to acknowledge again, as he has now done for 12 months, is that it is his policy and his government's policy which has cut $55 million a year off the ABC budget. If that budget had not been cut, they would not have had to restructure so many of their programs and sack nearly 1,000 people. That is Senator Alston's policy. It is what we will consistently say, every chance we get to expose the fact that he wants to blame ABC management for the changes in programming, when those changes are brought about by the cuts to the ABC that this government, in opposition, promised not to make. On election night, after they had won the election, when Senator Alston was asked, `Will you maintain funding for the triennium in real terms?' he said, `Absolutely.' Four months later, $55 million a year was taken off the ABC budget.

The issue of the cut to the weather reporting is on the front page of yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald. I think most people would rather trust the remarks of Allan Humphries and David Ellyard than your long track record of broken promises regarding the ABC. The article states:
But Humphries, 49, departed with both guns blazing. Yesterday he accused the ABC of "blatant urban bias".
"Ultra violet readings, Sydney's dam heights, a beach watch on bluebottle stings on Bondi Beach, and pollution levels now clutter the weather slot," he said.

He is going because this minister cut the ABC budget. This change to the programming of the ABC weather service is because this minister and this government have broken their promise to maintain ABC funding.

As I have said before, 1,000 jobs have gone. There has been amalgamation of programs, whether it is in radio or on television. The ABC still has not yet completed all its cuts to meet the target set by the government. We certainly know that Radio Australia has been destroyed to achieve the cuts of this government. We have already had plenty of evidence that this has reduced Australia's standing in the Asia-Pacific region. In recent times there has been evidence given that, even in South-East Asia, in such places as Cambodia, our expatriates have been put more at risk, as they said publicly to me and the ambassador in Cambodia—

TALK.START.PARA: —What's this got to do with weather programs?

—Because they can no longer get Radio Australia when relevant information should be made available. This is a result of the cuts that this government has made. We will consistently raise this and expose this minister for what he has done. He has comprehensively broken his own promise. This is not the only area in which he has broken his promise on the ABC—this is only one area.

SPEECH.PARA: He promised before the election to have an independent inquiry into media ownership in Australia. Now he is down to having deals done behind the scenes. That is typical of this minister. But the fundamental broken promise is $55 million a year off the ABC. Minister, do not blame the ABC management; blame yourself, Mr Costello and Mr Howard. You were the ones who posed the cuts. You were the ones who got the result that we saw in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald where well-respected staff of the ABC are saying publicly their program has gone because of your cuts that the management has to impose.

It is an absolute hypocrisy for you to stand up and say, `It's the ABC's fault, not mine.' If you had not put the cuts on them, they would not be having to do this to their program. We certainly will expose this at every chance we get and draw it to the attention of the public through press releases, through public statements and through statements here. Minister, we hope that in the next budget you can revisit the draconian cuts you have put on the ABC so that they can restore the programming that certainly regional Australia wants.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —All of what Senator Schacht just said is wrong—
—What? A $55 million cut?

—Hang on! But he is entitled to run a political line. You are perfectly entitled to get up and say, `The ABC had to do this because of the government's cuts.' The only problem is that you did not say that. This is where you kicked the biggest own goal in history because you said, `The minister's decision to axe the weather forecast—
—Yes—this weather forecast.

—No, but you see it is not the weather forecast that has been cut by me or the ABC. All that they have done is to say that, instead of having dedicated weather presenters, they will have it read by the news presenter.
—You are playing semantics now—a slick lawyer from Melbourne's defence.
—There is nothing slick lawyer about this, my friend. The fact is that you are absolutely and comprehensively wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: You overplay your hand. No wonder you cannot get a run. You do not get a run because you say, `The minister banned the weather.' That is investing me with supernatural powers. Gough Whitlam would be furious to think that I had the ability to ban the weather. If I could ban the weather, I would be banning a lot of other things as well and I would be trying to save you from yourself. But, unfortunately, I cannot. I do not have any control over your ability to put out press releases that are totally and absolutely wrong.

Play the politics as much as you like. Get up and say, `The poor old ABC had no choice because the nasty, wicked government chopped $55 million off them.' You ignore the fact, of course, that all they have done is bring it in line with the weather broadcasting around Australia. As the head of news said, it will be delivered by the news presenter as it has been in every other state for some years.

Again, if only you just made it a bit clear that you understood the issue. If you say, `The minister axed the weather report,' and then say, `The minister banned the weather,' it is no wonder they do not take you seriously. They think, `This bloke is out of his depth.' They probably think, `This bloke has been out in the rain too long.' You are drowning in it.

TALK.START.PARA: —You break your promises all the time, Richard.
—Unfortunately, you do not run that line here. You do not say, `This is because of the government's breach of promise.' You do not say that; you say, `The minister has banned the weather report.'
—Minister, maybe if you address the chair, it will discourage him.

—I have no objection at all to Senator Schacht on a personal explanation apologising for just getting it so fundamentally wrong. Think about it for a moment. The only reason you put out a press release is to try to make a political point, isn't it? You are not making a political point if no-one takes you seriously, and they do not take you seriously because you do not understand the issues.

SPEECH.PARA: They do not think it is very clever. They do not think it is particularly funny. Maybe the staff thought it was funny. Maybe they had had a long lunch and thought, `Chris will not mind. We will just run this out and see if it gets a bit of a giggle.' It did not. All that happens is that it comes right back in your own face.

I know there is not much talent over there, but you have to be under pressure after this effort. If I were you, I would go back, think about the issue, make your political point and blame them. I have not blamed the ABC.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, you did.
—I have just simply recited the fact that the ABC itself took the decision and, as it says, it brought it in line with the practice in every other state.
—You are telling lies again, Richard. You could not lie straight in bed. You are a slick, lying lawyer from Melbourne.
—Order! Senator Schacht you might like to withdraw the last comments you made.
—I withdraw.

—The ABC may well have taken this decision irrespective of the level of funding they got from government because it is simply a sensible decision to take. It brings this service into line with the service in every other state. Get the facts right. Give it a bit of a political barb. We do not mind that. Good cut and thrust and the media will say, `Well, at least he understands the issue.' If you go and put out something bordering on the insane, it shows that the only issue of insanity arises over there. That is the problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne, Sen Vicki

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) can say, `You can make it political if you want,' but this was made political when this government first of all chopped $11 million from the ABC budget last year, and will chop $55 million from the ABC budget over the next three years. The reason it was made political—
—The press release doesn't say that.
—Is the minister interjecting when he is not in his seat. I am outraged if that is the case.
—Minister, you know the correct behaviour.

—Fancy ministers exhibiting incorrect behaviour. I am very shocked. The political point was made by the cabinet of this government when last year they chopped $11 million from the budget of the ABC and this year chopped $55 million from the budget. Perhaps the weather forecasters would have been the people to go anyway, as the minister said. There are a lot of things that have to go from the ABC that should not have to go. There were innovative programs being developed that have just been chopped. We will never see them. We will never know what they were.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that Frontline is now not able to be bought by the ABC because somebody has outbid them for it. Where did the people who developed Frontline come from? What did they say on the television when they were interviewed? They said, `If we had not been trained in the ABC, we would not have been able do this.' They thought that in‐house production in the ABC was one of the most valuable things that the ABC does. This government is trying to make the ABC stop all in‐house production except for news and current affairs. That is an absolutely outrageous and totally ridiculous situation.

BREAK.PARA: One other issue that I will mention before I sit down is one that Senator Schacht mentioned and that is Radio Australia. Radio Australia currently broadcasts in many languages. I will give them that. I think we are up to plan C. Plan A was to get rid of Radio Australia. This of course came from the government and not the ABC. Plan B from the government was, `We will not get rid of it, but we will put it out just on satellite. So if you are poor and do not know what is going on in your country you will not be able to hear it anyway. It will only be in English, by the way, so if you do not speak English too bad. But we want to be really close to Asia.'

Plan C is what we are up to now. The Cantonese service was chopped on 1 July—spectacular timing; the day that Hong Kong was handed over to the Chinese again. The French service was chopped that day too. There are a lot of French speakers in the Pacific region because it is an old colonial region. Cantonese has gone and French has gone.

It is very good that we still have the other languages, but, unfortunately, if you live in Cambodia, where they speak Khmer and where we are trying to broadcast Khmer to, you cannot hear it because the Cox Peninsula transmitters have been turned off. The reason they have been turned off—they are still being maintained, I am very thankful to say—is to save $1.6 million a year. In order to save $1.6 million a year we are making sure that we do not get Australia's voice out to Asia on short wave, which, by the way, is not a dying technology. Its use is increasing, particularly around this region.

To save $1.6 million a year we have cut off Australia's voice to that part of the world. We have cut off Australia's voice into Asia. Even though we are saying that we want to have more of an impact in Asia and that we want to demonstrate to Asia that we are their friends, we have made sure that the people in Asia cannot hear us. It is an absolutely outrageous and ridiculous situation. The situation the ABC finds itself in overall is outrageous and ridiculous. I would really like to see the government put back that money. If it has any sense it would. It could start with the $1.6 million. I would also like to hear the opposition say that when they get back into government they will put back that money as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN MACDONALD
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am absolutely dumbfounded that Senator Schacht should compound his embarrassment by moving to take note of this answer, but I thank him for doing that. I do not want to miss the opportunity—and I know a lot of my colleagues do not want to miss the opportunity—of helping Senator Schacht understand the issue.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Alston has quite clearly and explicitly mentioned, the whole issue is a complete beat‐up. There has been no cutback in weather reports, forecasts and warnings on the ABC. The ABC in Sydney is doing exactly what the ABC in every other state does and that is have its news presenters deliver the Bureau of Meteorology forecasts. Senator Schacht's media release is so ludicrous that I find it quite unbelievable.

In his press release, Senator Schacht suggests that `the decision to axe weather reports will clearly disadvantage people living outside metropolitan Australia'. That is absolutely wrong. It will make no difference whatsoever to the weather reports that people living outside the metropolitan areas of Australia will receive. What could have had an impact on the weather reports given to people right around Australia, including Sydney, was the atrocious mess the Labor government left the Bureau of Meteorology in when they left office. Upon coming to office this government received a report from Professor Slatyer entitled Review of the operations of the Bureau Meteorology.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Deputy President knows about that.

—The Deputy President would know about that. Professor Slatyer, an eminent scientist, was roundly critical of the run‐down in the Bureau of Meteorology resources since 1991. One of the paragraphs in his report states:

SPEECH.PARA: In particular, the review found that the effectiveness of the Bureau's basic national observation and climate monitoring networks had deteriorated significantly since 1991 compared with accepted benchmark standards.
One of the recommendations that Professor Slatyer made in the first report was that the basic network should be restored to accepted 1991-92 levels.

Senator Bourne and Senator Schacht might like to comment on the fact that the Labor government ran down the effectiveness of the Bureau of Meteorology—the people who really do give the weather reports to rural and regional as well as metropolitan Australia. They just simply let it run down. They did not provide it with the proper staffing, with the proper equipment, to provide the necessary service. Rather than Senator Schacht complaining about what the ABC might like to do—that is, the ABC in Sydney doing simply what the ABC everywhere else does—he should get his facts in order. He should address the real problem: the Labor Party's criminal neglect of the Bureau of Meteorology during their term in office.

Senator Alston has quite comprehensively destroyed any credibility Senator Schacht might have had in relation to the ABC and this particular issue. I call upon Senator Schacht to address the real problems of getting weather forecasts out. Rather than suggesting that the minister had banned the weather, he should look at the effects of his government—a government in which he was, for a short time, a minister—and the way that his government impeded the Bureau of Meteorology in their tasks and duties of providing good and accurate weather forecasts and services to all Australia. Senator Schacht's stupidity in this press release perhaps equals the stupidity of his government—the government of which he was a member—in running down the excellent work that the Bureau of Meteorology did.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam Deputy President: referring to the stupidity of Senator Schacht is really quite out of order. I ask that it be withdrawn.
—I did not hear the comment, but I am advised of it. Would you like to withdraw the comment, please?
—I am sorry?
—Would you like to withdraw your comments about stupidity, please? Unconditionally. Just withdraw, thank you.
—I do not know—

—Madam Deputy President, on a point of order: I do not think Senator Ian Macdonald should have to withdraw the word `stupidity' in relation to the previous government's actions on cutting the resources of the Bureau of Meteorology. There is no doubt that Professor Slatyer has said in that report that it was dangerous and that it put lives at risk. It is clearly an act of stupidity. He may have to withdraw in relation to Senator Schacht, but not in relation to the stupidity of the previous government. It has been proven in a report that—
—Sit down. You are abusing the system.

—I am not abusing it. I am making it quite clear that he should not have to withdraw the word `stupidity' in relation to the actions of the previous government. When you slashed the resources of the Bureau of Meteorology and put people's lives at risk—as you know, Madam Deputy President, because I have heard you speak on it—
—Order!

—particularly in Western New South Wales—you stood up, Madam Deputy President, and made a very important speech on this matter—you should not require Senator Ian Macdonald to withdraw that. It was a stupid government and a stupid act of that government.
—Order! Senator Campbell, would you please resume your seat? Senator Ian Macdonald, you were reflecting upon an individual and that is why I am asking you to withdraw the word, please.
—Madam Deputy President, it is not worth making an issue over. If you want me to withdraw, I will.
—Withdraw it!
—His approach to it was quite stupid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise also to speak to this motion. I have noted with interest through the course of this taking note the elaborate lengths to which the government representatives have gone to try to deflect the substance of the issue—the cuts to the ABC and the resultant decisions of the ABC to deal with those cuts in the most sensible way that they see fit.

—Madam Deputy President, on a point of order: this is a taking note of a question asked by Senator Heffernan in relation to cutting the weather and axing the weather. That is what Senator Alston's response was about. We are talking about cuts to the weather. Senator Ian Macdonald has actually approached the issue because he talked about the cuts to the weather expenditure by the previous government and the increases in spending on weather prediction under this government. I ask you to draw Senator Lundy's attention to the relevance of this debate. You must address the matter of cuts to the weather. It has got nothing to do with the ABC.

—Madam Deputy President, on a point of order: the point of order is obviously spurious. This is an argument that senators have put around the chamber on the question of who is responsible for the actions taken by ABC management. The minister has claimed it is entirely their fault; the Labor Party maintains that this is a direct result of government actions.
—Order! There is no point of order. This is a wide‐ranging debate and it did include discussions about the ABC by the minister.

—That just vindicates the position I earlier stated. What we are talking about here are the cuts to the ABC and how they are being effected on the Australian community. There is no doubt in the minds of Australians what this government has done to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. The manifestation of that $55 million cut this year and the cuts previously has been a significant reduction in the services that reach Australia. The cuts do not only affect Australia. We have already heard from Senator Bourne that we are talking about how Australia communicates with the rest of the world.

SPEECH.PARA: We have here a systematic deflection from the substance of this issue. Yes, Minister Alston, let us talk about the politics of it. Let us talk about the restrictions on drama productions by the ABC. Let us talk about the forced consolidation of services, not only in regional Australia but in metropolitan Australia as well. Let us talk about the cuts to Radio Australia and the closing down of the relay points in other places in the world. Let us talk about the programs that would have been, had that funding to the ABC been maintained. What we see here is the end result of cuts.

I want to take up the point about funding of the ABC and where the ABC would have gone if real funding had been maintained—as this government promised not only in the election but prior to previous budgets as well. They stood up in this place and the other place and gave a 100 per cent commitment to maintain ABC funding.

That has all gone out the window. What we have today is quite a pitiful attempt, Senator Campbell, at ridiculing a political statement that focused on the result of the cuts to the ABC and how that has equated to limiting services to regional Australia. That is what we are here to talk about today. That is the politics of the issue.
Senator Campbell interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Campbell. Senator Lundy, you might like to address your remarks through the chair.
—Perhaps Senator Campbell would like to stop contributing to the ridiculous and petty attempt by government senators to try to stop us making our point about the result of the cuts to the ABC.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Ian Macdonald interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps Senator Macdonald needs to understand that he is contributing to our argument by making the point continuously that, in this case, we are talking about the impact upon weather services.

SPEECH.PARA: In closing, I would like to make a point about ministerial accountability. How come it suits this government to stand up and say, `It's not our fault that the cuts are in this area. We just cut the funding. It's the ABC management that have made the cut in this area,' and Senator Alston stood up here and said that himself? We have had other examples of this government doing exactly the same thing—cutting significant chunks of funding out of public institutions and then standing up in this place and saying, `Oh, it wasn't our fault they've had to cut that end of the service. It's the fault of the management of that particular institution.'

We have a very fine example of this in the ACT itself. The closure of the High Court on weekends is a classic example of the government cutting the overall budget of an institution and the institution having to make some very hard decisions about how it was going to survive and cope with the magnitude of those cuts. We are also talking about ministerial accountability and the responsibility that Senator Alston has to stand up here and take the wrap for the cuts that have occurred in all of the services—not just the ABC but everywhere else.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the first things that Senator Lundy will learn following her elevation to the frontbench is that the last person you would want to come in here and try to defend is Senator Schacht. I would have to say that Senator Schacht must have drawn the short straw in having to get up and take note of the answer that was given during question time today by Senator Alston. Senator Schacht was absolutely slaughtered by Senator Alston's response in which the minister referred to Senator Schacht's media release. The one thing that Senator Schacht, Senator Lundy and Senator Bourne would not refer to is the media release of Senator Schacht in which he talks about `everywhere you go, you will have to take the weather with you'.

SPEECH.PARA: The cutting of the weather is yet another chapter in the sad story of ABC cuts. How wrong can you get it? All Senator Schacht does is sit there and talk about a slick Melbourne lawyer defence. I can tell you, I would rather have a slick Melbourne lawyer defence. It is far better than a failed Labor minister and trade union official defence, I can tell you.

Senator Schacht drew the short straw. I happen to live outside the metropolitan area and weather reports are very important. If weather reports were going to be cut, the first place you would get a response from would be those people in the bush who rely entirely on the weather reports for planning ahead for what they need to know and what they need to do in their day-to-day work. I do not care who gives the weather report. I could not care less whether it is a special weather presenter or whether it is the principal newsreader.

The only thing that really matters to people outside the metropolitan area who listen on a daily basis to weather reports—and the only reason they listen to them—is finding out with some reasonable accuracy what the weather will be. Under this government, they are going to find out with even more accuracy what the weather is going to be because a new $40 million computer has just been installed in Melbourne which gives much more accurate five day forecasts. This money has been spent, so they will get more accurate weather reports.
I am amazed by the press release of Senator Schacht's. I am amazed, Senator Lundy, that you would stand up to try to defend Senator Schacht. In his press release, Senator Schacht said:
The other sad aspect of the Minister banning the weather is the loss of the familiar face reading the weather reports.
The really sad aspect is that you are not going to see a familiar face reading the weather reports. Who would care who was reading it as long as you get the results? The press release continues:
The ABC localises all of its weather reports, often showing photographs sent in by people from around the state and creating a sense of community.
I think the next sentence of this media release really tops it all off. Senator Schacht says:

BREAK.PARA: Senator Alston now goes down in history as the only Minister to have banned the weather.
I reckon that is a feat in itself—to ban the weather. From now on there will be no weather, Minister, because you have banned it. I am so sorry to hear it.

The real truth of the matter is that Senator Schacht drew the short straw. It was his turn to take note of answers and no other answers were thought worthy of taking note of. Senator Schacht, having just been slaughtered by Senator Alston, got up to try to restate his case. In doing so he talked about cuts to the ABC and not his press release, and his press release was the very issue that Senator Alston raised in his answer.

All I can say is that, if Senator Schacht's effort in taking note of answers is the best that you can come up with in trying to be critical of answers that are given by this government, I would suggest that in future you have a little round table meeting prior to question time. Senator Lundy, you want to be ready to move up a seat or two because Senator Schacht is surely skating on very thin ice, although, if that is a weather prediction, we do not know if there is going to be any ice. But if we do have some ice, Senator Lundy, you will be next.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —A petition has been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
For permanent protection of old‐growth forests and all other areas of high conservation value, and for the implementation of tree plantation strategies.

This petition from the undersigned respectfully points out that: there is an increasing and urgent demand from the people, to protect all remaining high conservation value forests which support flora and fauna unique to Australia, thus complying with the United Nations Biodiversity Convention to which Australia is a signatory. We have a responsibility to future and present generations, and the necessary reasons, knowledge and technology to act now on the following achievable solutions.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate legislate to:

PARA.TAB: Immediately stop all logging and woodchipping activities in high conservation value native forests;

ensure intergenerational equity by planning for the rights of future generations, and protecting in perpetuity all biologically diverse old‐growth forests, wilderness, rainforests and critical habitats of endangered species;

facilitate rapid transition of the timber industry from harvesting high conservation value native forests, to establishing mixed‐species farm forestry on existing cleared and degraded lands, using non‐toxic methods to protect ecological sustainability;

maximise use of readily‐available plantation timber for industry needs, using appropriate forestry techniques and progressive minimal‐waste processing methods, such as radial sawing, and wherever possible, reuse and recycle wood and paper products;
support incentives for nationwide composting, soil remineralisation, and planting programs of trees and annual fibre crops, inter‐grown with appropriate fruit and nut trees and medicinal plants;

encourage sensitively‐managed, environmental education tourism in appropriate forest areas, with full respect for natural ecosystems, Aboriginal cultural heritage, sacred sites and other sites of significance; and

progressively utilise technological expertise and resources transferred from the military sector, to help implement these tree planting solutions; and to motivate the international community to follow this example.
