INTERJECT.SPEAKER: DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the President has received the following letter from Senator Stott Despoja:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to standing order number 75, I give notice that today I propose to move:
That in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The failure of the government to introduce legislation amending the Privacy Act 1988 to extend the operation of the Privacy Act 1988 to all sectors of the Australian community.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that informal arrangements have been made to allocate specific times to each of the speakers in today's debate. With the concurrence of the Senate, I shall ask the clerks to set the clock accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The failure of the Government to introduce legislation amending the Privacy Act 1988 to extend the operation of the Privacy Act 1988 to all sectors of the Australian community.

I brought the matter of the extension of privacy laws to the privacy sector before the chamber today because the Australian Demo crats are on the record as expressing our concern—indeed our condemnation of this government—that the government has failed to deliver what was an election promise. That is, their promise to extend those very laws to the private sector.

A discussion paper was released by the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) on 12 September 1996 which set out a scheme based on the existing information privacy principles that are in the Privacy Act 1988 and added to this codes of practice and a range of additional provisions which address the particular concerns of the private sector. In essence, this was a proposal for industry codes of practice that were to be supported by the Privacy Commissioner and subjected to statutory backing—essentially, a co‐regulatory approach. This scheme was consistent with schemes being adopted in other parts of the world. I can name the European Union, Hong Kong and New Zealand among those countries which have similar principles and schemes.

But on 21 March this year, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) announced that the Privacy Act 1988 would not be extended to the private sector. The Prime Minister essentially ended Australia's chance at an international best practice privacy scheme. This was another election promise broken. It was an absolute backflip from this government, and one that we have had little justification for, or explanation of, to date.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you mean `little'? There's been none.

—I take on board that interjection. We have had some reference and some excuses, and I will go on to explain those. The reasons for this decision and the relevant information that the Prime Minister used or relied on to make this decision have not been made available. That is very true. What Senator Neal said is correct. We have had little information—indeed, no information—as to why the Prime Minister made this particular decision.
—Rolled by his mates, he was.

—Rolled by his mates, suggests Senator Woodley. As Senator Woodley would note, I am sure, a decision of this importance should not be passed off without some level of explanation. It is a matter of urgency, I believe, and it is one that the parliament cannot ignore.

SPEECH.PARA: Failure to legislate for a national and a consistent privacy scheme applying to all sectors of the Australian community is a short‐sighted disaster for all Australians. By that, I include not only businesses and industries but individual consumers. Our access to new technology and the data flows in our region and across the world will be severely limited by a failure to have adequate privacy regulation. This is quite clearly a matter of Australian jobs and lifestyles.

The G7 industrialised countries and the APEC ministers have identified privacy as an issue which is vital for commercial reasons. So everyone else is identifying this as an important issue; it is just us who are lagging miserably behind. New Zealand, the European Union and a number of other countries in our region have adopted legally enforceable privacy laws. This is serious—the fact that they are doing it and we are not—and it should be reviewed. To date, we have had no willingness from this government to undertake such a review.

Among businesses and their customers, privacy is a particular. It is a primary concern. In fact, Price Waterhouse surveyed 130 large businesses earlier this year and found that 70 per cent favoured, 10 per cent were neutral and 20 per cent opposed the introduction of comprehensive national privacy laws. The survey concluded:
Australian business has identified privacy as a major business risk and they are looking to the Australian government for guidance on how to manage it.
So they have looked to this government for guidance, but certainly none has been forthcoming.

This survey confirmed an earlier survey conducted by the Faculty of Business and Economics at Monash University, which found that businesses recognised the import ance of personal information to their clients and employees. So I asked the government where they got their conclusive evidence that introducing privacy laws would increase compliance costs and regulatory burdens, when this data clearly shows that businesses want privacy regulation. That is the only excuse I have had from this government—that somehow it would lead to increased compliance costs. It is a somewhat dubious argument, and we have yet to see any data that backs it up.

The Privacy Commissioner states that there is significant evidence of unfair information on privacy practices, which creates a real problem for real people in Australia. She receives something like 15,000 complaints per year and a significant number of these are about privacy intrusions in the private sector—that one area that is relatively uncovered. Similar responses came from the telecommunications ombudsman and the South Australian privacy committees. I have a number of examples as to privacy intrusion that are not covered but should be covered by legislation. I note these examples, which have been provided by the Privacy Commissioner.

One example provided was of a woman who gave birth in a hospital and the baby died within a few days. For weeks afterwards, the woman received at her home congratulatory notes from a range of baby product companies which had bought details of new mothers from the hospital. Outrageous!

A second example provided by the commissioner was of a man who found he was having difficulty getting insurance. He eventually found out that he had been mistakenly confused with someone else with the same name who had a record of insurance fraud. It took him a significant period of time to have this confusion sorted out and corrected. No wonder state and territory governments are considering and examining privacy legislation options.

If state and territory governments do introduce privacy schemes, businesses will be required to satisfy requirements which may be different for each state and each territory. A fragmented approach to privacy regulation and protection is likely to increase compliance costs—the very thing the Prime Minister wanted to avoid—and the regulatory burden for many businesses. This is an approach that has been adopted in Canada, where there is a centralised scheme for public agencies and a whole hotchpotch of province laws with varying requirements.

Businesses and consumers have to look to a range of different and sometimes inconsistent regulations. This is exactly what Australian consumers do not deserve. It is something that we want to avoid, and certainly Australian consumers and businesses do not need that kind of fragmented approach.

These measures alone should be enough to encourage the government to reconsider its privacy backflip. The International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights include privacy measures. It is a fundamental principle, a fundamental right, that a person has a right to know what information is held about them and, if that information is lawfully held, that the information is correct. So privacy is a human rights issue, and the government should deal with this issue appropriately by introducing a suitable legislative scheme to comply with Australia's international obligations.

So on Monday in this place, I tabled an exposure draft that looked to some possible options for extending privacy laws to the private sector in Australia. Essentially, it was for the purpose of community consultation and, given that privacy is such a complex matter, we would benefit as a parliament from a range of different viewpoints and a range of community input into various beliefs and ideas of different consumer and representative organisations. I suggest that a Senate committee might be an appropriate way of canvassing the broader perspectives in this debate and also a way of seeking a good basis for legislative reform. So I hope the government will perhaps consider taking up this option as a way of addressing the privacy backflip that it was responsible for earlier this year.

Last week, the Privacy Commissioner released a document that sought the views of the Australian community for a privacy scheme based on voluntary participation and self-regulation. This is a commendable response to what the Privacy Commissioner herself has described as a broad consensus that there is an urgent need for a national consistent framework for the protection of information privacy. Her framework is a best attempt to cover up the privacy vacuum that has been left by this government, but it does fall very short of the kinds of schemes Australians were promised—promised by the current government—at the last election. This is supported by a range of consumer and other groups which have boycotted this consultation because of its self-regulation and its voluntary nature.

So I recognise these concerns, particularly among those consumer groups, and reiterate that a voluntary and self-regulatory scheme is insufficient. If I have time today, I will refer to some of the information I have had from consumer groups, including Privacy International, which has sent an open letter to the Prime Minister outlining their international concerns.

The need for privacy is also being driven by technological development. Storing and exchanging information on electronic devices is much easier, and the applications are dependent on that personal information. So, to embrace the new technologies and the new commercial possibilities, consumers and businesses need to be sure that personal information is safe. So technology is one reason that these laws, more so than ever, are imperative.
I believe our community wants this legislation: consumers, individuals, businesses. I am glad of the opportunity to bring this matter before the Senate today. I only hope the government acts on it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion before us is not so much a product of the alleged urgency of the matter, rather a product of what some of us on this side and in the media have been observing as the divisive machinations within the Australian Democrats. We all know how Senator Stott Despoja was sacked from the employment portfolio—by fax by her leader—and she has been frozen out from being able to ask questions. Now it would appear that, as a sop to her, they have allowed her to move an urgency motion.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Apart from the offensive and patronising nature of the remarks, my point of order goes to relevance.
—It is straining the interpretation of a point of order, Senator Murray. I have to say that there is no point of order. Senator Abetz, could you please direct yourself to the urgency motion.

—Absolutely, Madam Acting Deputy President. It was a matter of urgency for the Australian Democrats to give something to Senator Stott Despoja to do in this chamber that is the result of this motion being before us. It is not the result of the community having some degree of urgent feeling about this matter—important though it be.

SPEECH.PARA: One would have thought that, if Senator Stott Despoja had the right to choose the topic for today, she may have chosen one of those really urgent matters that are facing the community today—those matters that this government is addressing to fix up after 13 years of Labor failure. How about employment? How about the national debt? How about some of the real issues confronting this nation? Instead, we have a motion dealing with the Privacy Act 1988. It has been around for nine years, and all of a sudden it is urgent that it be amended.

Madam Acting Deputy President, if we are talking about straining the standing orders, I think we should look at standing order 75. I have to say to you that it really does seem to strain the credibility of the standing orders and the processes of this parliament for Senator Stott Despoja to get up and say that somehow this is a matter of urgency. The matter of privacy is an important issue within this community, and we in the Liberal and National parties have a great record on that issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —You had a good record. It is falling apart at the moment.

—Which parties were the ones that stood up against your Australia Card, Senator Neal? We on this side blocked that, and we did so unreservedly and unashamedly because we believe in fundamental privacy principles. So I am very interested, Senator Neal, that you are on the speakers list to make a contribution. You might like to explain to the Australian people about your fundamental commitment to privacy and how that somehow marries in and dovetails with the Australia card proposal of the Australian Labor Party.

BREAK.PARA: The Australia Card was an outrageous proposal, but it was indicative of the fact that you somehow believe that every individual in the community ought to submit themselves to Big Brother. We on this side do not believe in that. That is why we, as a matter of privacy for the individual, fought so hard against the Australia Card. The community recognises that, and we are seen on this side of the chamber as the champions of the individual and their individual privacy.

The principles of privacy are set out in section 14 of the Privacy Act, and they are good and important principles. The legislation that is currently on the statute book in this country was developed over a considerable period of time. Sure, we can look at amendments; we can look at refining it; we can see about making amendments and changes to it, but to trot into this parliament today and somehow say that this is a matter of urgency—when there are so many people unemployed in this country and when we are facing a huge debt—really defies belief.

One wonders what Senator Stott Despoja and the Democrats did during the break we had in this parliament. I have to say that, when I went door knocking and when I went to community groups, not a single person raised with me the issue of privacy—let alone that somehow it was a matter of such national urgency and importance that it ought be debated within the first three days of us resuming.

The government has not been quiet on this very important issue of privacy. Indeed, the Attorney-General's Department released a discussion paper in September. Responses to that discussion paper provided the government with very clear guidance as to the real concerns of business and industry and individuals on possible government approaches to privacy protection. What you have to understand is that, if you put another web of red tape over the top of business and industry, it will cost jobs; it will make them less competitive. We as a government also went to the election promising to reduce the red tape. So we had two competing principles. It is not so very simple.

That is what I find so very frustrating about the Australian Democrats—they always come into this place with a simplistic answer. One day they will talk to you about cutting red tape for small business as a matter or urgency; the next day they will say, `You have got to bring in privacy legislation.' The fact that those two concepts might conflict and require some sound judgment absolutely defies the

Democrats. They can never grasp that some of the problems and difficulties that we as a government have to deal with are multi‐pronged. As a result we as a government are looking through the privacy issue in a mature and considered manner—concepts which are completely foreign and not understandable by the Australian Democrats and the Labor Party.

On 15 August, the Privacy Commissioner released a consultation paper proposing the development of national standards. To the listeners out there: that was only 12 days ago. This issue is currently under consideration and being developed by the Attorney‐General's Department and the Privacy Commissioner. We are looking and working through those issues. The issue, therefore, really is for the Democrats to come before us and say that the privacy issue is of such fundamental importance that somehow it ought to take top rung on the ladder of priorities facing this nation. I have to say to you, it is an important issue; it is a concept that all of us grapple with. All of us have our own particular ideas and views. But you can hardly come into this chamber and pretend, with any degree of credibility, that it is a matter of urgency that is above some of the other issues that I have mentioned in this debate.

There are many issues and concerns within the community about privacy. That is clear. They are issues that need to be addressed. But, after 13 years of Labor, this government has had to set certain priorities in relation to turning the ship of state around to a proper course. It is a question of what we as a government consider to be the vital issues. I have got to say to you—and I am not sure that the Australian Democrats really agree with our approach to balancing the budget, of trying to reduce the national debt—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are going to have a surplus. Don't you read the newspapers?
—Senator Neal, are you suggesting that you had a surplus?
—You are going to have a surplus within two years, as we predicted.

—Senator Neal, thank you very much. Put it on the public record. She has agreed now that after the first three years of the Liberal government there will be a surplus in the budget. The Australian people out there will say, `Good on you, you have got your priorities right, you have looked at the big issues and you are going to ensure that the economy is going to grow, so that many of our fellow Australians can be taken off the unemployment list.' That is what is so important.

BREAK.PARA: They will say to us, `Congratulations that you have now fixed up the budget situation and have not allowed yourself to be distracted to the extent of overlooking those important issues, by those other issues such as privacy.' Important though they may be, you can hardly assert with any credibility that there is something urgent about this matter when Australia has been able to operate since 1901—for the past 96 years—without the sort of legislation that Senator Stott‐Despoja is talking about.

TALK.START.PARA: —Changes happen.

—I know changes happen, Senator Stott‐Despoja, and I remember the one that happened in March 1996, in particular, when we won government. That was one of the most important changes that occurred in this country's history and I welcomed it. We are committed to privacy, and we will deal with it, but we will deal with it in due course and not be distracted from the main issues. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say it is always difficult, in the light of Senator Abetz's provocative statements, to stay focused on the issue at hand. But I have to say that I was a bit disappointed, bearing in mind Senator Abetz's usual way of dealing with matters, that he feels unable to deal with the substantive issue at hand today, which is the Privacy Act and its extension to the private sector.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true that the issue of privacy is not a new issue. It has probably been on the agenda since the early 1980s. In fact, when the Labor government was elected in 1983, less than one year later, Lionel Bowen, who was to become the Deputy Prime Minister, made a statement that a privacy act would be enacted. Privacy legislation was enacted in 1986, with subsequent legislation being carried in 1988.

There seems to be a view that what has been done at the moment is adequate and there is not an urgent situation. I have to say that I disagree with that proposition because circumstances have changed very markedly in the short period since the election of this government. The Prime Minister, John Howard, at the time he was seeking election, made a very clear statement to the Australian people that he intended to put in place privacy legislation that extended to the private sector.

But that, as we know, is not what took place. What happened was that Daryl Williams, the Attorney‐General, was asked to produce a discussion paper. This discussion paper, released in September 1996, was very well received. Probably most of you have had an opportunity to have a look at it. Not only was it very well received by consumers and individuals, but contrary to the Prime Minister's view, or his apparent view, it was extraordinarily well received by the business community as well.

BREAK.PARA: I was optimistic that, after the discussion paper's release and its reception, this government would go ahead and introduce that legislation. Of course, that is not what occurred. In a blatant breach of his promise, the Prime Minister in March 1997 said:
The Commonwealth opposes such proposals which will further increase compliance costs for all Australian businesses, large and small.

His response, in fact, was to ask the Privacy Commissioner at HREOC, with its reduced financial resources, to prepare a consultation paper on information practices in the private sector in lieu of legislative extension of the Privacy Act to the private sector.

At the time that discussion paper was being proposed, the Labor Party held its peace, because we were wanting to see the protections in place and thought that we would give it a go; that we would see what the discussion paper proposed before we made a judgment. One should always be optimistic in this situation.

Despite a lot of fine work done by the Privacy Commissioner—a lot of the information contained in that discussion paper is extraordinarily useful—it is our view that it is not an adequate response or adequate alternative to having a legislative base for an extension to the private sector.

That is not only my view. The community at large was very much of the view that it was not an adequate response. It is not some consumer groups that have refused to discuss the report with the Privacy Commissioner: a total of 15 consumer groups have said that they do not intend to liaise further with the Privacy Commissioner to progress this discussion paper.
Mr Puplick, an ex‐coalition senator, said—and I will quote some of the key portions of his statements:
The scheme outlined in Miss Scollay's consultation paper was a minimal proposition that would not be regarded by anybody as sufficient and would encourage the states to go further.
I will quote further, as he obviously felt quite passionate about this issue:

The sort of knee‐jerk reaction that says, `We can't have privacy legislation because it is an imposition on business' in fact is going to end up costing Australian business and causing a great deal of confusion about data exchange with the European Union.
The control of private information and privacy protections is a major part of setting in place a framework for the expansion of the information technology and data processing economy in Australia.

Certain things have happened internationally over the last two years that mean that, if Australia does not legislate to protect our privacy, we will be falling behind in international trade and international economy. Both Hong Kong and the European Parliament have passed legislation that data, and particularly personal information, should not be provided to those countries that do not have sufficient protections in place .

It is my view that the proposals set out here in the discussion paper by HREOC at the behest of the Prime Minister are not adequate to meet those guidelines. This government's failure to take action in terms of privacy ensures that Australia is excluded from the fastest growing industry in the world. That is not an overstatement of the circumstances.

Contained in the Attorney‐General's discussion paper are some comparisons and exam ples of other jurisdictions that have put these sorts of protections in place. I was interested to see that in the Canadian example many businesses that had initially thought that there would be great impositions had found at the end that the costs were minimal and that they had made substantial gains in consumer confidence by putting in place those protections of personal information.

There is an urgency at the moment. The private sector must be included within the bounds of the Privacy Act. That is imperative because of the increasing and rapid change in information technology and the transfer of personal information. It is urgent because, if we do not take the steps in Australia to put these protections in place, then we will be excluded from a major industry that will provide jobs to Australians. Having these protections in place will mean that in the future Australia will be a better place and have an industry that it would otherwise not have had.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Privacy is a major issue in our society. The Privacy Act was put in place as part of a recognition of the international standards in relation to preservation of privacy. Privacy has become an urgent issue with the decision to outsource various aspects of government activity. A major area of outsourcing is collection, analysis, organisation, storage, retrieval and maintenance of information. It is something people can do outside of government departments, and information technology is a major target of government outsourcing.

SPEECH.PARA: In part, this issue has arisen through application of the principles of competition policy. This policy demands that services provided by government be open to competition or at least to bidding by the private sector. But the real agenda of this government is to divest government of all the functions it can, on an ideological assumption that the private sector can do it better, more cheaply and make a profit.

Outsourcing information technology has been done through opening bidding, generally without really allowing or considering in‐house bidding. Government does not want to know whether existing departments can actually do a job more cheaply and with better reliability. It wants to outsource to big business.

Ask the Australian information technology industry about the tenders. They are designed so that only a couple of major transnational companies—like IBM—will effectively fit the tendering profile, if reports from the IT industry are to be believed. But there are no effective provisions that require private sector IT operators to maintain privacy, and there is no regime in place to monitor whether or not they are doing this.

In government bureaucracies there have been cases where examination of personal information for private purposes has been picked up and prosecuted. With the private sector, however, we are potentially talking about people who set themselves up as effi cient because they are information‐processing experts. They will be very possibly working for several public and private clients, they will be minimising cost and this will probably include having minimal supervision regarding privacy, unless it is required. Remember, this is a competitive world; if it is not required, it will be cheaper not to provide it.

More of a worry: one of the cheapest and most common means of dealing with information input is to send it to India for input. Indian computer subcontractors work for huge numbers of public and private organisations. So in a competitive situation like that without regulatory legislation, where is the guarantee of privacy? It is time to look at the social impacts of competition policy before it is too late. I also urge senators to support a Senate inquiry into the social impacts of competition policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —For weeks and weeks now, government senators have been urging the Democrats—Senator Kernot in particular—to give the kid a go, to let Senator Stott Despoja make a contribution in this chamber. Today she has been given full rein in proposing this urgency motion. We can all now well see why Senator Kernot has been keeping her on a tight leash. It is not, as some might suggest, because Senator Kernot sees Senator Stott Despoja as a threat to her leadership of the Democrats. On the contrary, what we have seen today in this contribution from Senator Stott Despoja is that the Democrats and Senator Kernot quite justifiably feared that she would make a fool of herself and, indeed, a fool of the Democrats. Senator Stott Despoja has indeed made a fool of herself and of the Democrats by proposing as a matter of urgency—

—On a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President, if the senator is not out of bounds on the basis of relevance, could you at least suggest that he refrains from the patronising and insulting language that he is directing my way?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Stott Despoja, in this case I think Senator Chapman's language is out of order. To describe you in the way that he has, I believe, is outside the standing orders. Senator Chapman, I ask you to withdraw those comments and proceed according to the debate under question.
—Which particular comments are you referring to, Madam Acting Deputy President? I was referring to this particular issue which is before us today.
—To describe Senator Stott Despoja as making a fool of herself is what I am referring to, if you would care to withdraw those words.

—I withdraw those particular words, but I will say that proposing this particular matter as a matter of urgency clearly makes a fool of the Democrats. I quote the matter of urgency, as it is claimed to be:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the government to introduce legislation amending the Privacy Act 1988 to extend the operation of the Privacy Act 1988 to all sectors of the Australian community.

Very clearly, this is not a matter of urgency and it is quite ridiculous to suggest that it is. Bringing on this matter by the Democrats shows two things. Firstly, it in fact shows what a terrifically good job the Howard government is doing in dealing with major issues of concern to the Australian people, issues like inflation, interest rates and creating a sound climate for business activity, solving all of those problems for which we were elected. It shows that the Howard government is doing a successful job with regard to all those issues. As a result of that, the Democrats have to resort to desperately attempting to beat up a non‐issue into an issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —An urgency motion!

—It should be described as `a non‐urgency motion', Senator O'Chee. Secondly, this motion also clearly shows just how bereft the Democrats are of worthwhile ideas. There is no urgency in this matter. The government has made a well‐considered decision that an extension of the Privacy Act to the private sector is not necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Stott Despoja interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —While Senator Stott Despoja and her Democrat colleagues might disagree with that decision, it is an abuse of process and a waste of the Senate's time to raise an issue of this sort for debate today.

SPEECH.PARA: This issue, as raised by the Democrats, makes a complete fool of them by proposing quite unnecessary extensions of privacy legislation, which quite appropriately currently applies to the public sector, to the private sector. For years we have seen the Democrats parading themselves around the community as the friends of small business. This motion today clearly shows that that is nothing more than a camouflage. When the Democrats perceive a problem, whether real or imaginary, they inevitably resort to legislation as the solution. They completely ignore the regulatory and compliance cost burdens that such legislation imposes on business, including small business.

This Democrat failing is demonstrated par excellence in this so‐called urgency motion. Unlike the Democrats, the Howard government is genuinely committed to assisting small business. It is quite inappropriate, as Senator Stott Despoja proposes, to be adding yet another layer of regulation with associated compliance costs on business.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you want a GST for?

—Listen to Senator Cook, `Why do we want a GST?' That is a matter yet to be determined Senator Cook. Can I remind you of the compliance costs we currently have with the wholesale sales tax burden? Just get your little mind around that for a few minutes and talk about compliance.
—You want a GST—admit it; be honest.

—Enough of your nonsense, Senator Cook. As I said, we are genuinely committed to assisting small business and we do not want further layers of regulation. As a government we certainly recognise the importance of personal freedoms, which include an individual's right to privacy. That is why this issue—an extension of the Privacy Act to the private sector—has been fully explored by the government.
—It hasn't.
—It has, Senator Stott Despoja. You should just examine and understand the facts. Again, it shows why you have been kept on the tight leash by Senator Kernot for so long.

SPEECH.PARA: There is absolutely no evidence of the need for an extension of the Privacy Act to the private sector at this time. Nevertheless, the government does want to ensure that there is an appropriate Australia‐wide privacy regime. That is why last September a discussion paper was released by the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) outlining the possible approach to privacy protection in the private sector.

Responses to that discussion paper have provided the government with very clear guidance as to the genuine and real concerns of business and industry on the possible government approaches to privacy protection. Those responses clearly indicated that there is no need at this time for a legislative response to those privacy issues.

The government is committed to reducing the regulatory burden on small business. We demonstrated that very clearly when, not long after being elected to government, we established a task force to achieve this very goal. The result of that task force was the so-called Bell report, because that task force was, indeed, chaired by Mr Bell. The recommendations of that report have largely been adopted by the government. As a result of that, we will see a significant reduction in the regulatory burden on small business.

The government's response to privacy issues is quite consistent with that objective. It demonstrates that the government is committed to assisting and encouraging the private sector in developing and abiding by fundamental privacy principles. The government has decided that the Privacy Commissioner will be available to assist business in its endeavours to meet privacy standards and will be available to assist business with the development of voluntary codes of conduct. As a result of that determination by the government, the Privacy Commissioner has initiated a range of meetings with industry and consumer groups as a starting point for developing codes of conduct.

BREAK.PARA: As well, as recently as 15 August, the commissioner released a consultation paper proposing the development of national standards for handling personal information by the private sector. This continues the process which the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) commissioned in March. We believe that the Privacy Commissioner's consultations with the private sector will develop an appropriate framework for privacy protection without unnecessarily increasing compliance and regulatory costs for Australian business.

I conclude by mentioning in response to what Senator Margetts put before this chamber that she has quite clearly confused the issue of the private sector generally with the process of contracting out of previous government services. The government has announced that the privacy legislation will be extended to cover the contracting out of government services, but that is a quite different issue to generally extending a legislative response to the private sector on the whole.

The government is adequately dealing with this issue. I come back to the point that there has been no demonstrated need and no evidence adduced for an extension of the legislation to the private sector. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —I think this is a very good motion. I do think it is a matter of urgency that Senator Stott Despoja has brought forward. If you look at what privacy is about, then you can see the force of this motion. Everyone has an inherent right to keep control of information about them. The access to that information is rightly theirs to determine. That means that there is information that is yours alone. There is information about you that you, as a citizen of this community, should be able to retain control of and which should not be taken out of your possession without your permission. If it is taken out of your control, then you should know about it and have access to it.

SPEECH.PARA: There are issues of privacy, even for small business. A small business can be sent bankrupt by a bank failing to give credit on the basis of information which that small business does not know about. One of the rules of privacy is this: not only should people have the right to maintain information about them which is rightly theirs but, if you are going to have laws which say that people or institutions are allowed to have information about others—or even if you have not got a law and the situation is that people have information about other people—then that should be available to the people about whom that information is held.

A lot of institutions, such as banks, insurance companies and even government itself, say, `Yes, it is all right for us to hold information about you. We can know all that we want to know about you, but you can't get information about us.' The great test of that, of course, is the estimates committees. We go along on behalf of the people of Australia to get information about government and they say, `No, you can't have information about what we are doing. You can't have our legal opinion. You can't have information about why we made this particular decision. But we can hold information about you.' The Health Insurance Commission, the Department of Social Security and the income tax office can hold information about you, but you cannot look at the information that those bodies hold.

This whole motion is talking about those two issues. The first issue is what information should people be able to have about others and what information should people be able to keep control of. The second: if information about a person or people generally is to be made available to all and sundry, then that should be the law for everyone. If it is good enough for information to be made available about private individuals, why isn't it good enough for information to be made available about banks, about taxation offices or about the police force, if you like?

If we are going to say, `It doesn't matter how far the contravention of privacy is spread, we don't need laws to protect privacy,' then what about those laws that—in my view, properly—protect the information that law enforcement authorities hold? If it is good enough to have laws to protect that, why isn't it good enough to have laws that protect people who are going to be injured by information that is made available about them?

BREAK.PARA: Another issue to raise in this regard is what information people should be able to obtain from you. I think this is also a matter of urgency because there are calls at the moment to get rid of the right to silence. People are saying that people should not be able to withhold information about themselves if law enforcement authorities, for example, should be able to obtain information from people if they want to ask them questions. If you are in court and you maintain the right to silence, or if you are being questioned by the appropriate authorities and you maintain the right to silence, then that should be used. That is a very interesting concept. One of the great figures, one of the great humanising figures in history who maintained the right to silence was—

TALK.START.PARA: —St Thomas More.
—And before him Senator O'Chee was Jesus Christ. When Jesus Christ was before Pilate he maintained the right to silence.

BREAK.PARA: Senator McGauran interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great worry that Senator McGauran, for whose piety I have great honour, seems not to know that that was one of the central themes of the trial of Jesus Christ. You should have a look at that. I refer you, Senator McGauran, to the gospel of Mark 15:1‐6. If you read that you will see the importance of the right to silence.

BREAK.PARA: As Senator McGauran is one of the most eminent backbenchers in the government parties his reaction worries me because I think it indicates an attitude within the government. I think Senator Stott Despoja's case has been made out because they are ignorant of one of the great issues in history and ignorant of one of the great issues of the moment which is the ability to keep private and keep to yourself what is properly yours. That apparently does not resonate on the benches of the government because they laugh at, in my view, the greatest figure in history. Senator McGauran obviously does not consider that to be so. I digress.

The issue of privacy is fundamental and one that needs to have the force of law behind it to make it effective. The government talks about the right to privacy, but there is a refusal to bring in laws to back that up in the private sector. It says that the private sector does not want that. I would be very surprised if that were the case. I would have thought that the private sector would be interested to know what those big financial institutions do with the information they have about those small businesses, but, in any event, the government says it is not.

I put the proposition to the Senate that there are laws giving people enforceable rights to life and limb. If a person attempts to kill you or attempts to maim you there are laws to protect you. There are laws to protect your securities and shares in companies. There are laws to protect your land and chattels. There are laws to protect your intellectual property and your reputation. The government does not say anything about the cost or the terrible burden it places on the community having law enforcement authorities, courts and procedures whereby people can manifest these rights.

Why is it that privacy, this inherent right to maintain information about yourself or if information about you is going to be made available that it should be made available about everybody else, should be separated out from other rights? It is all right for the community to bear the expense of protecting other rights but not the right to privacy. I think this is a very important matter. It is a matter that has been delayed too long. Economic rights are important but civil rights are very important too. We have neglected them. I think it is urgent that we get on to them. I congratulate Senator Stott Despoja for bringing this matter before us today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran, Sen Julian

TALK.START.PARA: —The difficulty in following Barney Cooney in a debate—
—With the greatest respect, Senator McGauran, it is Senator Cooney.

—Senator Cooney is ever so eminent and ever so lofty in presenting his points. An old tactic that only Senator Cooney, given his credibility, can get away with is speaking about the issue of privacy as if the other side of the chamber—the government side of the chamber—does not hold up the principles of privacy, has not enshrined the principles of privacy or fought and defended the principles of privacy. I point out our opposition to the Australia Card which Senator Cooney was around for and voted for. Senator Cooney simply concentrated on the lofty matters of privacy and free speech going back some 2,000 years. I am always happy for Senator Cooney to refer me to passages in the Bible . I can always do with that sort of advice.

SPEECH.PARA: To dress up this whole issue brought to us by Senator Stott Despoja in nothing more than the principle of privacy, free speech, the right to silence is to really distort the facts. Those opposite make out that this government is doing nothing about it. It is moving on the matter. It is moving, but not the way Senator Stott Despoja wants us to. We are the government. Do you think we are going to move the way the Democrats suggest? I cannot think of one time that we ever moved with the Democrats. They have quite often moved with us. I cannot think of a time when we would say, `Yes, Senator Stott Despoja you are right.' The whole bench across there has never come up with a bright or right idea.

Senator Cooney, I am going to go back to the Bible and refer to those passages. But do not try to tell this government that we do not enshrine the principle of privacy. Quite frankly, I think both sides of the parliament do—they just have a different way of going about it. A good try, nevertheless.

A lot was made of the discussion paper that was brought out by the Attorney‐General's Department on 12 September 1996—as if it were government policy. That is like saying the Industry Commission report brought down on the car industry was government policy. In that report they recommended no further tariff cuts. The government did not take up that recommendation by the Industry Commission. It was just one source fed into cabinet's decision making process. So, too, was this discussion paper by the Attorney‐General's Department. Cabinet made a decision on 17 March. I will read it out for you, Senator Stott Despoja. Cabinet agreed:

BREAK.PARA: (a) no Commonwealth legislation would be developed at this stage;
(b) the Privacy Commissioner would be available to assist business in its endeavours to meet privacy standards, including assistance in the development of voluntary codes of conduct; and

(c) the Prime Minister propose to Premiers and Chief Ministers that, in recognition of the added costs to business that would result from piecemeal State and Territory legislation, the States and Territories not enact their own privacy legislation as it affects the private sector.

So we too are looking for a national code of conduct, contrary to what some of the previous speakers said. I endorse what the previous speakers on this side said when they talked about this being a waste of time.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the insults?

—I will not deliver the insults—you can refer to the Hansard . This is far from an urgency motion. Quite frankly, before I got up it had pretty well run out of puff. You can be very thankful Senator Cooney put some spice into the whole debate. I really think that, as far as urgency motions go, this is one that has really run out of puff. It does not warrant the title of urgency motion. Nevertheless, in the brief time we are given I will attempt to address the matters before us.

BREAK.PARA: It is worthy of note that, following that cabinet decision, the Privacy Commissioner initiated a range of meetings with industry and consumer groups as a starting point for developing a code of conduct. I heard Senator Stott Despoja say some of those consumer groups are black‐banning these meetings. They may well black‐ban them, but the more significant ones are turning up. By the way, you never named the ones that were black‐banning them. I would find that an interesting list indeed.

On 15 March, the Privacy Commissioner released a consultation paper proposing national standards for the handling of personal information by the private sector. This continues the process commissioned by the government in March. The government is very confident that the Privacy Commissioner's consultations with the private sector, which are well under way, will develop an appropriate regulatory framework for privacy protection in the private sector without unnecessarily increasing the compliance cost to Australian business. Isn't that important? This government is committed to reducing the regulatory burden on business. It is against this backdrop that our response to privacy concerns has been developed.

I would have thought that, after 18 months of seeing this government operate, that would be a pretty clearly understood principle for the Australian Democrats. It was mentioned by Senator Neal and Senator Stott Despoja in regard to outsourcing. It is an important matter, it is a serious concern—and we have picked up that serious public concern.

So those privacy concerns, Senator Stott Despoja—if you care to listen—are being taken up in regard to outsourcing. When Labor was in government they promoted outsourcing in the Public Service for five years, but they never once introduced—(Time expired)
