DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Visit by the Prime Minister to the United Kingdom and the United States of America

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a statement on his overseas visit to the United Kingdom and the United States, and to move a motion in relation to the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—
The United Kingdom and the United States are two of Australia's strongest and most important political and economic partners.
Our relationships with both countries are founded in our shared histories and traditions, our common values and aspirations and the strong personal links between our societies.

One of the principal messages of my visit was that my government intended to build on this shared history and shared values in looking ahead and creating modern and dynamic partnerships which meet Australia's contemporary needs and interests.

The United States is the largest investor in Australia, and the United Kingdom the second largest. The United Kingdom invests more in manufacturing in Australia than any other foreign investor and so is a very important source of employment in this country.

It is not a one‐way street either. Australia is rivalling France and Germany for third place amongst foreign investors in Britain. Australian investment in the United States is 40 per cent of the United States' investment in Australia—a very large figure when you consider the difference in the size of our economies.

We have substantial trading relationships with both countries. Our alliance with the United States is vital to Australia's stability and the security of our region. We have close and valuable defence ties with the United Kingdom.

It was therefore timely to visit the United Kingdom early in the life of the new government led by Mr Blair. Mr Blair of course is no stranger to Australia. I invited him to visit us again in his new capacity.
I was also pleased to have the opportunity to call on the Queen.

I had a very valuable round of discussions with Mr Blair and leading members of his government, including the deputy prime minister, Chancellor of the Exchequer, defence secretary, foreign secretary and home secretary. I was pleased to find that they share my conviction of the growing strength and relevance of the relationship between Australia and the United Kingdom.

I was struck by how much there is in common between my government and Mr Blair's on the challenges faced by our societies—especially the issues of unemployment and the role of welfare—and the need to address those challenges, not with ideological prescriptions but by looking for practical ways to achieve results. I was particularly interested to hear about the welfare to work proposals of the new government and Mr Blair's views on changing attitudes in modern societies towards welfare and how they married with much of our thinking.

Both with the UK government and in my meetings with leaders of the UK business community, I was able to set out first hand the strength of the Australian economy. The reality is that our economy over 1997 and 1998 is predicted to grow more strongly than any of the G7 economies.

During a visit to the Hawk aircraft assembly line in Warton, I announced the then imminent signature of the contract for the lead‐in fighter for the RAAF—a significant boost for the Newcastle area both in terms of the jobs and the leading edge technology it will bring.

I pointed out in my meetings that Australia's integration into the Asia Pacific region and the United Kingdom's with Europe were making our bilateral links more relevant and valuable—rather than the reverse as some might think. No two countries in their respective regions have closer relationships or a better understanding of each other than Australia and the United Kingdom.

The benefits are becoming more evident in the number of British companies locating their regional headquarters in Australia and using Australians skills and expertise to expand their business in the Asia Pacific region.

Australia and the United Kingdom hold different positions on climate change, which is not surprising given the differences in the structures of our economies. I made clear to Mr Blair and his government that Australia is prepared to play her part in tackling greenhouse gas emissions. But we will not be party to a legally binding uniform target which no‐one honestly expects will be achieved, which is discriminatory in its economic consequences and which does not make an effective contribution to improving the world's environment.

A continuing irritant in our bilateral relations is the UK government's refusal to index pensions for UK residents in Australia. Mr Blair and I agreed that as a first step officials would reach an understanding on the actual costs involved—lack of agreement on this has so far obstructed sensible discussion of the issue.

I also took the opportunity of being in London to maintain my contact with former prime ministers, John Major and Baroness Thatcher, and to meet the new leader of the Conservative Party, William Hague.
During my visit, I was pleased to be able to help facilitate requests for the return of Yagan's skull to Australia and I hope that outstanding issues can be resolved soon.

My visit to the United States was an opportunity to build on the success of President Clinton's visit to Australia last year. I met a very wide range of key figures in President Clinton's administration, Congress and the business community in New York. My meetings left me in doubt about the strength of the US alliance with Australia and the value the United States places on it.

Our shared strategic and economic interests in the Asia Pacific region meant that the future of our region was an important focus of my discussions in Washington and New York. The other was my message that under my government's reform programme the Australian economy was creating new opportunities for US business to use Australia as a base for operations in Asia.

I emphasised the vital importance of continued US engagement in the region. The interests of Australia, the United States and the region are all served by the United States continuing to make a strong contribution to the stability and economic growth of the region.

I was reassured by my discussions with President Clinton and others in his administration of the continuing commitment of the United States to exercising its leadership, economic power and strategic influence to help ensure the region's stability and prosperity into the next century.

It is a tribute to the role Australia plays in the region that President Clinton and members of his administration and Congress want to know what Australia thinks of developments in the region and to discuss ways in which we can extend our cooperation there.
While sharing fundamental objectives, Australia's specific geography and interests means that she has a different perspective on the region from the United States—and that makes our views useful.

In a major speech to the Foreign Policy Association annual dinner, I set out Australia's views on the important changes taking place in the region and how we should respond to them. The opening up and modernising of economies and societies in the region are bringing immense benefits for the countries of the region and their peoples. It is in our interests to reinforce these trends and to encourage the integration of regional economies into the world economy rather than lecture them about their shortcomings.

For example, it is in the interests of Australia, the United States and the region that we maintain broad and balanced relationships with Indonesia within which differences for example on human rights can be handled productively.

The government and the Clinton administration agree on the importance of integrating China into the region. We agree also on the importance of APEC's role in sustaining the growth of regional economies by freeing up trade and investment. We are keen to see APEC's momentum maintained under the Canadian chairmanship at Vancouver.

An active and credible ANZUS alliance is an important part of the contribution we both make to the region. I was pleased to highlight that with an invitation to the Seventh Fleet to visit Australia in the year 2000.

The Australian and US positions on climate change are not the same—but we share a desire for a realistic and equitable outcome of the Kyoto meeting. President Clinton acknowledged the need for flexibility in order to achieve that and we agreed on the need to find a way of involving the developing countries effectively in the process.
I was pleased to hear Dr Greenspan comment on the strong position of the Australian economy.

New York is where perhaps the toughest bottom lines are drawn about economic performances. So I was pleased to see when I visited Salomon Brothers a graph which plotted the differential between Australian and United States Treasury bonds. When my government came to office the margin was about 250 points against Australia. On the day I visited, the margin had dropped to only 60 points. Recently it has dropped to 25 points. This is a measure of the extent to which in the past 17 months we have been able to repair the fundamentals of the economy.

I was interested to hear from the US administration and business their views on how the US economy's impressive rate of job creation has been achieved. While I heard a range of ideas, there was consensus on the importance of labour market flexibility. I came away convinced that sensible reform of the kinds we have undertaken—to achieve greater labour market flexibility, to remove the obstacles to job creation and to address welfare and taxation disincentives against work—is critical if we are to improve employment.

Dr Greenspan also stressed the role that the integration of new information technology into the economy has played in creating jobs in the United States. The government will be announcing steps in this area in the near future.
Finally, I would like to extend my deep appreciation to my hosts in both the United Kingdom and the United States for the warmth of their reception and their generous hospitality.

I believe my visit has helped focus the leadership of both countries on the benefits that our partnership can bring to all of us if firmly oriented towards the future. Together, our partnerships with the United States and the United Kingdom will play an important part in Australia's growth and security.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —In agreeing to take note of this statement, I cannot allow the opportunity to pass to condemn the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) for having failed to attend the Earth Summit in New York, which was attended by some 100 heads of state, including the President of the United States, the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, heads of states from Japan, France, Germany, Russia and right around the world. What happened was that our Prime Minister was sipping tea with Baroness Thatcher and twiddling his fingers in London, as the Lord's cricket match was not on because it rained, while a world conference on the environment and sustainable development was attended by heads of state from almost everywhere else on the planet.

SPEECH.PARA: You would have to ask why John Howard did not represent Australia. Why didn't he do us proud at this prestigious international gathering? The reason is that he is downright ashamed of his government's environmental record. I note the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) is absent, but he would be able to endorse the fact that since John Howard came to office the already destructive process of woodchipping in our native and wild forests in this country has been accelerated. It has been accelerated by the Prime Minister who referred to the last Prime Minister, Mr Keating, with some good reason, as the Prime Minister for woodchipping. What John Howard has done is leapfrog the record of the Keating government and accelerate the destruction of native forests and wildlife in this country at a time when that industry is job shedding.

The Prime Minister is about expanding uranium exports out of this country into the unsafe nuclear industry, which countries like France, Sweden and Great Britain are getting out of, because there are dollars in it. This government would sell off anything and let the devil look after the next generations. Not least amongst some 15 uranium mines on the slate is Jabiluka, where the traditional owners do not want that mine in the heart of this magnificent valley in Kakadu. This government is about to ride across the top of social justice and environmental parameters. Any sane, responsible and caring government would stand against that.

Of course, amongst the other multitude of sins of this government as far as the environment is concerned, and what should be a matter of great shame for John Howard—and ample reason as to why he stayed away from New York—is the abhorrent record his government has in its responsibility for tackling, along with the rest of the world, the greenhouse gas and global warming problem: Australians, per capita, are the worst defaulters on the face of the planet.

This Prime Minister's policies are dictated by the coal industry, by dollars, not the rights of future generations, certainly not the rights of our neighbours living on islands and certainly not the rights of people who right around the world are going to have to grapple with the awesome downside of the neglect by this Prime Minister of his national and global responsibilities.

So what happened? He had tea with Baroness Thatcher and then he flew to Washington, bypassing New York. When he got to Washington he found that President Clinton was not there because President Clinton was spending four days in New York, three hours train ride up the line, with the rest of the world in what turned out to be an unsatisfactory conference but at least an effort to get together to try to tackle the world's environmental and therefore social problems. John Howard sat in Washington having coffee with Newt Gingrich, the extreme right representative of the Republicans, because he felt more at home with that than he did representing this nation at the biggest gathering of heads of government that he is likely to see in this period of office.

It was a failure of responsibility; it was a failure of national leadership; it was a demonstrable failure to represent this nation, to give Australia top level representation at a global conference which mattered. And if John Howard cannot do better than that he ought not to be in that office. If he has not got the vision beyond that narrowness which says `Baroness Thatcher before the world', he does not deserve to be in the prime office of this nation. He is selling out Australians, he is selling out this nation's interests and he is selling out future generations. He is not up to it, and we are seeing this more and more as we go down the line.

This is the Prime Minister who says that the great adventure for Australia, as we go into the next century and the next millennium, is going to be tax reform. As important as that is, it shows the degree of failure of imagination of this Prime Minister—imagination which, if it were firing and if it were up to the representation Australians expect, would have us as a middle order nation taking a lead amongst the community of nations in a planet that, for goodness sake, needs leadership. We did not get it in New York and we are not going to get it during this period in office of the Prime Minister—in office not at the Lodge, but in his residence in Sydney.

I suppose these things creep up on people slowly, but Australians have to recognise that there is a vacancy where we need leadership, that there is a vacancy where we need vision for the next generation coming after us, that there is a failure where we need success as a country that has everything going for it, if we want to take a lead in innovations, bright ideas and solutions as we move into the next century. The Prime Minister cannot even come to grips with that when it comes to such a simple thing as alternative power, solar power. The world is crying out for power alternatives which are going to help fix the global warming problem.

Instead of that, he is subsidising diesel fuel use—greenhouse gas production—to the tune of $800 million a year for the mining corporations alone and cutting $20 million to $25 million out of energy research assistance for solar power. It just shows how wonky his priorities are, how far off‐beam he is, how narrow minded and, I think, self‐centred he is, and how limited his field of view is, when this great nation of ours needs statespersonship, vision, imagination and get‐up‐ and‐go of the wider sense that goes beyond tax reform to the other values that we have to hold high in life if we are going to give fulfilment not only to this generation, but to the people who follow us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, wish to speak to the motion to take note of this ministerial statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) on his trip to the United States and the United Kingdom. When one reads the document that the Prime Minister has used to report on this trip, I think one would have to say that this is a very thin justification for going. There are no matters of great moment contained in this document. It is a travelogue of meeting major Tory celebrities and hobnobbing with them in Britain. The list was: Baroness Thatcher, Mr Hague and John Major. In the United States the stand‐out personality was Newt Gingrich. This was a Tory celebration and a tour by the Australian Prime Minister to get, no doubt, the approbation of his political kin in the United States and the United Kingdom. It did nothing for Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: When he was away, major issues occurred here that he did not attend to. The Newcastle steelworks was closed down and the protests about the jobs for people in that city reached a crescendo. The carcass of the then minister for small business, Mr Prosser, was turning in the wind awaiting finally being put to rest as he was a political neuter, given the clash of his personal interests and his public responsibilities. And that remained unresolved.

The handover of Hong Kong occurred. Our Prime Minister did not appear at that. Of course, as Senator Brown has just alluded to, the greenhouse gas conference was being held in New York at the United Nations. Major countries were represented by their heads of state, by their prime ministers or presidents. Australia was not. Australia was remarkable for that fact; Australia was represented by its Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) and therefore was not able to mix it with the big boys in terms of the argument that it wanted to put. The level of representation sent was seen as an indication of the strength of the arguments Australia wanted to present.

I am not saying, in that sense, that I justify the arguments that the government was wanting to put at that conference, but it downgraded its own ability to be respected by the level of representation it presented when most other nations were represented by their heads of state. The Chancellor of Germany was there, the President of France was there, the President of the United States was there, the Prime Minister of Britain was there; our environment minister was there. Our Prime Minister was at Lord's watching the cricket—or, rather, he wasn't because it rained on the day he went. If that is a signal of prime ministerial responsibility and priority setting, one has to say he has got it miserably wrong.

Indeed, the Prime Minister's trip provided a huge source of levity for the cartoon drawers of Australia: at the Lord's test when it rained, and later when the Prime Minister opened the Ashes exhibition at Lord's and described it as one of the greatest events of his prime ministership—`the greatest occasion of my prime ministership'. The opening of the Ashes museum in London was hardly a significant event for Australia. It was symbolically important for those interested in cricket and sport, but it was not something which changed the national destiny of this country. And then, in New York, Shirley MacLaine fell asleep while the Prime Minister was making his speech. She later apologised for that, but it was an indication of how vibrant and exciting things were on the Prime Minister's international trip.

I want to deal in some detail with two things which the Prime Minister has included in the report of his international trip and which I think should be explained to this parliament. Firstly, he argued in his report—and he argued in the media at the time—that, on meeting Tony Blair, the Labour Prime Minister of Great Britain, their exchange had been useful because he and Blair had a common view about policies on unemployment and welfare.

The Prime Minister used this point to argue that that meant that Labor in Australia was out of date or out of touch. Let me put a few of the facts on the record. The leader of the Labor Party in this national parliament, Mr Beazley, put these facts on the record directly to the Prime Minister in the debate in the other place earlier today.

Essentially, from the day‐long discussions that Kim Beazley had with Tony Blair—as opposed to the short hour or so that the Prime Minister had with him—what was shown to be true was that Tony Blair is a friend of Australia. He is a friend of the Australian Labor Party. He gained inspiration to conduct his campaign in the United Kingdom from what he found in Labor in government in Australia. He is a personal friend of Kim Beazley. The policies that John Howard was referring to were policies drawn by the British Labour Party from our Working Nation statement, and then presented in British style.

What the Prime Minister is praising when he praises those policies is Working Nation—a statement that he condemns in Australia, and a policy which he has dismantled here, thus preventing the opportunity for unemployed people in this nation to gain access to training and jobs, and preventing the improvement of the lot of the long‐term unemployed. It is one thing to praise what the British Labour Party is proposing to do. Its model was Working Nation. That was the model we had in place in Australia, and that is the model that this government has shown respect for by scrapping. That is hardly sincere praise in those circumstances.

The other point I wish to comment on is that the Prime Minister came away from his discussions with President Clinton having suddenly discovered the information industry. He had left Australia several weeks before that, in the closing week of the Senate during which, to the ignominy of information technology, the Senate voted, with a government majority, to scrap the computer bounty.

The computer bounty was one of the things that underpinned the existence of an information technology industry in Australia. But, having scrapped it, the Prime Minister discovered, after having chatted with President Clinton, how important information technology is for the world, and how Australia must catch up—after his having demolished the basis on which information technology development was founded in Australia.

Both these examples show a Prime Minister who in this way confesses that he knew not what he did: he had no policy vision; he was a policy‐free zone when it came to planning the industry, welfare and employment needs of this country in his first and second budgets. In both those budgets the Prime Minister chose to opt for a level of growth for the economy—a GDP growth level—of 3¾per cent. In the first year it was not realised—we got 2.4 not 3¾per cent. In choosing to set the budget at a growth level of 3¾per cent knowing that, to make any impact on unemployment at all in this country, to bring unemployment down, this nation has to have its economy grow at 4½ per cent, he made a positive choice to keep unemployment high and, in fact, for unemployment to grow. That is the inescapable conclusion from the budget settings of budget No. 1 and budget No. 2 of this government. The government chose a level of economic growth in this country which would keep unemployment levels high, and growing.

Despite all the words the government members might say about their concern for unemployment, it is actions that decide sincerity, not words, and the actions were budget settings which will cause unemployment to remain high or to grow. When the Prime Minister talks, as he did in London, about concern for the unemployed and about what he might learn about how to keep them off welfare and get them back into the work force, one has to remember that this is the man who presided over a Treasurer who set budget growth levels below the level at which you can make a dent in unemployment levels.

They were the targets. The actual performance in the budget of last year, as I said, was not 3¾per cent but 2.4 per cent, so the actual outcome of the budget settings undershot the target that the government had set—you would have thought it would have done something to correct that in the second budget, but it did not—and any words we therefore hear from the Prime Minister about how he might tweak the system to make it marginally better, based on what he learnt from new Labour in London, are about moving the deckchairs on the Titanic.

You must first fix the problem by growing this economy at the levels that it is capable of and within the speed limits that it is capable of achieving, at around five per cent or six per cent, and bring down the total level of unemployment. In that way, the issue of what you then do about the long‐term unemployed is the secondary question, because you are reducing the total number of unemployed. In facing that secondary question, the blueprint is the Working Nation statement.

Let me now turn for a minute to the industries of the future. The biggest industry in the world and the fastest growing industry in the world is the information and telecommunications sector. Australia imports something like $6 billion worth of information technology a year. That is the net trade balance. We export some; we import some. The net deficit is about $6 billion.

BREAK.PARA: By the end of this century, the net deficit will be $20 billion, unless we husband this industry in Australia so that we build here the type of technology that we now import and we replace those foreign imports with home-grown products. That would change the trade balance and create challenging, intellectually stimulating, highly skilled, technical jobs for Australia.

That is the program Labor was embarked on and, to help Australian industry achieve that, we had a bounty for computer production. That is, we paid a small amount to encourage this industry to re-establish itself here and make that equipment in Australia. Well, it is a matter of record that, just before the Prime Minister left for his overseas junket, he scrapped that bounty. He cut the ground from under this industry, pushing a number of these companies out of Australia and into new markets. They then had to export into Australia, and that pushed the level of trade deficit up even further.

The Prime Minister cut it out from under this industry without studying the impact and in the face of an Industry Commission report which found in favour of continuing the bounty. I might say that, over the last few weeks, we have heard of workers in the car industry attacking the Industry Commission for removing protection, and we have heard of workers just this week—and we will be moving a motion tomorrow on this subject—in the textiles, clothing and footwear industry attacking the Industry Commission for removing tariff protection from them, and with justifiable reason in my view.

In this particular case, the Industry Commission had found that the bounty should remain. This ultra dry agency had found that the bounty should remain because that was the only way in which it could leave a growth in this industry sector. But the government—against the advice of the most dry economic group—cut that bounty out and then discovered, `God, we've got to do something to create an information technology sector in Australia.'

We now have the Goldsworthy report, but we do not know what the government is going to do about that. Of the Goldsworthy report, let me say that it is a worthwhile try but it is nowhere near the answer to putting Australia on the map as a world power—as it could be—in the growth sector of the future. That is where the jobs will come from in the next century. So we have a Prime Minister who confesses his sins on both those fronts while away.

I have heard what Senator Brown has said with respect to the earth summit in New York. Indeed, it is true that the Prime Minister should have been there, he should have represented Australia and he should have put Australia's views. The fact that he chose not to is a massive slight to the rest of the world and a lack of faith in or commitment to the case Australia has been making internationally.

There is no excuse for the Prime Minister to be at the cricket or sipping tea with Baroness Thatcher when the world was gathered in earnest consideration of the effect of greenhouse emissions on the ozone layer and was trying to cobble together an agreement about that. The fact that Australia was not represented is an enduring slight to the rest of the world.

I want to conclude my remarks about this trip with another point that stands out. We do know this. Prior to the Prime Minister packing his bags for London, his office systematically leaked to Australian reporters, to tease them about how important his mission would be, that he would make a speech in London, the Menzies memorial lecture, and that in that speech he would link the member for Oxley, Pauline Hanson—rightly, I might say, in my view—with the association of the Ku Klux Klan in the United States. He was to make a comparison of her policies and their policies, note the striking similarity between both and note the interdependence that seems to be growing between the Hanson group and those extreme right wing elements in the United States. That was leaked out of the Prime Minister's office to the Australian media, and the Australian media reported it.

So it was that, when the Prime Minister rose to the lectern to deliver the Menzies memorial lecture, we waited to see exactly how he would present this view. The truth is that he did not. He squibbed it. It dropped out of his speech. He did not actually do it.

One wonders what mental processes were in his mind that caused him to make that shift. He had told the world that he was going to do it, and the world was expecting to hear from him about it. He was going to at last provide some leadership on what is, I think, one of the biggest international issues facing Australia now—that is, the fact that we are being characterised as a white racist nation by people who are not friendly to us. They are using the Hanson factor to justify it and, as they often do, are pointing to the Prime Minister of Australia as encouraging the Hanson forces because of his refusal to condemn her out of hand at the very beginning. The Prime Minister then says he is going to do it, and then he does not do it.

What sort of message is that sending to the rest of the world? That is a disgraceful message for the rest of the world. It gives rise again to the belief that this Prime Minister is soft on this sort of view being put in Australia, that he is quite happy to sit back and allow the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Fischer) and the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) to do the hard yards, to make the condemnations that are appropriate and proper—and I support them in what they say—to express the tolerant and multicultural face of Australia to the world and to argue for its importance. But when the time comes for the Prime Minister to stand up and be counted on this issue, despite the fact that he leaks his intention to do so, he does not deliver.

During the recess I visited a number of Asian nations as shadow minister for trade. I might say that the character of a nation is often judged by what the leaders of the nation say, and what the Prime Minister says or does not say on this subject is being treated as indicative of the views of the government and sometimes the views of the nation.

The fact that he said he would perform and did not is taken to be further confirmation that perhaps there is a sneaking regard for Hanson policies in the government. I think the truth is that there is not, but the truth is that there appears to be, at least with the Prime Minister. That is a shocking view to have abroad. But that is the view abroad, and it is one that he has created by his failure to perform on this matter.

Let me conclude as I began. His report to this parliament about what he did in the UK and the United States is a thin travelogue and a Tory tour of the world. It carries with it no lasting statesmanlike effort to place Australia better in the world than it was before he left. It recounts what the investment flows are between Australia and the United Kingdom and how important US and UK investment is to Australia, but that is citing the facts—the facts that were achieved by Labor when it was in government. What this report fails to do is show how the government intends to enhance that or take it further. I think the failing is in this report.

The trip overseas by the Prime Minister has been a damp squib and has not advanced our national interests. It has not advanced our national interests because he was preoccupied with cricket and he failed to perform in the Menzies lecture. He put Shirley MacLaine to sleep in New York. Then there was the unfortunate trip on the way to the rose garden in Washington. These incidents have caught the tone of this venture. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PARA.TAB: This Act provides the necessary framework for the election of delegates to a Constitutional Convention to represent the views of all Australians about possible changes to the Constitution.
The Convention will provide a forum for debate about:
. whether the present Constitution should be changed so that Australia might become a republic with its own Head of State; and
. what republican models should be put to the voters of Australia as elements of the choice between the present system and a new system; and
. the timeframe and the appropriate circumstances for considering change.

If it is to be successful, it is vital that the Constitutional Convention reflects the diverse experiences, backgrounds, views, beliefs and aspirations of the Australian people. In particular, and in light of the fact that the Constitutional Conventions of the 1890s which led to Federation were composed entirely of male delegates, it is to be hoped that all groupings will provide for the fair and equal representation of women.
