PARA.EMPHASIS: House of Representatives reasons for disagreeing to Senate amendments 1 to 8 and 10 to 68—

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Amendment proposes a preamble be included which specifies the role of the Convention and the appointment and election of delegates to the Convention. The House of Representatives does not accept the Amendment, as it does not reflect the purpose and scope of the Bill.

These Amendments focus on the method of voting for half of the delegates to the Constitutional Convention which will meet for 10 days in December 1997 to consider the question of whether or not Australia should become a republic. The Amendments require that voting in the election be by a compulsory attendance ballot, which will make Australians who choose not to vote in the election for delegates liable to prosecution and add up to $20 million to the cost.

The Amendments also propose that the election be conducted along the lines of a Senate election. In light of the large number of candidates which could contest this election (possibly exceeding 200-300 candidates in New South Wales) a pure Senate "style" election would make it difficult for electors to vote for someone other than a group, and would extend the time needed to count the vote.
Accordingly, the House of Representatives opposes these Amendments (Numbers 2-8 and 11-68).

This Amendment provides that candidates' $500 nomination fee should be returned if the candidate is elected or the candidate/candidate group receives at least 4% of the total number of votes. Given the Government will be providing a tax deduction for election expenses up to a limit of $1,000 to candidates, whether successful or not, the House of Representatives does not accept Amendment Number 10.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling the parliamentary secretary to speak on this bill, I would draw the Senate's attention to the fact that, in order to consider the amendments disagreed to by the House of Representatives, senators will need to look at the statement I made on 24 June 1997, copies of which have been circulated in the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the committee does not insist upon its amendments to which the House of Representatives has insisted on disagreeing.

The government is presenting the Constitutional Convention (Election) Bill 1997 to the Senate for what amounts to effectively the third time by way of this motion to the committee. In doing so, I think we are demonstrating our genuine sincerity in wanting to hold a constitutional convention. If we did not want to hold a constitutional convention, we would not have bothered to go through this process today. We would simply have said, `The Senate has voted against it twice. Clearly the Senate is not going to allow us to hold a constitutional convention. We will abandon the idea.' Nevertheless, we will give the Senate another opportunity to allow a constitutional convention to proceed by effectively re-presenting it to the Senate for a third time today.

We are committed to advancing the debate on the republic, despite the squeals from those opposite. The way in which we proposed this to the Australian people, which they endorsed, was to hold a constitutional convention. It is perfectly true that the coalition government is not committed, like the other parties, to Australia becoming a republic. On that basis, we need not have bothered with the process, but we have put forward a process to move this debate along. We made that quite clear in 1994—this is a policy we have had for three years—and we are attempting yet again to implement the policy that we went to the people with in 1996.

Of course, the irony in this is that all the opposition parties who run around the country desperate to have Australia become a republic are the ones who have refused to allow this debate to proceed by killing off the process put forward by the government. If the opposition parties are serious about progressing this debate, then they should obviously allow this bill to pass on this third occasion.

It does seem quite extraordinary to us that the opposition parties are deliberately sacrificing the process to advance the debate on a republic which they so want on the altar, frankly, of their obsession with compulsory voting. There can be no other interpretation of what has occurred to date. I have to say that, from the government's point of view, we do regard the opposition parties as behaving in a most extraordinary fashion on this matter. From the government's point of view, it has been a history of backflips and double standards and hypocrisy.

We announced this electoral system back in February. We said then in the Prime Minister's statement the process by which we proposed that delegates to the convention be elected. The Labor Party and the Democrats said at that stage that, while they did not like the voting system, it was not their intention to block it and prevent the process occurring.
Senator Margetts interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You said that you would not prevent the government's announced proposals for a voluntary postal ballot from proceeding. Mr Beazley made that quite clear and, I believe, the Leader of the Democrats (Senator Kernot) made that quite clear at the time. Of course, what appears to have happened is that the Left of the Labor Party, sitting together in the chamber at the moment, rolled the Labor leader, Mr Beazley, on this. They forced a complete backflip by demanding of the Labor Party outright opposition to this proposal. It is something that we do not really understand, given their passion for the Australian republic. It does appear that it is absolutely founded upon a refusal to allow the government to have a voluntary postal ballot to elect delegates. That is the fundamental objection.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to draw the Senate's attention to the editorial of the Adelaide Advertiser today—a paper out of the News Ltd stable, which is completely committed to an Australian republic. What we are talking about here is the opposition parties refusing to allow this whole process to go forward because of this fundamental principle—they say—of not allowing a voluntary postal ballot. As the Advertiser said, it is not the government which is going to thwart the event but a combined opposition vote. It went on to say:

The general election was not a referendum on a republic or even a convention, though Mr Howard did have a policy for one. It was the bestowal of a mandate for a limited period on the coalition parties. Surely if an elected government wants to call a meeting it has the right to set the rules?
Whether people go is then their own concern. But to seek to change the rules is plain arrogant.

I concur with the Adelaide Advertiser that the Senate is displaying the most extraordinary arrogance in saying to the government of the day, which wishes to hold a convention, that the Senate, in its petulant manner, will not tolerate the rules which the government have set which are perfectly reasonable.

Those rules have been endorsed by the only independent electoral commentators that we have. The Electoral Reform Society and the Proportional Representation Society have both endorsed the rules that we have established—not these partisan, biased opposition senators. A journalist, of course, that I think even you might respect, the Australian Financial Review's, Michelle Grattan, said in her column on 19 June about this whole issue:
But Labor's (and the minor parties) argument that voting for the republic convention should be compulsory? This, surely, is nonsense.
I agree entirely with Michelle Grattan about the opposition's position on this thing.

I have repeatedly stated, and I think it is fair to say this, that the position of the Labor Party and the Democrats on this question is entirely hypocritical. The Labor government back in 1989 brought into this parliament a proposal to establish the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, and specifically provided in that bill that voting for the elections within ATSIC would be by a voluntary vote. I was not here at the time but I presume, in the event that it passed, that it was supported by the Democrats. This chamber and this parliament have, when it was run by the Labor Party, voted for, supported, introduced and authorised voluntary voting in national elections: to wit, elections to ATSIC.

You had seven years to change that. You did not make any move to change away from voluntary voting for ATSIC elections. If voluntary voting is all right for the body that you set up to represent Aboriginal Australians, and which controls a budget of nearly $1 billion, why is it not all right for Australians, in voting to elect delegates to a national convention which will meet for 10 days, to have voluntary voting? It is an utterly ridiculous position that you are putting forward.

As I have said many times, the Labor Party itself, through its industrial wing, presides over voluntary postal voting for trade union elections. Many of the Labor Party members in this parliament are, of course, the products of trade union officialdom, to which they came through voluntary postal voting.

As my colleague Senator Abetz has reminded the nation, the Leader of the Democrats in this parliament, Senator Cheryl Kernot, is elected by a voluntary postal ballot, to cap off the hypocrisy. The leader of the party that has the swing vote in this chamber, which can decide whether propositions become law or not, is elected by a voluntary postal ballot. But delegates to attend a convention to discuss the question of whether Australia should become a republic cannot be elected by a voluntary postal ballot.

Your opposition to this bill is so disingenuous that it is clear to us that you are simply determined to use whatever means you can—no matter how ridiculous and no matter how ill‐founded—to shatter our proposal for a constitutional convention. You are prepared to use any means at your disposal to prevent a constitutional convention proceeding. The Senate is insisting to the government that this ballot can only proceed if it is a compulsory attendance ballot. As we have repeatedly said, that is not acceptable to the government.

We are not prepared to allow the Senate to set absolutely unreasonable rules for the election of delegates to this convention. We are not prepared, as a coalition government, to compel Australians to vote in this election of delegates to attend a convention. That is simply not consistent with our view of the world and we are not prepared to accept that proposition. As I have repeated many times, the proposition put forward by the Senate for a compulsory attendance ballot has been estimated by the AEC to add to the cost of the whole process an amount of somewhere around $15 million, up to possibly $20 million—more than the government's proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is rubbish and you know it.

—It is not rubbish, Senator Bolkus. There is approximately $13 to $14 million more for the attendance ballot, and up to $4 million extra for it to be compulsory. You have had those figures. You know they are true.
—You have the figures too and you know better than that. You are lying to the public.
—Order! Senator Bolkus, withdraw that comment.
—I made the assertion that he is lying because he knows full well what the figures are. He may not be lying, but he is not telling the truth.
—You should withdraw unconditionally, Senator Bolkus. I ask you to do so.
—I withdraw the claim that he is lying, but I say he is not telling the truth. I can do that.

—I have little regard for the comments or views of Senator Bolkus at any time, so I will ignore that comment. The costs have been determined by the AEC, not by us, and they amount to some $15 million to $20 million more. Of course that figure will fluctuate because it will depend on how many people choose not to vote.
—They're bodgie figures. You are a disgrace—an incompetent, devious disgrace. You put up bodgie figures all the time.

—Therefore, the costs of prosecuting Australians who do not vote is unlimited, Senator Bolkus, so you do not know what it is going to cost. It could cost more than $20 million if Australians exercise the right not to vote. We have committed $35 million to this process.
—I raise a point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman. I think the description by Senator Bolkus of the parliamentary secretary as devious is unparliamentary and should be withdrawn.
—I ask Senator Bolkus to withdraw that statement.
—I used three adjectives: incompetent, devious and a disgrace. If Senator Heffernan is only concerned about one of them, I withdraw it.

—Again I will ignore the ridiculous comments coming from the opposition. The government has committed $35 million to the process of election. We think that is a reasonable commitment to the process of advancing the debate. We have got a lot of very important projects that we want to spend money on, but we are laying our money on the line. We are saying, `Yes, we are prepared to spend $35 million to allow Australians to elect delegates to this convention. We have budgeted up to $5 million to hold the convention itself and yet you, the opposition parties, are not prepared to accept that. You are insisting on us spending a whole lot more money for your compulsory attendance ballot, something that is just unacceptable to the government.' We do not think we are being unreasonable; the Senate is being utterly unreasonable in refusing to allow it to proceed on the sensible basis which we have proposed.

SPEECH.PARA: We do want this convention to proceed. That is why we have reintroduced the bill. As I said at the start, we could have simply said, `You've voted against it twice' and have forgotten the whole process. We want a convention. It is before you again. We ask you to support it.

The Democrats have floated a proposal for a Senate committee to look into this question. My initial reaction to that is that it really is a pretty pathetic alternative to what the government has put before the people. We are proposing a national election of delegates which will involve every Australian. They will receive material from the government setting out the pros and cons of change. Material supplied by both sides of this debate will go to every household. They will have their chance to vote for delegates representing both sides of this debate. We will have 152 people elected from across Australia. All the state governments and oppositions will be represented.

The convention is a magnificent opportunity for a national debate of this issue. Instead, you just want a Senate committee to run around the country. The public will laugh at that—another committee of politicians just running around the country. That is not an alternative to what we are presenting. It is a joke. I therefore ask you to support this bill and not insist on your amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —The government has said that the reason the Constitutional Convention (Election) Bill 1997 is back is that it wants to give Labor, minor parties and Independents in this place one last opportunity to support the Constitutional Convention. In doing so, Senator Minchin has said again today that if we fail to support this bill the convention will not proceed. Let us put aside for one moment the sheer arrogance of Senator Minchin's statement—a statement which shows very clearly that the government is not serious about a republic, it is not serious about engaging in a constructive and bipartisan approach to constitutional reform, and it is not serious about approaching this issue in the way that it should be.

SPEECH.PARA: The history of our constitution has shown time and time again that proposals for reform succeed only when those proposals and the processes by which they are implemented are supported by both sides of politics—when the politics are in fact inclusive.

It is the government which has sought to deliberately divide on this issue. They have asked the Labor Party and all other parties and Independents in this place to make what they know is for them an unacceptable choice. They want us to choose between progressing a republic and support for compulsory voting. We do not want to choose between those two issues; we do not need to choose between them. We are not prepared to play your silly, divisive game, Senator Minchin. An increasing number of your backbench are getting tired of your silly, divisive game.

Accordingly, we will continue to support a compulsory ballot for the election of delegates to the People's Convention. If the government is not prepared to support a voting system that has served this nation well since 1924, it can explain that decision to the Australian people.
Senator Minchin quotes from the Adelaide Advertiser News Ltd newspaper. I will quote to you from the national News Ltd newspaper, Senator Minchin, what they said about your devious little games:
. . . the government is beginning to look as if it fears the march of history.
They went on to say:
Mr Howard did not campaign on the proposition that the selection of delegates to the people's convention should be used as a pilot for voluntary postal ballots.
They said a lot actually. I have only four short grabs here. They said:
Equally, the Government has made no case for the use of voluntary postal ballots for testing the waters on matters of ant importance.
That is News Ltd's points 1, 2 and 3. The fourth point was in the editorial yesterday:

. . . the suspicion must be that the government is not so much interested in curbing the cost of the convention vote but in limiting the scope for a majority of electors overall to endorse a republic.

We know that that has been your motivation right from the start. The issue of the republic will not go away, Senator Minchin. Shortly, with the Democrats and others in this place, we will be initiating resolutions to establish either a joint select committee or Senate committee to examine various models for an Australian republic. Of course that committee will draw on a considerable body of expertise and thought on issues surrounding the Australian republic.

The republic issue is one that should be handed over to the Australian people. In order to do so, the committee we propose will, through a series of hearings, forums and public meetings, take the issue of the republic to the Australian people across Australia.

In advancing these proposals it is fair to put on record and to appreciate the work that has been done by Senators Kernot, Harradine, Margetts and Brown. We have had discussions and will continue to have discussions, and we will make sure that the overwhelming majority of Australians will be able to have a fair say in a fair process for a fair outcome. The 70 per cent of Australians who support a republic will not be subverted by your devious little games.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is 49 per cent in your own Australian .

—It is much more than that, and you know it. So the choice will not be ours; it will be the government's. With these resolutions it will be up to the government to decide whether to participate in the committee process and help to advance the discussion on a republic. We hope you do.

SPEECH.PARA: A very early decision you will have to make will be whether to support the establishment of a joint select committee or to let the Senate proceed with a Senate committee. If you are serious about debating the republic, you will support the establishment of a joint select committee. If you are not, we will have to proceed with a motion of which notice has already been given by Senator Kernot to establish a Senate committee to ensure that the people do have an input.

There are other matters that I would like to discuss at this stage—all of which surround what I must call the government's incompetence in the handling of this bill. The first and most important is the remarkable contribution made by Senator Abetz to this debate. Senators may recall that on Monday there was some unfounded speculation that the Austral ian Democrats would do a backflip and support the convention bill. In that context, Senator Abetz said that the passage of the bill would be:
. . . a major boost to trialling voluntary voting on a national basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —Exposed.

—Exposed all right, well and truly exposed. Not surprisingly, Senator Minchin quickly carpeted Senator Abetz and said that Senator Abetz was not speaking for the government. You can look at Senator Abetz's comments in one of two ways. One is that Senator Abetz was a fool for admitting what the government had repeatedly sought to deny in this debate—namely, that this bill was a Trojan horse for voluntary voting. If that is the true interpretation of Senator Abetz's comments, then he has only confirmed our worst fears about the bill. He has shown that the government is not serious about this bill or the republic and that it is more interested in some ideological pursuit of voluntary voting—an idea which 70 per cent of Australians oppose.

SPEECH.PARA: The alternative view is that Senator Abetz, most likely in collusion with Senator Minchin, knew exactly what he was doing. He knew that his comments would force any non‐government senators who were considering changing their minds to oppose the bill. If that was his intent, then he and the government have, once again, shown their lack of commitment to the republic and to the convention.

TALK.START.PARA: —What commitment to a republic?

—Either way, you have shown what we have said all along, Senator Minchin, that this charade has been nothing more than an attempt to bury the republic and to introduce voluntary voting. On either ground, you, Senator Abetz and the government stand condemned. Of course, Senator Abetz may come in here and explain his actions, but I suspect he will not do that and, if he does, we will not know his motive.

SPEECH.PARA: The second matter I want to discuss is why we are debating this bill this week. What the government has refused to admit is that the reason why the House voted on the bill on Monday night and why we are voting on it today is that the government's so‐called master technician, the man who has all the high‐profile jobs, Senator Minchin, made a mistake. He forgot to return the Senate's message on this bill to the House at the end of last sitting. The effect of that mistake was that the time period required by section 57 of the constitution between the first and second rejections of a bill by the Senate only started to run two days ago when the House insisted on its amendments. But worse than making that mistake, Senator Minchin, your pathetic attempt to cover it up compounded the felony. In your press release issued last Friday you said:
While there is no indication that the Senate is likely to change its position on the Bill, it is the Government's view that the issue should be finally resolved early in this session.
If the Senate again insists on its amendments to the Bill, then the Constitutional Convention cannot be held in this term of Government.

Despite your comments, it is interesting to note that the three‐month gap required by section 57 of the constitution for a double dissolution trigger will now be completed in the last sitting week of the current session. In other words, the government still has the opportunity to use this bill as a double dissolution trigger, as they have repeatedly threatened to do, before the end of the year. Of course, Senator Minchin says, `We were never going to use it as a double dissolution trigger.' But what did the Treasurer say on the Sunday program? He clearly left open the issue as to whether this bill could be used for a double dissolution. He said:
The only way a double dissolution trigger can come about is if Labor rejects legislation.
Forget about the other parties in the Senate; it is just Labor as far as he is concerned. He continued:
Now, we have a policy which we took to the Australian people last year for a constitutional convention this year. The legislation's in the Senate. We want the convention.

Either you are not being honest or the Treasurer is not being honest. It is up to the public to work that out in a very hard field. You have contrived a bill which you hoped would end our republican dream, not bring it closer, a vehicle for burial, rather than to progress the issue. Senator Minchin, it is not going to happen. You have claimed you have a mandate to elect the delegates to the convention in any way that you want, but you do not have a mandate to do so contrary to the will of some 70 per cent of the Australian public who have made a decision as to whether or not they support voluntary voting. You continue to grossly overstate the cost of holding a compulsory ballot. Your figures have been dodgy from the start but, like Goebbels, you continue the big lie. And with that big lie, we saw the Prime Minister on the weekend running the same line—$20 million difference.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Bolkus, please withdraw that reflection.
—Which one?
—You know which one, Senator Bolkus.
—I am sure mention of Goebbels has been acceptable conduct in this chamber. It is on the record. I do not know why you are asking me to withdraw it now, but I withdraw it.
—Senator Bolkus, the particular issue which I raise is your assertion that Senator Minchin is continuing the big lie.

—I withdraw that as well, if you really want to be tetchy. What we have here, though, is a lie on the discrepancy between the two alternatives. You have promised to give Australians a heavy dose of democracy and to entrench division you have sought the most devious way to produce and conduct a process for the election of a convention and a republic. This is not the last chance for the Senate, for anyone who does not agree with the government or for the republic. It is the last chance to elect fairly a people's convention. If the government supports our amendments to the bill, then the people's convention can go ahead this year in December, as promised. Just keep that in mind. It does not take more than six or seven weeks to run a ballot.

SPEECH.PARA: You could still have this convention this year if you wanted to. In doing so, you could keep faith with your election promise and with the Australian people. Alternatively, you will be given the opportunity soon to support our model for a joint parliamentary committee, but if you refuse both of these, then through a Senate committee at least this issue will be kept alive.

The republic issue is bigger than today's vote, it is bigger than the government's legislation, it is bigger than any party in this place. It will continue and either the government can confront the republic in a fair and reasonable way or it can take its tricky and devious approach and proceed down that road. I think the Australian did get it right yesterday when they said what we are seeing here is `the government beginning to look as if it fears the march of history'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha!

—Senator Minchin, you can laugh. I am sure that when you went to the meeting of the uglies two weeks ago and told them what a great job you are doing burying native title you also told them that you were in charge of burying the republic. They were all very proud of you. They stood up and cheered and saluted you—I'll bet they did. The reality is you are a minority in your own party. State leader after state leader wants to see some constructive progressive leadership on this. But it is you, Mr Howard and Mr Morris, all the Prime Minister's men, sitting in the bunker of The Lodge, whenever he gets there—at Kirribilli, most likely—or in the bottom of this Parliament House, not looking at the tide of history—
—The tide of history swept you right out.

—It took 13 years to do so. It may not take more than two or three years to knock you off, particularly, as has increasingly been the case, the Australian public are seeing your government as a government that cannot constructively run any issue at all. You will be hung on this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Well we might laugh—and there is an awful lot of irony about that debate, that is so true—but the government's choice in bringing the Constitutional Convention (Election) Bill back to the Senate for the second time, in my view and in the Democrats' view, has absolutely nothing to do with their passionately wanting to have a constitutional convention; it has everything to do with the beginning of another deliberate government campaign to beat up the mythology of Senate obstructionism. That is what it is about.

SPEECH.PARA: This has nothing to do with the government wanting to have a convention; it has everything to do with the very immature advice the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has been given over the break to rescue his failing leadership. This was summed up by an article by Hugh Mackay in the Weekend Australian of 19 and 20 July, which says:
This week's Newspoll findings suggest that the Prime Minister has suffered an alarming slump in public esteem. Why?

That is what this is about. This is about the advice that the Prime Minister has been given to rescue his leadership by being seen to take on the Senate. I recall reading that advice in the break. Paul Kelly, writing in the Weekend Australian , said:

Howard should keep calling the Senate's bluff and force either a series of Senate retreats (which depict his own strength) or, if the Senate holds, secure his reforms at a post-election joint sitting, inevitably a grand event.
Laurie Oakes in the Bulletin of 29 July under the heading `Political circus in search of a strongman' again quotes the same story around the gallery. It says:

Advisers . . . will be telling him . . . that from now on, he should be uncompromising with the Senate; that he should bowl everything up to them, and not budge an inch. He needs to call the Senate's bluff . . . . If the opposition parties in the Senate do not back down, Howard will at least have been seen to take them on.

That is what this is about. The campaign is beginning. Biffo No. 1 is the convention, biffo No. 2 is the unfair dismissal law debate coming up and biffo No. 3 is native title. It is so transparent, Senator Minchin.

BREAK.PARA: The only problem is Australians do not actually believe that this self-imposed virility test and your criterion of macho aggression and taking on the Senate are the most important measure of leadership in this country. They do not agree with you. They will see through this transparent little campaign.

Senator Bolkus quoted from the Australian editorial of 26 August. Of course, Senator Minchin only quoted selectively from the Adelaide Advertiser, his home‐town paper. We all know what campaigns it prefers to run. A June Australian editorial said:

The government is clearly wrong to use the convention to experiment with voluntary voting. The Parliamentary Secretary responsible for the republican convention, Nick Minchin, an ardent espouser of voluntary voting, stresses it is a one-off proposition.
The obvious question is: why do it at all? Good question. That was June, but yesterday the Australian editorial said:
Mr Howard did not campaign on the proposition that the selection of delegates to the people's convention should be used as a pilot for voluntary postal ballots.

Equally, the government has made no case for the use of voluntary postal ballots for testing the waters on matters of national importance. That is the significance. This is a very important matter, despite all the other nonsense we hear in here about public interest and national interest. The shape of our government for the next century is quite clearly one of the most important issues facing this country.

Senator Minchin, you are determined to put this little poisoned pill of voluntary voting in there because you do not want the shape of the government in this next century to be anything like a republic. That is what this is all about. We do not believe you want a convention. We do not believe you want a republic. What is more, we do not believe your disingenuous little assertion on the radio this morning that `this is no Trojan Horse'. Goodness me, this bill is no Trojan Horse for voluntary voting! Senator Abetz has already blown your cover on that one.

From the record, we also know of the passionate endorsements for voluntary voting you have given during past American and New Zealand election campaigns. You have been very quick to leap into print to point out the merits of voluntary voting in all of those and, in some cases, I suppose, to misrepresent voter turnout.

You said this morning on ABC radio that the Senate would need to vote on changes to the electoral act: `Just let it through this once and, really, the wider electoral act is protected because it has to get through the Senate.' I am afraid that one of the problems with attempting to persuade us to that view is that, to put it delicately, the state of play in relation to the Senate numbers at this moment, in the Democrats' view, means that the merits of arguments for or against the proposition are not the only determinant of the outcome of how the Senate might vote. So do not ask us to be reassured by your saying, `Don't worry, it has to go to a vote of the Senate.'

I noticed that you came in swinging with the same old Senate obstructionism lines this morning. I heard you on both ABC interviews and I counted the number of times and said to myself, `The campaign's beginning; this is biffo No. 1 back on the agenda today.' Whenever things start to look a little bit shaky for you lot, whenever the failure of your economic policies are exposed or whenever we have another debate on unemployment where everybody says, `We don't want more labour market deregulation,' what do you fall back on? Senate obstructionism.

It was very disappointing that you ruled out Senator Bob Brown's plebiscite offer. You said that it was an unreasonable demand for a plebiscite to be held at the next election. You said, `My goodness, this will be three national votes in the space of 12 months!' Obviously, you are inferring that Australians are not capable of doing that, let alone the fact that Americans can cope with 15 or 16 votes simultaneously.

There has been a tremendous amount of goodwill in here and in our meetings on this matter in recent days. We have been trying to provide an alternative forum so that the impetus for national debate on our nation's future is not lost. I expected you to disparage our proposal as it stands at the moment—as a notice of motion today.

It is not just another Senate committee—and let us not say that about Senate committees anyway. We know that there are some that have had a fantastic impact on the legislative history of this country. It is not, as you say, just another Senate committee. This is a committee which has the express responsibility of facilitating the staging of a national debate, utilising the existing mechanisms of the Senate.

As Senator Bolkus explained, individuals considered to have some expertise on this issue, irrespective of whether they are for or against the status quo, are invited to express their views at a forum to be determined by this committee. We think one of the options for consideration ought to be, as has been done in other parliaments, particularly in the state parliament of New South Wales, that people address the Senate from a lectern at the front. They can actually say, `These are my views,' and not necessarily be subject to cross-examination. I think the important thing is that their ideas for a possible model for an Australian republic can then form the framework within which a series of public hearings can be staged.

We can take this debate, as Senator Bolkus said, to every corner of the continent—that is, into the cities and the regional centres—and we can ask as many Australians as possible, not just a select few, what they really think about the issues. I think the public hearings process could be informative for those individuals confused about the alternatives available. It could spell out the implications of those alternatives. I think it could result in a much better indication of the Australian mood than any small sample from a Newspoll could.

I think there is one fundamental difference between the proposal that we in the non-government parties are trying to work up to put to the Australian people and through the Senate and the government's talkfest. We do not have questionable motives on this. We are not trying to stick a poisoned pill in the middle of it. This is a very simple proposition. We want to facilitate the move to a referendum. We are not seeking dishonestly to put obstacles whenever and wherever we can in the way of such a move. Then it will be the job of this committee to recommend to the Senate, based on the evidence they have received, a form of question or questions to be put to the Australian people at a referendum on this issue.

That is what we want, is it not? Is that not what we really want to come out of the debate, even out of your convention? But you are requiring some kind of consensus to be reached and then you are going to give us the wonderfully grand gesture of a vote before the end of the century. Thank you very much for that.

When I think about being offered a vote before the end of the century, I say to myself that I hope to goodness it is before the Olympics Games because I do not relish the thought of the Queen or the Prime Minister, John Howard, being the face of Australia for the rest of world in opening the Olympic Games. I think that is a fantastic reason for not putting obstacles in the way of the republican debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The only obstacle is the one you are putting in the way, as far as I can see.

—Senator Boswell, you speak again. The important issue to come back to is the timing. Why has the government brought this back today? Why have they brought it back at all? Senator Minchin, wearing his other hat, is expecting the native title debate to happen in the Senate in December. That is at a time when we were not meant to be sitting.

BREAK.PARA: The question is: why have you brought it back at a time when it is not a trigger. I think that is wise enough for you. It is not the motive. It is not a reason that you have given all of us. It is not because you want a convention. Nobody believes you. You say the issue of voluntary voting is not important. I say a convention should not be held hostage. You should have been willing to consider a compromise instead of saying the Senate is blocking your legislation. That is not true. The Senate has amended your legislation. It is your government that has been unwilling to walk away and say, `Is it not possible that we could break the nexus, that we could break the hostage relationship between the method of voting and the outcome—the convention?' You were not willing to do that. Your government has not been willing to do that and that is what needs to be injected into consideration in this debate.

I regret that we may not have a convention, that we may not be able to go forward and take the republican debate forward via that mechanism. But I agree with Senator Bolkus that you should not be forcing the Senate to choose between the principle of compulsory voting, which has underpinned our democracy for so long in this country, and the opportunity to have a discussion on the nature of a republic in this country. I say shame on your government for behaving so immaturely. I also come to my starting point: this is not about your wanting to have a convention; this is the first phase of your next campaign to build up the mythology of Senate obstructionism.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —During the debate that we had the last time we were debating this legislation some points became very clear. Those points were that the preamble, which stated the framework for the constitution convention, was not actually what the government had in mind for the constitutional convention to debate and have an influence over.

SPEECH.PARA: I asked questions in relation to the time frame. What if the Constitutional Convention were to say, `We would like to have an indicative plebiscite earlier?' The response from the government—and Senator Minchin might respond to this—was, `We will decide when and if that plebiscite takes place.' Basically, the Constitutional Convention was given no power to actually make that decision. One of the three points in the preamble, and a very important one, to the Constitutional Convention—that is, the time frame and appropriate circumstances for considering change—the government clearly stated it had not considered doing. They were going to make the decisions when they were good and ready. One out of three points the government had no intention at all of honouring. So the convention was not expected to do what it was listed to do.

BREAK.PARA: One of the other issues was what republican models should be put to the voter. That could be a range of things; I guess that issue is as wide as it is long. It is not for the cabinet to decide what the Constitutional Convention interprets that as. I suggest that the Constitutional Convention might look at the various elements of constitutional change that might be appropriate to go with any discussion about whether or not Australia progresses to a republic.

At that time Senator Minchin also said, `Well, no, that's not the role of the Constitutional Convention.' So, no, the government does not expect the Constitutional Convention to look at the models that should be put to the voters of Australia; that is, the government does not expect it to look at what kinds of constitutional changes should attend any proposed changes. They said that the government will make decisions on the time frame and that the Constitutional Convention would not be empowered or somehow the government would not be paying attention to them if they looked at any alternative models; that is, if they looked at any wider constitutional changes. That, as far as I can see, would fit into what would be the model for a change.

Let us face it: it is called a constitutional convention, not a `Would you like to be a republic convention?' It is called a constitutional convention. What is left? What is left is whether the present constitution should be changed. Guess what? The Prime Minister said, `If there is a consensus.' It has been set up so there cannot possibly be a consensus. A consensus is a bringing together in one mind. It is a process that means working together to a common end, and that those people who have a different view are prepared to step back. It is not designed to do that. That is three out of three—you have batted out.

It is not as if what the Senate is being asked to do is vote on a partially flawed model of a constitutional convention. What came out in the debate is that the model is almost totally flawed. Added to that is the very real risk that, in supporting the government's poor offer to the people of Australia, the Senate would potentially be used as a vehicle for pushing other changes to the voting system. It is not just about the voting system; it is also about whether or not women will be fairly represented. It is about a whole lot of issues within the Constitutional Convention which certainly make it highly flawed.

When it comes to money, if this convention were to take place you would have to say that that amount of money should be spent carefully. You would not put a constitutional convention together and then maybe at some stage if another government came through—or even the same government rethought the situation and realised that it was acting against the interests of the community—think, `We'd better do it better this time.' What then could we use to say, `Let's do it properly this time'? You would say, `Oh, we spent $35 plus million on it before; therefore we can only do it the once.'

There are many people I know within the wider community who have varying views on this issue. I know within the Greens network there are people who believe that the convention should be progressed. But I also know there are many more people within the network that I speak to who, on the issue of how we are going to advance the constitution of Australia—that is, our democratic process—believe that if there is one issue where the means is at least as important as the end, it is how you come to the decisions about your constitution. How can you say, `Let's just be undemocratic,' and hope that the process will turn out to be representative of people's views?

I can understand those in the republican movement who might like to progress this further or who believe that this is the way to progress it. I have a difficulty with those people in the republican movement who believe that part of this process is to control the debate to stop it from widening out. I also believe, however, that this is an opportunity; instead of being rushed into a flawed mickey mouse process which is, by its process, undemocratic, now is the opportunity for the community to claim back the process.

It is possible for people across Australia to have meetings, to have workshops; for local government, perhaps, and for other groups to have meetings and workshops to talk about the issue of what kind of Australia they would like in the next century, what kind of constitutional basis they think is appropriate for Australia in the next century and how they want to relate to their head of state.

To me, the minimalist approach of simply changing the head of state and then hoping that the rest will all turn out okay is a flawed process. I believe if we have got the chance to do it, we should do it right. It is extremely tempting not to vote on this issue at all, because then the government would be left with a constitutional convention which clearly they do not want. That would mean that they would have to deal with the public's response when, inevitably, they could not totally control the process. But to lead such an important issue into such a flawed process is still a problem that I have difficulty dealing with. I would have to say that the ends that the government has presented do not justify the shoddy means that they are presenting to the Senate in order to achieve an end which is uncertain. Quite clearly—Senator Brown knows this—the government has no real intention of advancing the process.

So all three proposals for the forum have turned out to be flawed. The government has no intention of acting on any outcomes on any one of those three proposals. Therefore, at this stage it may well be better for us to go back to the community. The community can kick the proverbial rear end of the government so that they get it right and join with the rest of the community in taking this issue further and debating it further.

The Senate committee by itself, obviously, is no exchange for a full and properly funded process of consultation, but it would open the process up to more of the community than would currently be the situation with both the election and the selection process that is under way. It is my opinion it is not enough. In order to work, it will also have to be associated with a lot more involvement within the community of sharing ideas, empowering other people through information and providing the way forward. I really hope that that will happen.

I also hope that the republican movement will open that process to bring in the excitement of those people who really do think that we have to not only change the head of state in Australia but also that we should look at what kind of Australia is appropriate in terms of such things as human rights, ecological sustainability as a right of citizenship and the rights of indigenous people in Australia.

We have this immense opportunity to talk about those kinds of issues. We have this immense opportunity to talk about the roles of states, including the revenue powers of states and local and federal government. We should not waste this opportunity. Therefore, we should all open out the process to make sure that it is inclusive and that the maximum participation means that the outcome is worthy of Australia and Australia's future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin my contribution on the Constitutional Convention (Election) Bill 1997 by reaffirming the fundamental position of the Labor Party. We are absolutely committed to the system of compulsory voting that has served this country so well. Any move away from the system will be absolutely opposed by us, despite whatever threats the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and his cronies might wish to hold over us.

SPEECH.PARA: The opposition is fervently committed to a republic and an Australian head of state. We also strongly believe that the best way to achieve a republic is via a sustained and rational debate by all Australians leading to an indicative plebiscite and, ultimately, a referendum. We have said all along that the government's proposal for a constitutional convention is a political exercise—an unnecessary and ill-conceived political exercise. The way the government has managed and handled this legislation really demonstrates what a paltry political exercise it really is.

It is the tried and true Liberal Party technique of the sugar coated poison pill. They have tried yet again to blackmail the Senate into supporting the backdoor introduction of a voluntary system of voting—a perversion of the democratic process; a perversion of the electoral system that has found support not only in the Australian community but also throughout the world. We have in Australia the best electoral system in the world. The cornerstone of it is compulsory attendance ballots.
We see belligerent posturings from Senator Minchin on this bill—that is when he takes time out from organising the extreme right wing Liberal Party faction in the New South Wales—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mainstream!
—It is called the mainstream, is it, Senator Minchin? No wonder you laugh because you do not believe it and no-one else does. It is only you and Lyenko Urbanchich who cop that.
—Never met him.

—Never met him? Well, he was at the meeting. Of course, it was not really a meeting, was it? It was just a family gathering. That is right—it was a family gathering. I forgot. There you were up in New South Wales not organising a new extreme right wing faction but involved in a family gathering. The only problem is that no‐one's family was there, including Senator Minchin's. It is only his political family, the broad church of the extreme right wing of the New South Wales division of the Liberal Party.

SPEECH.PARA: When you take time off from your family gatherings, what you are saying is you will can the constitutional convention if we, the Labor Party, do not back down on our amendments. We will not, because our amendments are designed to preserve the democratic traditions of this nation. It is the best electoral system in the world.

The last time we were here debating this legislation I acknowledged, generously, that the holding of the constitutional convention was a Howard pre-election pledge. I did say that it was an unusual pledge because it was one of the few that Mr Howard had made that he intended to honour. But, of course, like so many of Mr Howard's promises, it is one that he was really ready to ditch once the going got tough. He is now backing away from the constitutional convention with a simple threat: he will not hold it unless the Senate backs down on its position of principle and compromises on the issue of a voluntary postal ballot.

The proposals in this bill include a massive change from compulsory to voluntary voting, holding a postal ballot, not an attendance ballot, and a change to optional and preferential voting, all of which I believe are of great significance to the Australian electorate. But not one of them was ever canvassed by the coalition parties before the election. They were certainly not part of Mr Howard's promise to the Australian people at the last election. It was the secret agenda of Mr Howard, Senator Minchin and the mainstream faction of the Liberal Party.

I think we need to be very clear on this. Our amendments do not prevent the Constitutional Convention from proceeding. We have always said that we at least respect the fact that the convention is the preferred vehicle for the government to progress the debate on the republic. However, what we have done and what we will not back down on is our commitment to ensure that the ballot is a compulsory attendance secret ballot to ensure that the system of voting is simplified so it is as straightforward, as accessible, as democratic, as well understood and as simple as is possible.

Both Mr Howard and Senator Minchin are on the record in the Sydney Morning Herald of 5 May stating that they `won't be budged' from the proposed voluntary ballot and that it was `non‐negotiable'. Likewise, the Labor Party, the opposition, will not be budged on these issues. Likewise, these issues are non‐negotiable as far as Labor is concerned. The real agenda of the Liberals has always been very transparent. They have always been committed to undermining our democratic process by abolishing compulsory voting in favour of a voluntary system.

We say that a voluntary system would further alienate the disadvantaged and the disaffected from the political process. I will not go through the arguments that I outlined at length when this matter was previously debated in the Senate. I believe I went through them very thoroughly before and those views are firmly on the record. Suffice to say, Mr Howard and Senator Minchin's real agenda is clear: they do not want a convention. They do not want a republic. They have tried to spike this convention with their electoral experiments in the knowledge that the Senate would not be likely to support them. Of course, the underhand way that they have manipulated this legislative process is proof of their commitment to changing Australia's electoral system.

I would like to refer to a matter raised by Senator Minchin in his contribution. I was most interested to see the true Liberal agenda come out via the press release from Senator Abetz. For the information of anyone who might be listening to this broadcast day in the Senate, let me explain who Senator Abetz is. He would not be well known. It is Senator Eric Abetz from the state of Tasmania. I hope that explains who he is. Senator Boswell did not know either, but there are a lot of listeners who would not have heard of him, I can assure you, Senator Boswell.

Senator Eric Abetz put out a press release demonstrating for the first time on his part not only some real political insight but also the true Liberal Party agenda. Fancy him being honest enough to actually confirm what Mr Howard and Senator Minchin were really on about before this debate was about to occur in the Senate! This is what he actually said. Let me quote Senator Eric Abetz, Liberal, Tasmania. He said:
The reported Democrat backflip on the constitutional convention is a major boost to trialling voluntary voting on a national basis.
Thank you, Senator Abetz. Then he went on to say:
If the Democrats do support the constitutional convention they will allow a significant voluntary voting project to be undertaken and I look forward to that prospect.

Thank you again, Senator Abetz. It is a set‐up. The Liberals are using this election of delegates to the Constitutional Convention to attack the integrity of Australia's electoral system. But we will not back away from the Australian way of voting. We will not back away from the Australian ballot, which has traditionally been a compulsory attendance secret ballot. We will never accept the perver sion of our electoral system, which is an electoral system that I think the vast majority of Australians are proud of and rightly regard as the best in the world.

It is shameful to see people like Senator Boswell and his colleagues from the National Party conned by this. The National Party do not support voluntary voting, do you, Senator Boswell? No. You do not support postal ballots for elections, do you, Senator Boswell? No.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support this bill.

—Yes, but you support this because you have been conned, Senator Boswell. You have been conned again. The National Party is rolling over on what hitherto has been a fundamental principle that that party has signed up to. It is weakness on the part of the National Party, and it is pathetic on behalf of the constituency they claim to represent. We will do everything to ensure that the convention just does not become a device for Mr Howard and Senator Minchin to smother a republic and to rort our electoral system. We have taken the first step along the way by amending this legislation to make the ballot for delegates to the convention a ballot in the tried and true Australian tradition, which is a compulsory attendance ballot. We are not going to back away from that now.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also like to make some reference to the feeble defence that the government has put to the parliament that the voluntary postal ballot is a more cost‐effective way of electing delegates to the convention. Our response to that weak and pathetic excuse is simple: the cost of democracy has never before been an issue in this country. It should not be one now. You cannot compromise the democratic process on the basis of cost. What price does the Liberal Party put on democracy? In this context it is a measly $13 million at the most.

We say to the government: whatever the difference is between the cost of a compulsory attendance ballot and a voluntary postal ballot, whether it is $13 million or it is less, the integrity of our electoral system is worth the money. There is no defence, budgetary or otherwise, for the government's proposed voluntary postal ballot. It can be justified only in terms of the government's lack of commitment to a republic, lack of commitment to their own Constitutional Convention and desire to fundamentally change our electoral system for their own political advantage. I urge the chamber to press these amendments, to progress this matter and to reject this barefaced, transparent rort from Mr Howard and his henchman, Senator Minchin.

TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)
