DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: South Australia: Leader of the Opposition

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Schacht's desperate and grubby little political exercise cannot go without some response but, because I have a number of things I want to read onto the record, I do not propose to respond to what Senator Schacht has said. Instead, I will read an account of a media release from the Premier of South Australia, Mr John Olsen, followed by a statement. This is a media release from Thursday, 21 August 1997 and it says:

SPEECH.PARA: Premier John Olsen today released details of his defamation response.
His rebuttal of the Opposition Leader's claims includes:

. A detailed legal statement from Premier and Cabinet Chief Executive Officer, Ian Kowalick, that the Government papers concerning the EDS Contract/North Terrace Development released by the Opposition were not cabinet documents but departmental documents which Premier Olsen had no access to, could not have had access to and had not seen.
And I will be reading a copy of that statement into the record.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I have a point of order. My point of order is that Senator Ferguson is raising issues and accusing me of not quoting correctly. He is quoting from documents which I attempted to table today. Senator Ferguson and other Liberals refused to give me leave to table those documents—the same documents he is now reading from. It is extraordinary!
—There is no point of order. I call Senator Ferguson.
—The press release continues:

SPEECH.PARA: . A statement that it was a local media organisation which provided the Catch Tim information directly to the Opposition Leader so that parliamentary question time could be used to extract further information from the Government.

. Confirmation that Premier Olsen had not been part of the IT cabinet sub‐committee since 1995 and therefore had no access to the commercial in confidence details of the EDS development which it is claimed he supplied to the Opposition.
I now want to read the following statement of 24 July 1997 made by Ian Kowalick, Chief Executive of the Department of the Premier and Cabinet. It reads:
I have been Chief Executive for approximately two and a half years.
My department is responsible for the circulation of Cabinet papers. Cabinet papers are prepared by Ministers or their departments.
I am aware that the Leader of the Opposition, the Honourable Mike Rann, has alleged that material relating to EDS was provided to him by Premier John Olsen.
In this instance, in relation to the EDS material, it was prepared in the Department of the Premier and Cabinet.
That evidence was given on 10 June 1997.
On Tuesday 27 June 1997, I looked at material provided to me by the Premier's Chief of Staff, Liz Blieschke.
I looked at it at Parliament House.
On that day, Mike Rann handed material out to members of the media, identifying it as material provided to him by John Olsen.
As far as I am aware, he did not issue any press release.
I was not present when he actually handed it out.
He did not do it in the course of Parliamentary proceedings.
Liz Blieschke told me, when I was at Parliament House that certain documents she was holding were copies of material provided by Mr Rann to the media.
She indicated that the copy she held had been provided to her by an Advertiser journalist, who had received the material from Mr Rann.
Vicki Thompson was the member of the Premier's office who received them, and she would know the identity of the journalist. I do not.

The documents which I saw were copies of documents relating to a proposed building for EDS. The material consisted of typed extracts from a Cabinet Submission in the standard font for the Department of the Premier and Cabinet and a copy of a letter from the former Premier, the Honourable Dean Brown, to Mr J Bowyer of Hansen Yuncken Pty Ltd that was an attachment to the Submission.
I am familiar with the process for preparation and distribution of Cabinet papers.
In this instance, I believe that standard process was followed.
It involved the preparation of a draft Cabinet Submission in the Premier's Office or the Department.
That was then distributed to a number of agencies for comment.
In this particular instance, I am able to say that the agencies to whom the draft was distributed were:
. Treasury
. Services SA
. Crown Law
. Department of the Premier and Cabinet
. Department of Information Industries.
I am able to say that from information maintained in our departmental computer system, which I have accessed.
That information is perfectly standard.
Generally, such submissions are sent out for comment.
Any comment or criticism is returned to our office, from which my department prepares a "Cabinet blue".
This is an attachment to the Cabinet Submission containing our summary of any critique, comments or modifications proposed in relation to the Submission.
After the blue is prepared, it will be distributed to Cabinet with Cabinet Submissions, ie the Submission and the blue will often be distributed together.

Distribution of Cabinet papers to Ministers occurs late on Wednesdays and Fridays, for the following Monday's Cabinet meeting; or, as on this occasion, for the next morning's special Cabinet meeting prior to Executive Council.
Our departmental computer system shows that the submission was received at 10.30 am on Wednesday 23 October 1996.
I do not know for sure if a blue was prepared in this case.
It does not always occur.
Here, having regard to the short time frame, I suspect one was not.
However, I can say, from information contained in our departmental computer system, that the submissions were distributed to Ministers at approximately 4.00 pm on 23 October 1996.
That is, prior to that time, John Olsen did not have access to a copy.
It had gone to the five agencies only.
No minutes or attendance records are kept for Cabinet meetings.
However, Executive Council follows on Thursdays after any special Cabinet meeting.
Records are kept of who attends Executive Council.
Those who attended were:
. Premier Dean Brown
. Deputy Premier Stephen Baker
. Attorney-General Trevor Griffin
. Minister for Tourism, Graham Ingerson
. Minister for Transport, Diana Laidlaw
. Minister for Housing & Urban Development, Scott Ashenden
John Olsen did not attend the Cabinet meeting that day.
I was not at that Cabinet meeting, but have made enquiries.
My enquiries of John Olsen's office indicate (from memory) that he was somewhere down South doing an opening ceremony.
I have looked at the material which, as I understand it, Mike Rann has identified as being provided to him by John Olsen.
I have compared it to the first generation copy provided to agencies for consultation.
I noted a number of matters.

The Leader of the Opposition's copy carried defects which I am able to say are "fingerprint" characteristics of the drum of the photocopier used to make previous generations of the copy. Also, the photocopied staple marks on the copy of the letter appear in a different position to that on the Cabinet file master copy.
That is, the Rann document was not derived from the same master as the documents that went out to Ministers.

On 27 June I examined a copy of the submission in the departmental working file. That file was the basis for consultation with other departments and the Prudential Management Group and later reconsideration of the proposal for the EDS building by Treasury and myself, ie it was the document which went out to the agencies.
The copy in the departmental working file bore the same characteristics as the copy provided to the media by the Leader of the Opposition.
From that, I infer that the Rann document comes from someone who has copied an agency consultation copy—being a copy which would not have been able to be accessed by John Olsen.
I made a copy of the master copy which is the source of Ministers' copies on the Cabinet Office photocopier.
I was not able to reproduce the characteristic defects.
That is, I came back to the State Administration Centre 14th floor photocopier, which I am able to say is the machine used for distribution of Cabinet papers.
I receive copies of all Cabinet submissions produced in the same run as Ministers' photocopies.
I was overseas at the time this particular matter went before Cabinet, ie on 23‐24 October 1996.
In order to check my findings, I examined a photocopy of another submission produced by the Cabinet Office in late September 1996.
Again, it did not have the defects of the Rann photocopy.
My department and I are very security conscious.
When I saw the Rann document, I knew straight away which floor of the State Administration Centre and which machine it had been produced on.
I recognised the characteristic defect as emanating from a photocopier on the 13th floor.
It was then used by the Project Co-ordination Division of the Department of the Premier and Cabinet.
Staff working in that area at the time were working on the EDS proposal.
There are other functions of this department and Treasury on the 13th floor.
I cannot say how many people may have had access to the photocopier.
I am unable to say who made the photocopies.
I am however, from my knowledge of Cabinet procedures, able to say that John Olsen could not have made that copy.
So far as l am aware, he has never accessed a photocopier on the 13th floor himself, and it would be most unusual and memorable if a Minister did so.
Indeed, for security reasons he would not have been able to access the 13th floor.

I am able to say that other photocopies within the Department of the Premier and Cabinet files have the same "fingerprint" characteristics as the material provided to the media by Mr Rann, ie other copies in the files which were made on the 13th floor machine have the same defect.
The probability that a copier in a Minister's Office would have the same random defect on its drum is infinitesimal.
It is not even remotely possible.
Further, in any case the staple holes in the copy of the letter would have been in a different position.

Accordingly, I have no doubt that the Rann photocopy and the attached letter was derived from a copy made in the Department of the Premier and Cabinet. It was not made from a first generation copy made by the Cabinet Office for distribution to Ministers.

I am able to say that at least five departments had copies for consultation purposes. Accordingly, the likelihood is that the material received and distributed by Mr Rann was provided by a government officer, not a Minister.
There are two more pages of my speech, but I will leave those for my colleague Senator Ferris to read into the record when she speaks later in the adjournment debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to expand on the remarks I made yesterday in the urgency debate regarding schools and literacy. As all senators will now be aware, our two ministers for education—echoing complaints made from time to time by disgruntled employer groups—are back on the bandwagon of literacy or, should I say, the lack of it in government schools.

SPEECH.PARA: This began with Dr Kemp's pronouncement late last year that one-third of year 9 students could not read—something which has now been said by him so often that it has become the truth for many people. He took for his evidence the results of a test for something quite different; that is, a very small section of a longitudinal 20-year study of the transition from school to work, in which a complex question of comprehension was put to students. Senators may recall that the journalist who wrote the piece on which the test was based failed the test according to the examiner's interpretation of the meaning. I keep raising this matter because the minister continues to mislead parents by repeating his remarks over and over again.

Now Senator Vanstone has joined in the fray, and she too proclaims that literacy is of great concern to this government. Literacy ought to be of concern to the government. Every effort should be made to see that all students have the most basic skills in literacy by their very early primary years. Unfortunately, concern is not enough. A nine per cent reduction in real terms in spending on literacy is not enough. A nationwide campaign to test students is also not enough. In fact, wholesale testing is not only ineffective in improving literacy but it also has the potential to do more harm than good.

The harm that I refer to is that the government will use the results of that data in its ongoing campaign to shift students from government to private schools or, as the minister says, she `wants to focus a spotlight on areas where they'—that is, government schools—`can do better'. I would like to contrast the government's `bleed them dry then test how they cope' mentality with what the educators are saying tonight.

Almost 12 months ago, the Australian Literacy Educators Association produced what was titled `A strategy plan for successful literacy learning'. This organisation is made up of members of all levels of education and from different education systems. The plan outlines 10 key recommendations. Of course, it may come as a surprise to the government that none of these is about testing and none of them is about competition between schools and any of the other nonsense that we hear about from our education ministers when they discuss the matter of literacy. In the preface of the strategy plan, the association says:

While there is no evidence to support the commonly expressed view that there has been a decline in literacy standards in Australia, literacy educators must not be complacent for the highly technological society in which we live demands or requires more sophisticated skills.
The association goes on to say:

We believe that high standards of literacy are necessary for today's students to meet the literacy requirements for our present society as well as for the future. Changes in technology and society have altered and will continue to alter the ways in which we use language to communicate and to think. Students must be prepared to meet these demands.

However the act of setting high standards, by itself, cannot erase the impact of poverty, ethnic or cultural discrimination, low levels of family literacy, and social and political disenfranchisement. We must ensure that all students have equal opportunities to learn that inequities in school resources are addressed, that schools have an adequate number of knowledgeable teachers, and that we provide safe and supportive environments for learning.
Literacy involves the construction and interpretation of meaning for a range of purposes. Meaning has to be at the centre of any literacy program.

The association's first recommendation is that a major literacy promotion campaign through commercial television targets parents and carers of pre-school students, highlighting the importance of their role in supporting early and on‐going literacy development. It should be understood that literacy learning begins a long time before formal schooling. Studies have shown that if families can share books with babies as young as six to nine months of age, then these children will show positive literacy outcomes.

The second recommendation is the development of a home education literacy program. This would target new parents and would focus on talking with and to children, singing, chanting rhymes and jingles, sharing reading and enjoying books with children. The program, they say, could be run through maternal and child health centres, libraries and communities centres.

The association suggests the appointment of pre‐school literacy officers attached to community service centres to assist in the administration and development of the program. Very high on the list of priorities for the association is a well resourced local library. Most communities already have a good local library, but many do not. Of course, remote rural areas are the places where we find very low retention rates. A number of inquiries and reports, and their recommendations, have already been made. Now, says the association, is the time for a firm policy to be articulated to ensure that there is increased provision for literacy education in all pre‐service education programs.

The association points out that over the last four years there have been dramatic reductions in the time allocations for pre‐service education courses in the areas of language and literacy education. It says that early childhood, primary and secondary teacher education should include compulsory language education units. Their recommendation No. 6 is that all primary teacher education programs should include compulsory units on early literacy learning, in addition to other language education units. They suggest that on‐going professional development in literacy education should be compulsory for all teachers so they remain informed about literacy research and practices and can translate these into classroom practice. The association points out that many teachers have been in the service for a long time and there is a need for them to keep abreast of current research, theory and current practices, and the significant changes which have taken place over the last 10 years in literacy education.

Their recommendation No. 8 relates to support for programs. There should be a network of locally based language and literacy specialists to support teachers in improving their classroom teaching, as well as curriculum support guidelines and materials that reflect current research and practices in teaching and learning. Of course, funding should be made available to assure small class sizes at least in the early years. Funds are also needed to ensure that classrooms and school libraries can continue to provide children with contemporary Australian books.

Their recommendation No. 9 is that schools should be supported and encouraged to develop agreed school policies and programs which prioritise literacy, and develop plans to have experienced teachers with specialist qualifications in literacy; to maintain well stocked school and classroom libraries; to provide access to classroom based computers and materials for classroom reading, writing and spelling activities; and, finally, to ensure that curriculum evaluation procedures match individual school policies.

The reason that I raise this strategy plan tonight and give it to the Senate in some detail is because I want to point out that the government has put in place none of these recommendations. I did not notice anywhere in that strategy document the requirement that all students be tested and the results made public. I detected no sense of blame because schools and teachers have not tried hard enough, or have not been competitive enough, or efficient enough. This is a plan of action—a positive contribution towards improving literacy in our schools. The government has had this plan for almost a year and has managed to ignore it totally.

The Senate Employment, Education and Training References Committee will commence its inquiry into the status of teachers this Friday and I want to tell senators that it is my earnest hope that, although the government has not listened to this advice and the advice, no doubt, that it has been given from other sources since it came to office, the evidence which might come before that committee perhaps will lend weight to that advice. It is my hope that our two education ministers will put aside their rhetoric and their attacks on schools, and on teachers and learn to take better care of the education of children in this country.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: South Australia: Leader of the Opposition

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferris, Sen Jeannie

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to complete the statement being read into Hansard by my colleague Senator Ferguson and I take up where he left off:

SPEECH.PARA: The copies of Cabinet Submissions which are distributed to Ministers each have characteristics which make them identifiable as Ministers' copies.
That does not apply to those draft submissions which are distributed to agencies for comment. In the case of the Rann photocopy, I am able to say that it was not a Ministerial copy.
I also add that the Rann photocopy had in the top left hand corner a dark patch, ie when the document was photocopied, someone had turned over a page.
That does not appear on Ministerial copies of Cabinet Submissions, because they are prepared on an automatic collating machine which photocopies the single sheets.
In relation to Cabinet meeting procedure, the Cabinet Submissions are distributed to Ministers in a locked case, to which the Minister has a key.
At Cabinet, all Submissions are placed in the centre of the table after discussion, ie handed back.
If a Minister did not attend a meeting, the likelihood is they would not even have read the documents or unlocked the case.
In any event, the Cabinet Submissions would normally be returned, ie John Olsen would have returned the papers in the Cabinet bag and placed them on the table for disposal.
I cannot guarantee that occurred, but that is ordinary practice.
What I can say is that the Cabinet Submission copy sent to John Olsen's Office is not the document identified to me as having been released by Mike Rann.
I can also say from my experience in working in government that there can be many and multiple sources of leaks.
Leaks from government are not uncommon.
I have no reason to believe that John Olsen leaked the material at all, and every reason to believe that he did not.

In relation to the water contract material that Mike Rann claims to have received, the only material I am aware of is that tabled by John Olsen in Parliament, being material which came from a filing cabinet of Richard Yeeles.
That cabinet was located in the Premier's Office on the 15th floor of the State Administration Centre.
Only the Premier's personal staff, myself and my deputy have access to the Premier's suite.

So the damaged Mr Foley will have no chance of taking on the leadership, clearing a path for John Hill.

BREAK.PARA: Alternatively, of course, he can make way for his other close and dear friend, Trish White. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eggleston, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to reply to Senator Murray's recent adjournment debate speech on the proposal to dam the Fitzroy River in the Kimberley region of Western Australia. I would like to provide evidence to the Senate and place on record that the damming of the Fitzroy River could well deliver strong economic growth to the region. Contrary to what Senator Murray stated in his adjournment debate speech, the damming of the Fitzroy means that significant net benefits most certainly could be achieved. The West Kimberley has the prospect of becoming an Australian food and fibre powerhouse.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, I would like to provide the Senate with some background information on the Fitzroy River. The catchment area of the Fitzroy is bigger than Victoria and, in flood, the volume of water from the Fitzroy is second only to the Amazon. In fact, it would fill Sydney Harbour in three and a half hours. However, at present the water resource of the Fitzroy is neither harvested nor utilised and, if used, this area would become a diverse agricultural production zone that would provide solid opportunities for food and fibre crops and generate at least $900 million in exports per year. This of course means jobs and new small business opportunities for Australians.

Senator Murray asserted that no appraisal is being undertaken into the environmental, social and long‐term economic wellbeing of the region. I would like to place on record in the Senate that this statement is totally untrue and unfounded.

Following a widely advertised invitation for expressions of interest, the state government of Western Australia on 29 July 1997 announced the appointment of Western Agricultural Industries Pty Ltd—I will refer to them as WAI in the rest of this speech—as the preferred proponent to carry out an environmental impact statement and feasibility study into the West Kimberley land and water resource development proposal.

WAI is an Australian company comprising Queensland Cotton Holdings and Kimberley Agricultural lndustries—both proprietary limited companies—and they will start their feasibility study into the damming of the Fitzroy in approximately two months time. That study is expected to take two years for completion. WAI will study all aspects of the planned project, including flora, fauna, hydrology, environment, heritage, culture and social impact.

WAI has recently completed a six-year pre-feasibility study of the Fitzroy River and the West Kimberley area. It is WAI's plan to harvest 25 per cent of the annual flow of the Fitzroy River and leave 75 per cent for environmental use.

WAI states that broad community participation will be sought in the problem solving and decision making process with regard to the damming of the Fitzroy, and this will be brought about by one‐to‐one meetings, discussion groups, workshops, speaking engagements and telephone surveys as required. WAI studies will provide evidence that economic growth will be generated from the damming of the Fitzroy River and that significant net benefits will be delivered.

Trials of cotton and other crops, in conjunction with CSIRO and Agriculture WA will continue to assess the environmental and economic sustainability of fibre and food crops using bore water for irrigation. An aquifer south of Broome will be investigated to define annual sustainable water yield levels, and this will form the basis of a pilot project to prove the economic viability of the next possible stage of the project, which would involve construction of a water storage dam. A very important point to make is that no decision can be made on the likely site of any dam or dams until the feasibility study has been completed.

The full development of this project is estimated to take 10 to 15 years and will involve an area estimated to be 225,000 hectares. The initial crop will be cotton, which has existing market opportunities in which Australia holds an internationally competitive position as the fourth largest cotton exporting country.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

(b) No.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bourne, Sen Vicki

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 20 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) (a) What are the spousal and defacto entitlements for members of the Australian Defence Forces (ADF); and (b) can a copy of the guidelines, regulations, directives or orders regulating the benefits and conditions of spouses in the defence forces be provided.

(2) (a) What are the entitlements for members of the ADF who have same sex partners; and (b) can a copy of the guidelines, regulations, directives or orders regulating the benefits and conditions of same sex couples in the defence forces be provided.

(3) (a) What are the entitlements for members of the ADF who have defacto partners; and (b) can a copy of the guidelines, regulation, directives or orders regulating the benefits and conditions of de facto couples in the defence forces be provided.

(4) What, if any, regulations exist to recognise spouses, defacto partners and same sex partners in the ADF: (a) how is this done; and (b) what evidence is required to prove defacto or same sex couple status.
(5) Who decides whether a spouse, defacto or same sex partner is entitled to `partner' benefits in the defence forces.

(6) What are the entitlements for members of the ADF: (a) with a family; (b) without a family; and (c) can a copy be provided of the guidelines, regulations, directives or orders regulating the benefits and conditions of: (i) members with a family, and (ii) members without a family; in the defence forces.

(7) What, if any, regulations exist to recognise spouses, defacto partners and same sex partners as dependants of members of the ADF: (a) how is this done; and (b) what evidence is required to prove dependency status for defacto couples and same sex couples.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with advice to the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel the following information is provided in response to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (l) to (3) The Manual of Salaries and Conditions of Service for the Permanent Forces and the Manual of Pay and Conditions of Service for the Reserve Forces contains details of all financial conditions of service for members of the ADF. The entitlements of members with family are applicable to members in de jure marriages and ADF recognised de facto marriages.

The ADF does not recognise same sex partners, consequently, there are no regulations covering the recognition of same sex partners. Members with same sex partners do not have access to additional entitlements other than to those available to members without family.
The Manual for the members of the Permanent Forces consists of four volumes
. Volume 1—Salary, Allowances, Bounties and Gratuities;
. Volume 2—Travel and Removal Entitlements;
. Volume 3—Accommodation, Leave, Compensation and Other Provisions; and
. Volume 4—Conditions Relating to Overseas Service.

Because of the size and number of volumes involved I have not produced a copy of the Manuals. A copy is held in the Parliamentary Library, however, if this does not meet the Senator's needs I could arrange for a copy to be provided.

Should the Senator require a synopsis of the ADF's Conditions of Service, a Parliamentary Research paper entitled `Conditions of Service in the Regular Defence Force' is also available from the Parliamentary Library. This document is presently being updated by library staff.

(4) Instruction 1001 of Volume 1 of the Manual for members of the Permanent Forces (copy provided) provides details on the procedure for recognition of a de facto marriage and the evidence a member may provide as proof that a relationship exists.
(a) De jure marriages are recognised on production of a marriage certificate by members. Recognition of de facto marriages is subject to the member providing suitable evidence of the relationship.

(b) Evidence may be provided under the following criteria: mutual support and interdependence; common household; elements of permanence or exclusivity in the relationship; recognition of marital status in public and private; mutual society and protection; and nurture and support of children.

(5) Applications for recognition of de facto marriages are generally approved at the unit level, however, where special circumstances exist or applications contain minimal evidence these are considered by the member's Service Office.

(6) (a) (b) and (c) The Manual of Salaries and Conditions of Service for the Permanent Forces and the Manual of Pay and Conditions of Service for the Reserve Forces contain details of all financial conditions of service for members of the ADF. Each instruction in these manuals clearly indicates whether it is applicable to members with family and/or members without family, but does not categorise conditions of service provisions under these headings. The entitlements of members with family are applicable to members in de jure marriages and ADF recognised de facto marriages.

(7) (a) and (b) Determination Number 45 of 1991 made under section 58B of the Defence Act 1903 provides for the recognition of dependants. In accordance with this determination a dependant in relation to a member is defined as the spouse of the member or a child. A spouse includes a de jure spouse or an ADF recognised de facto spouse. A child includes an adopted child, an ex-nuptial child, a foster child, a step-child or a ward who is a child of the member or spouse, is dependent on the member and is under 21 years of age or an invalid or infirm. A dependant is approved on provision of appropriate evidence (for example, marriage certificate, birth certificate or adoption papers) by the member. As the ADF does not recognise same sex partners, there are no regulations to recognise same sex partners as dependants of ADF members.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bourne, Sen Vicki

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Indonesian military open fire on 200 people who gathered outside the Mahkota Hotel in Dili in an attempt to see Mr Jamsheed Marker, the United Nations General Secretary's Special Representative on East Timor, in order to pass him documentation on human rights violations in East Timor.
(2) (a) Is it a fact that as many as three youths were killed and 45 were wounded, seven seriously; and (b) were 48 people detained and are 24 still being held in custody.

(3) (a) Can details be provided of the Government's reaction to the Indonesian military's attack; and (b) is the Government going to raise the issue in its dialogue with the Indonesian Foreign Affairs ministry.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to Senator Bourne's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There are unconfirmed reports that police fired some shots from handguns during a demonstration outside the Mahkota Hotel in Dili on 23 March 1997. The International Committee of the Red Cross has informed officers from the Australian Embassy in Jakarta that it was very likely that shots—probably fewer than 10—had been fired from handguns. The East Timor Roman Catholic Church's Commission on Justice and Peace said that they believed the police had used "simulated bullets".

(2) (a) Neither the ICRC nor the Commission on Justice and Peace have confirmed any deaths resulting from the incident. Information supplied to officers from our Embassy in Jakarta during a visit to East Timor from 6‐12 April suggests that approximately 29 people were treated for various injuries at the Motael Church clinic.

(b) An Amnesty International report of 26 March 1997 stated that 45 people were arrested following the incident, of which 24 remained in custody at the time of the report. The Australian Embassy in Jakarta has been advised that 33 persons have been charged following the incident and are currently in detention awaiting trial. The case is likely to be heard by the beginning of August 1997. All the defendants are being represented by the Yayasan Lembaga Bantuan Hukum (an Indonesian legal aid foundation) which Australia has funded from the Human Rights Fund.

(3) (a) The Government has and continues to urge the Indonesian authorities to ensure that those detained be given their full rights and due process under the law and be treated in accordance with international human rights standards. The Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Downer, raised the human rights situation in East Timor at his latest meeting with Indonesian Foreign Minister Alatas in Hong Kong on 30 June. He also discussed the East Timor situation, in light of the incident at the Mahkota Hotel, with East Timor Governor Abilio Soares when he met him in Ambon on 24 April.

(b) In addition to the Minister's raising of these issues with the Indonesians the Government has asked our Embassy in Jakarta to take up this matter. Officers from the Embassy subsequently raised the issue with various officials and independent human rights observers in East Timor, during a visit in April 1997. The Embassy officers specifically raised Australian Government concerns regarding violence against demonstrators and suspects in the Mahkota Hotel incident. They also raised general human rights concerns in East Timor. These concerns were raised with a number of officials including the military command in Dili, the Police Chief, the Chief Prosecutor, the Komnas Ham (Indonesian National Commission on Human Rights) and the local leadership (civil and military) in Aileu, Baucau and Viqueque Kabupatens.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister of Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 24 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How much of Tasmania's $58 million Regional Telecommunications Infrastructure Fund will be retained by the Government for administration or other costs.
(2) To what use will the funds be put.
(3) What schemes have been considered in any way for fund allocation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Of the $58 million Regional Telecommunications Infrastructure Fund (launched as Networking the Nation on 20 June 1997), allocated to Tasmania over the five year life of the program, a total of $2.229 million will be retained by the Commonwealth Government for administrative costs.
(2) The objective of Networking the Nation is to assist the economic and social development of regional, rural and remote Australia by funding projects which:
. enhance telecommunications infrastructure and services in regional, rural and remote areas;
. increase access to, and promote use of, services available through telecommunications networks in regional, rural and remote areas;
. reduce disparities in access to such services and facilities between Australians in regional, rural and remote areas and those in urban areas.

The RTIF Board has agreed to the provision of funding for the establishment and operation of the Centre of $1.5 million per annum for three years from 1997‐98 to 1999‐2000. ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, an 24 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many inquiries into complaints referred to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (HREOC) by the Sex Discrimination Commissioner have been held since 1984.

(2) How many inquiries have been held into: (a) complaints of indirect sex discrimination, (b) complaints of direct sex discrimination, (c) complaints of direct discrimination because of a characteristic imputed to or pertaining to the sex of the aggrieved person, (d) complaints of non-intentional direct sex discrimination that was subconscious or systemic in nature; and (e) complaints of sexual harassment.

(3) What is the overall success rate for complaints, other than those who settle or withdraw from an inquiry, and what are the statistics for success or dismissal of the complaints in each of the categories in (2).
(4) How many inquires into complaints referred to the HREOC by the Race Discrimination Commissioner have been held.
(5) What is the rate of success or dismissal of complaints of race discrimination in relation to: (a) employment; (b) accommodation; and (c) services.
(6) What is the record of individual hearing commissioners in dismissing complaints and finding complaints substantiated.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised that these answers were provided by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (HREOC) and that the statistics are as at 8 July 1997. I am further advised that, unless the contrary intention appears, for the purpose of all answers concerning complaints/inquiries under the Federal Sex Discrimination Act 1984 (SDA), "inquiry" has been interpreted to mean the public inquiry that is held after a notice referred to in section 63 of the SDA is issued. Similarly, for the purpose of all answers concerning complaints/ inquiries under the Federal Racial Discrimination Act 1975 (the RDA), "inquiry" has been interpreted to mean the public inquiry that is held after a notice referred to in section 25E of the RDA is issued.
(1) How many inquiries into complaints referred to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (HREOC) by the Sex Discrimination Commissioner have been held since 1984.
(a) There have been 141 inquiries into 223 complaints where the inquiry has been completed and a decision handed down.
(b) There are 2 inquiries that are part-heard and 10 inquiries that have been completed but are awaiting decision.
(c) There are 8 inquiries that have been adjourned sine die (usually for want of prosecution): [statistics only available from 1994 to present].
(d) 19 inquiries have settled after the first day of hearing [statistics only available from 1994 to present].
(2) How many inquiries have been held into:

(a) complaints of indirect sex discrimination, (b) complaints of direct sex discrimination, (c) complaints of direct discrimination because of a characteristic imputed to or pertaining to the sex of the aggrieved person, (d) complaints of non-intentional direct sex discrimination that was subconscious or systemic in nature; and (e) complaints of sexual harassment.

For the purpose of this answer, "inquiries" is defined as public inquiries that have been held and completed and includes those where a decision has been handed down and those that are awaiting decision. Below each set of statistics are figures from 1994 onwards for those inquiries that were commenced in relation to each category but not completed (that is, the complaint settled or was withdrawn sometime after the first day of public inquiry).

It has also been assumed from the manner in which questions (a) to (d) are worded above that the term "sex discrimination" is used to refer to discrimination on the grounds of sex, potential pregnancy, pregnancy or marital status but not to sexual harassment as this is the subject of a separate question in paragraph (e).

It follows that the statistics provided below do not incorporate complaints of sexual harassment into the answers to questions (a) to (d) even though sexual harassment is itself a form of sex discrimination. The only category in which sexual harassment complaints are counted is in response to question (e). However, where an inquiry considered a complaint of sexual harassment as well as a separate complaint of sex discrimination (for example that the complainant was unlawfully dismissed) the separate complaint of sex discrimination has been included in the statistics given in relation to questions (a) to (d) as well as the sexual harassment complaint being included in the statistics in response to question (e).

Furthermore, it should be noted that one inquiry can be held into multiple complaints by the complainant(s) against the respondent(s) in relation to a particular fact situation. For example, where an inquiry was held into complaints of direct and indirect sex discrimination as well as a complaint of sexual harassment then the inquiry is counted as being one inquiry under each of the relevant complaint categories in (a) to (e).

Finally, in answering the questions, it is assumed that the reference to "direct sex discrimination" is a reference to complaints made under subsections 5(1),6(1) and 7(1) and that the reference to "indirect discrimination" refers to complaints made under subsections 5(2), 6(2) and 7(2) of the SDA.
(a) Complaints of indirect sex discrimination; 17 inquiries have been completed into complaints of indirect discrimination. [4 inquiries were commenced but not completed]
(b) Complaints of direct sex discrimination; 94 inquiries have been completed into complaints of direct discrimination. [43 inquiries were commenced but not completed]

(c) Complaints of direct discrimination because of a characteristic imputed to or pertaining to the sex of the aggrieved person. 43 inquiries have been completed into complaints of direct discrimination because of a characteristic imputed to or pertaining to the sex of the aggrieved person (including pregnancy or marital status). [41 inquiries were commenced but not completed]
(d) Complaints of non-intentional direct sex discrimination that was subconscious or systemic in nature.

The SDA does not refer to "systemic discrimination". The term is generally used to refer to situations in which a complex of directly and/or indirectly discriminatory practices operate to produce general disadvantage to persons in the same category as the individual. It is unclear what is meant by the reference to "subconscious" or "non-intentional" direct discrimination. Because the question is unclear, the answer is given under 2 categories.
(i) Direct systemic discrimination

This term refers to those complaints where the particular complainant experiences direct discrimination (for example, they are denied a particular benefit because of a characteristic imputed to people of a particular marital status) and this policy applies across the board to all persons in the same category as the complainant.
There are 14 inquiries that have been completed in relation to direct systemic discrimination.
(ii) Indirect systemic discrimination

This term refers to those complaints where the particular complainant alleges that he or she is aggrieved because he or she is a member of a particular group which is unable to comply with a facially neutral requirement or condition that is unreasonable. The discrimination is systemic in that all persons who share the relevant characteristic of the complainant are unable to comply with the facially neutral requirement or condition (for example, it is a requirement or condition of eligibility to apply for a particular job that a person must first have completed a period of employment in another related job, but the latter has in the past been limited to people of a particular sex or marital status and the imposition of this limitation is not reasonable).
There have been 9 inquiries completed in relation to indirect systemic discrimination.
[1 inquiry was commenced but not completed]
(e) Complaints of sexual harassment.
There have been 69 inquiries completed in relation to complaints of sexual harassment.
[118 inquiries were commenced but not completed]

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 25 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What actions has the Australian Government taken to date in responding to the Turkish military invasion of northern Iraq on 13 May 1997.
(2) What is the attitude of the Australian Government to the invasion of up to 50,000 Turkish troops into northern Iraq.
(3) Has the Minister been advised by the department of the widespread and systemic abuse, by invading Turkish troops, of the human rights of the Kurdish population of northern Iraq.

(4) Is the Minister aware that hostile acts perpetrated by Turkish troops in northern Iraq include repeated shelling of Iraqi towns and villages, the death of civilians and the forced displacement of civilian Kurds living in the area.
(5) When will the Australian Government join the United Nations, the European Union and many other nations in condemning this act of aggression by Turkish military forces.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Government is aware of the Turkish military incursion into northern Iraq. Our relevant Missions including those in Ankara and at the United Nations, New York, have kept the Government informed of developments. Turkey has acknowledged that as many as 50,000 troops crossed the border in an operation directed against guerrillas of the Kurdish Workers Party (PKK) which has been waging an insurgency in support of a separate Kurdish State since 1984. Turkish authorities have indicated that most of the forces have been recalled but the operation seems likely to continue for several more weeks at least. The media has not been allowed into operational areas and objective and independent reporting has not been possible. The Turkish operation is being conducted jointly with one of the main Kurdish factions established in northern Iraq—the Kurdistan Democatic Party (KDP).

(2) Australia has taken a consistent position regarding Turkish incursions into northern Iraq, the previous major intervention against the PKK having taken place in March 1995. Because the PKK is a terrorist organisation which is a threat to Turkey's security and has been responsible for the deaths of thousands of people, its actions cannot be condoned. At the same time Australia respects the sovereignty of Iraq and has noted Turkey's claims that it respects the sovereignty of Iraq's territory. Australia has consistently urged Turkey to limit any such operations against the PKK only to what is required to guarantee its security and with respect for human rights and the well‐being of the civilian population. The Australian Government expects Turkey to withdraw as quickly as possible.

(3) The Government is aware of the claims, principally by supporters of the PKK, of widespread and systemic abuse. The situation on the ground is not clear, but the Government is not aware of any substantiated evidence to support such claims.

(4) The Turkish ground forces have been backed by artillery, heavy armour and air support. The Turkish General Staff said that it had targeted and successfully attacked a number of identified PKK bases and strongholds, and that as many as three thousand guerillas and PKK supporters had been killed or captured and that others have fled across the border into Iran and Syria.

(5) A number of countries, including Iraq, Iran, Syria, Egypt and the United Arab Emirates have criticised the intervention. Iraq lodged a formal protest claiming that Turkey had violated Iraqi sovereignty and called for an immediate withdrawal. Other countries, including the United Kingdom and France, have urged Turkey to keep its actions to within acceptable limits and to respect human rights. The United States has acknowledged Turkey's right to defend itself against a vicious terrorist organisation and accepted Turkish assurances that the operation had a limited scope and that Turkey would withdraw once it had achieved its objectives. UN Secretary General Annan has urged Turkey to withdraw as soon as possible. We understand that most of the Turkish objectives have been achieved and only a small contingent remains in northern Iraq in support of the KDP. Australia supports an early withdrawal by Turkey from Iraq. At the same time, while Australia deplores any actions of the Turkish Government which fall short of internationally accepted standards of human rights and behaviour, it also condemns the actions of organisations, such as the PKK, which have resorted to terrorism and violence to achieve an independent Kurdistan.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 26 June, 1997:

(4) Will the Minister examine the matter and raise the concerns of both Australian environmental organisations and their Indian counterparts with P&O, particularly in the context of an Australian registered company acting in a manner which would be unacceptable in Australia.

(7) Does an Australian Coal trading company, Glencore Australia, have contracts to ship coal to Bombay Suburban Electricity Supply Company, despite Supreme Court orders in India ordering the power company to switch the relevant power station to gas firing.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I was aware that P&O Ports, Australia had signed an agreement to construct a major port facility at Vadhavan, India.

(4) As far as I am aware, P&O Australia has not acted in a manner which would be unacceptable in Australia. No environmental organisations have raised concerns with my Department either here or in India about the proposed project. ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Papua New Guinea: Export Finance and Insurance Corporation

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 26 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware that during the approval process for the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation (EFIC) loan to Lihir Gold the then Minister for the Environment recommended that a number of conditions be imposed on the loan and that this recommendation was accepted.

(2) Is the Minister aware that as a result of this recommendation EFIC has received from Lihir Gold a number of reports including one report commissioned from Dames and Moore and one from a Papua New Guinean consultant, which examine a range of issues relevant to the recommendations of the Minister for the Environment.

(3) Is the Minister aware that the Environment Protection Group (EPG) which provided the recommendations to the Minister for the Environment has been unable to obtain a copy of these reports from EFIC and therefore is unable to ascertain whether the recommendations made by the EPG, then Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency, and the Minister have been implemented.

(4) Will immediate steps be taken to ensure that, in future, the work of the department is not hampered by its apparent lack of a mechanism to ensure that the recommendations of the Minister and the department are properly implemented.
(5) Will the Minister immediately seek copies of the report from the EFIC; if not, why not.
(6) Will the Minister make these reports publicly available; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, I understand that the former Minister for the Environment, Senator Faulkner, recommended 15 conditions to the Action Minister in relation to the risk insurance proposed to be provided by Export Finance and Insurance Corporation (EFIC). I understand that the Action Minister's decision to approve the provision of sovereign risk insurance took into account the recommendations and the undertakings given by the company.
(2) I understand that EFIC has received a number of reports on aspects of the environmental management regime and performance of Lihir Gold operations on Lihir Island.

(3) The recommendations made by the Minister for the Environment, and undertakings subsequently entered into by Lihir Gold, did not specify that reports be provided to the Environment Protection Group.

It is the responsibility of the Action Minister to take into account the recommendations arising from the assessment process. In this case the Action Minister directed EFIC to negotiate with Lihir Gold. I understand that EFIC did obtain undertakings required by the Action Minister and continues to monitor the project.

(4) Administration of the EPIP Act by my department has not been hampered in relation to Lihir. The recommendations by the former Minister for the Environment were taken into account prior to a final decision by EFIC.
(5) See 3 above.
(6) The undertaking given by the company was to publish the findings on the environmental performance of the company in its annual report.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Veterans' Affairs: Appeal Mechanisms

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 9 July 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What appeal mechanisms are currently available for those people who apply for payments from the department.
(2) What is the normal process through which appeals would be conducted, for example, departmental review officer first, followed by an external body.

(3) For the past 5 years, if figures are available: (a) how many appeals have been made against decisions of the department; (b) how many were resolved in the department's favour; (c) how many were resolved in the clients' favour; (d) is there some breakdown as to the nature of the appeals; and (e) at what level in the review process were the appeals finalised.
(4) Does a representative of the department physically appear before review bodies or does the department simply submit written submissions.
(5) Does the Repatriation Commission have any involvement in the appeals process.
(6) Has any research been undertaken as to whether people view the appeals process as adequate; if so, what were the findings of that research.
(7) Are there any imminent changes to the process.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) & (2) Claims for pensions, allowances and benefits are determined by delegates of the Repatriation Commission.

Where a claimant for compensation (disability pension or war widow(er)s' pension) is dissatisfied with a decision of the delegate, he or she can appeal to the Veterans' Review Board (VRB). If the person is dissatisfied with the VRB's decision,
he or she can appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT).

Where a claimant for income support (service pension, partner service pension or widow(er)s' pension) is dissatisfied with a decision of the delegate, he or she can request a review of the decision by a senior delegate. If the claimant is still dissatisfied, he or she can appeal to the AAT. The VRB has no jurisdiction in these cases.
A further right of appeal on a question of law lies to the Federal Court and then to the High Court in both compensation and income support matters.

The Repatriation Commission has the power to review its own decisions on compensation under s.31 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, while under s.57 of the legislation a person can request the Commission to review its decision on an income support matter. The powers under s.31 and s.57 are delegated to certain officers of the Department. The aim of these reviews is to get decisions right at the primary level and to reduce appeals to the next tier of determination; that is, to the VRB on compensation matters and to the AAT on income support matters.
From 1995/96, the Repatriation Commission commenced reviews by delegates of all appeals on compensation matters lodged with the VRB.

(b) Decisions resolved in Repatriation Commission's favour

ANSWER.PARA: Table 2—AAT Appeals

ROW.ENTRY: Appeals lodged against Repatriation Commission/ VRB decisions*
(b) Decisions resolved in Repatriation Commission's favour

ANSWER.PARA: * Repatriation Commission decisions refer to income support matters and VRB decisions to compensation matters.
Table 3—Federal Court Appeals **

ANSWER.PARA: ** In a number of the cases in which clients were successful the courts remitted the matter for re‐hearing by the AAT on narrow points, yet, in effect, maintained the Parliamentary intent as submitted by the Repatriation Commission. Upon re‐hearing in the AAT, the clients have not necessarily succeeded.
Note: In the above tables, statistics for appeals lodged and withdrawn before decision are not shown.
3 (d) Statistics by nature of appeal are not recorded.

(3) (e) Appeals can be finalised at each level of the reviews process. For example, if an appeal is accepted by the VRB then the appeal is finalised at the VRB level. However, if the appeal is rejected by the VRB, the claimant can appeal to the AAT. If the appellant is dissatisfied with the AAT's decision, he or she can appeal to the Federal Court, but only on a question of law.
(4) A representative of the Department does not usually appear before the VRB. The Department provides written submissions on behalf of the Repatriation Commission.
The Department appears or is represented by legal counsel, on behalf of the Repatriation Commission, before other appeal bodies.
(5) The Department acts on behalf of the Repatriation Commission.

(6) The Department is not aware of any such research. However, the Repatriation Commission and the Department receive regular feedback from the ex‐service community on the determining system through various forums with ex‐service organisation representatives and communication with individual veterans and dependants on their cases. While the Department does receive some criticism of the system from time to time from individual veterans, the veteran community as a whole is generally happy with the system.

(7) The Attorney‐General has announced that the Government has agreed in principle to amalgamate several merit review tribunals. The present Administrative Appeals Tribunal, Social Security Appeals Tribunal, Veterans' Review Board, Immigration Review Tribunal and Refugee Review Tribunal are to be merged to create a single tribunal to be called the Administrative Review Tribunal.

Can you confirm that these loans are deemed as actual means under the revised Austudy Means test and may make some students with self employed parents ineligible for Austudy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —The response to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware of instances where universities arrange deferred repayment back loans for the costs associated with the flying training component of aviation courses.

These arrangements have been created because the Commonwealth does not (nor has it ever) provided funding to higher education institutions to cover the cost of pilot training. The Commonwealth has taken this view on the basis that the costs associated with obtaining a pilot's license and the undertaking of practical flying training should be born by individuals, not taxpayers.

Under the Higher Education Funding Act 1988, HECS liable and non‐fee paying HECS exempt students must be able to complete their chosen award without facing course related charges imposed by their higher education institution. Universities may not, therefore, charge fees for units which are compulsory parts of HECS liable courses.

Under some circumstances, however, a student may be charged fees for units which would give credit towards a course, as long as the student can choose to complete the course without undertaking those units. This is the basis on which institutions are able to charge fees for the costs associated with obtaining a pilot's license and the undertaking of practical flying training. My Department is in the process of formally writing to the universities involved in the provision of aviation courses to confirm that these courses comply with these provisions of the Higher Education Funding Act 1988.

Under the Actual Means Test (AMT) all expenditure and savings are included in a family's actual means except those related to the main business activity of the family. As the AMT measures expenditure and savings, and borrowings are a spending resource, any expenses which are paid from borrowings must be included as part of the actual means available to a family.
The changes to the administration of Austudy that I announced on 20 February, clarify the treatment of loans in the Actual Means Test for Austudy. Loans are treated in two ways.

Firstly the outlay or purchase price funded by loans for the principal family home, other real estate expenditure and motor vehicles should not be reported as estimated expenditure in the year of applying for Austudy. However, repayments of principal and interest in the year of study for these items are to be included as expenditure.

Secondly, the outlay or purchase price funded by loans for all other items including education should be included as estimated expenditure The estimated repayments of principal and interest for these items are not to be reported as expenditure.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, without notice, on 19 March 1997 (Official Hansard page 1818):

BREAK.PARA: Is it not the case that the Actual Means Test in interpreting debt as expenditure severely disadvantaging rural families whose incomes fluctuate from year to year and who need to make up that difference through debt.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —The response to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Rural families receive special consideration under the Actual Means test. For example, Sole Trader Primary Producers and families in receipt of Drought Relief Payment or Farm Household Support payments are exempted from the AUSTUDY Actual Means Test. Isolated families also receive a discount off their actual means when in receipt of the isolated boarders' concession.

For the purposes of the Actual Means Test, loans fall into two categories. For loans for the principal family home, other real estate expenditure and motor vehicles, the purchase price should not be included in estimated expenditure in the current year. Repayments of principal and interest in the

current year should be included in expenditure estimates. For loans for other items, the outlay only should be reported as estimated expenditure in the current year. Repayment of principal and interest should not be reported as expenditure. Neither business expenditure, including business loans, or business assets are counted in the Actual Means Test.

The Actual Means Test is an estimate of expenditure for the year of study and therefore it is sensitive to fluctuations in a family's current financial situation. The Actual Means Test like the AUSTUDY Income Test allows the family whose circumstances change within the year of study to have their eligibility and level of entitlement re‐assessed at any time throughout the year of study.
